loans.name: Ses

texts.en:
Mrs. Ses R. is a villager in Angk Ta Phouk village in Takeo province. She is a door-to-door wedding beautician who earns income to support her family. She is also a dessert seller. Her husband, Mr. Vuthy Hong, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support his family. He is also a photographer. She is the mother of three children who are all attending school.

Mrs. Ses R.'s problem is that she does not have a car to transport her wedding beauty supplies. To solve this problem, she is applying for a loan to have enough money to buy a car.

loans.use: To buy a car

loans.name: Millions Group

texts.en:
Jenilyn E. is from the village of Magsaysay, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 24 years old. Jenilyn is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Millions.

Jenilyn is single and has 1 infant child. To make a living, Jenilyn owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting, harvesting, and selling bananas, root crops, corn, and coconut. Jenilyn has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Jenilyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jenilyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase harvesting equipment. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Jenilyn from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase harvesting equipment.

loans.name: 01.05.20 Group

texts.en:
Thuy L. T. (4) is a 44 year old femaL. living in the town of Thieu Hoa Thanh Hoa. Thuy is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 20 (43835).

Thuy is married and has 2 school-aged children. To making a living, Thuy operates a family member's business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. WhiL. not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising cattL. for saL..  Thuy has been engaged in this business for over 13 years and earns approximately 1.500.000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2004, Thuy joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Thuy has successfully repaid a previous loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future. She is now requesting a new loan of 5.310.000 VND, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future. The loan will be the 12th loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Thuy plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1.  N. T. nghia (34) is a 58 year old femaL. who is requesting a 4.248.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.
2.  P. T. thuoc (35) is a 56 year old femaL. who is requesting a 4.248.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.
3.  N. T. lien (36) is a 50 year old maL. who is requesting a 4.248.000 VND loan to support his business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.
4.  N. T. thuy (37) is a 62 year old femaL. who is requesting a 4.248.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

Thuy L. T. (4) là 44 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thieu Hoa Thanh Hoa.  Thuy là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 5 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 20 (43835).

Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gia súc để bán.  Thuy thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 13 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Thuy kiếm được khoảng 1.500.000 VND.  Vào 2004, Thuy đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Thuy đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.310.000 VND.

Khoản vay sẽ là 12th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:
1.  N. T. nghia (34) là 58 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.248.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.
2.  P. T. thuoc (35) là 56 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.248.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.
3.  N. T. lien (36) là 50 tuổi nam.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.248.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.
4.  N. T. thuy (37) là 62 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.248.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.

Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:
Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ Hỗ trợ Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future.

loans.name: Lerio Group

texts.en:
Violeta M. is from the village of Looc Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. She is 43 years old. Violeta is the leader of a three-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Lerio.

Violeta is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Violeta owns and operates a retail store, selling daily use products such as pancit canton, noodles, milk, coffee, canned goods, shampoo, soap and toothpaste. Violeta has been engaged in her business for more than 10 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Violeta joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living and business situation. Violeta is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Violeta from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Khoem

texts.en: Mrs. Khoem V., who was born in 1960, lives in Si Sla village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Non Phoeut, are farmers who own a  4-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support their family; her husband also owns an agricultural machine. Mrs. Khoem V. has some problems because her field's soil is infertile. To improve production, she is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer, gasoline and pesticide. She is the mother of three children: one is a student, one is a laborer, and one helps with his parents’ businesses. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, gasoline and pesticide

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.es:
En la parroquia Quiroga de la  ciudad de Calceta, localidad donde la gente se dedica en gran parte a la agricultura, cría de animales  y a la venta de sus productos, se reúne cada quince días  El Banco Comunal Quiroga.

La Señora Mercedes es socia del Banco Comunal hace ya seis años y le ha gustado por la facilidad que dan para realizar los pagos. Tiene 53 años de edad,  es casada hace 28 años y tiene cuatro hijos, todos mayores pero una vive con ella, ya que es madre soltera y tiene una pequeña hija que es la ilusión de la socia.  Su esposo es chofer de un taxi amigo.

Ella es ama de casa pero también tiene una pequeña granja de pollos y chanchos, compra los chanchos cuando están pequeños los cría por cuatro meses y cuando tengan un peso adecuado los ofrece a los comerciantes que llegan hasta su casa a comprarle sus animalitos, los pollos los compra en Pronaca en Calceta los tiene por dos meses y luego los vende a comerciantes o los entrega pelados a las tiendas, trabaja todos los días unas tres a cuatro horas al día.

Con este crédito quiere construir otro galpón para meter más pollos.
 
Su meta son tener una casa en Manta.
texts.en:
The Quiroga Communal Bank meets in the Quiroga parish of the city of Calceta every 15 days. This is a place where most of the people work in agriculture, raising animals, and selling their products.

Mercedes has been a member of the communal bank for six years.  She has liked the ease of making the payments.  She is 53 years old, and she has been married for 28 years.  She has four children, who are all grown.  One child lives with her because she is a single mother with a small daughter.  This granddaughter is the light of her life.  Her husband is a Taxi Amigo driver.

She is a housewife, but she also has a small farm with chickens and pigs.  She buys the pigs when they are little.  She raises them for four months, and when they weigh enough she sells them to merchants who come to her house to buy her animals.  She buys the chickens in Pronaca in Calceta.  She has them for two months, and then she sells them to merchants or delivers them plucked to the stores.  She works three or four hours everyday.

She wants to use this loan to build another coop for more chickens.

Her goal is to have a house in Manta.

loans.use: To build a chicken coop

loans.name: Sean

texts.en:
Mrs. Sean N. lives in Si Sla village in Takeo province. She was born in 1955. She and her husband, Mr. Khea Koch, are farmers who own a 1.5-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support their family.

Her problem is that her rice field is infertile. To improve production, Mrs. Sean N. is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer. With the rest of the loan she will hire a plow machine to plow her field and a farm laborer.

Mrs. Sean N. has three children. Two are laborers and one helps with the parents’ business. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her rice field.

loans.name: Khiev

texts.en:
Mrs. Khiev M. was born in 1984. She lives in Si Sla village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Chatha Toem, is a taxi driver who is able to earn some money to support his family.

She has a problem because her field is infertile. To improve production, Mrs. Khiev M. is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide. With the rest of the loan she will hire farm laborers and a plow to plow her field.

Mrs. Khiev M. has a two-year-old child. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.name: Soria Elizabeth

texts.es:
En la parroquia Quiroga de la  ciudad de Calceta, localidad donde la gente se dedica en gran parte a la agricultura, cría de animales  y a la venta de sus productos, se reúne cada quince días  El Banco Comunal Quiroga.

 La señora Soria tiene 37 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre hace 21 años, de esta relación procreo 4 hijos, dos de ellos están estudiando en la universidad y los otros en  el colegio lo cual es una carga muy difícil por los gastos que esto genera, ella junto a su familia viven en una finca donde además de cuidar le permiten criar sus animales.

Se dedican junto con su esposo a la cría de animales porcino y vacuno, además de ciertas aves de corral, su esposo trabaja desde las 4 am en lo que es el ordeñar  el ganado y continua hasta las 15h00 en sus otras ocupaciones del campo, venden leche y queso que la señora se encarga de elaborar y que tres veces por semana llevan a entregar a tiendas en Calceta.  Sus hijos  se encargan de entregar el queso. 

Este crédito lo van a emplear en comprar una vaca parida y una chancha preñada que le están vendiendo para aumentar la producción de leche y para criar los chanchitos para luego venderlos. Es su cuarto ciclo en el Banco Comunal y le gusta por la facilidad para conseguir los créditos.
 
Sus sueños son comprar una finca y tener su casa propia.
texts.en:
In Quiroga parish, in the city of Calceta, a locality where people are dedicated mainly to agriculture, raising livestock, and the sale of their products, the Quiroga Communal Bank meets every 15 days

Soria is 37 years old and has lived in a common-law marriage for 21 years.  This relationship has produced 4 children, 2 of whom are studying in the university and the remaining 2 are in school, which generates serious expenses.  She and her family live on a farm where, in addition to caring for livestock, they breed them as well.

Soria and her husband breed hogs and cows, plus some farm fowl.  Her husband starts work at 4:00am herding the cattle, and he continues until 3:00pm with other chores, including selling milk and cheese that his wife makes and he takes to stores in Calceta 3 times a week.  Her children are also in charge of delivering cheese.

This loan will be used to buy a cow that recently gave birth and a pregnant sow, to augment milk production and to raise pigs to sell later.  It's Soria's 4th loan cycle with the communal bank, which she likes because it is a convenient source of loans.

Soria's dreams are to buy a farm and to have her own house.

loans.use: BUYING A MILK COW AND A PREGNANT SOW

loans.name: Ly

texts.en: Ly S. A., 47 years old, resides with her small family in Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. Ly S. A. is a good housewife who stays A. home to care for her children and maintain the family's daily routine. She also cultivates a rice crop during the farming season. Ly S. A. is married and blessed with eight children, two of whom are married, and the other six are single. Almost all of her children are employed in various jobs. Her husband is a local construction foreman who has many employees who help provide service to his customers. Ly S. A. has a mother who is very ill, and this is why she requests a loan: for her mother to use to visit the doctor.

loans.use: To send her mother to visit the doctor.

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie B. is from the town of Banga. She is 42 years old. Rosalie is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Rosalie owns and operates a business venture in the agricultural sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Rosalie also helps her husband maintain their rice farm.

Rosalie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Rosalie has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Rosalie is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock and feed for her pigs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to pay the tuition fees of her children and to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase livestock and feed for her pigs

loans.name: Brenda

texts.en:
Brenda G. is from the village of Brgy. Buliwao, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 27 years old. Brenda is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Brenda owns and operates a business venture in the agricultural sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Brenda has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 30,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2008, Brenda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services in order to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Brenda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Brenda is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Brenda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, such as manure

loans.name: Yadira Agustina

texts.es:
En la parroquia Quiroga de la  ciudad de Calceta, localidad donde la gente dedicada  en gran parte a la agricultura y cría de  animales, se reúne cada quince días  El Banco Comunal Quiroga.

La señora Yadira tiene 32 años y mantiene una relación de unión libre hace 11 años de la cual procreo dos hijos de 11 años y otro hermoso pequeñito de dos años el que requiere de muchos cuidados, su marido cultiva el campo, viven en una casa que le dio su papá para que vivan.

Para ayudar a su marido en los gastos del hogar inicio un negocio de venta de ropa por catalogo,  su sistema de ventas es puerta a puerta, ya lleva tres años con esto y le ha ido bien a pesar de la crisis económica que también afecta nuestro país  comenta. Trabaja todos los días unas tres a cuatro horas por día, deja a crédito y cobra los fines de semana, los pedidos los realiza cada fin de  mes.

En los actuales momentos tiene varios pedidos, es así como va a utilizar este crédito para comprar más de sus mercaderías y quedar bien con sus clientes. Está en el Banco Comunal hace cuatro ciclos con este, está muy contenta ya que estos créditos le han ayudado a crecer en su negocio.
 
Sus sueños son tener su casa propia y  darles un futuro mejor a sus hijos.
texts.en:
In the Quiroga parish of the city of Calceta, a region where the people for the most part work in agriculture and raise animals,the community bank Quiroga meets every fifteen days.

Señora Yadira is 32 years old and has lived in a common-law marriage for 11 years. From this relationship she has two children who are 11 and another beautiful little son who is 2 and requires much care. Her husband raises crops. They live in a house that her father gave them to live in.

To help her husband with the household expenses, Yadira began a business of selling clothing by catalog. Her sales method is door to door. She has been doing this for three years, and it has gone well for her, in spite of the economic crisis that has also affected our country, she comments. She works every day for three or four hours. She leaves things on credit and collects on the weekends. She fills her orders at the end of every month.

Right now she has various orders. That is how she is going to use this loan -- to buy more of her merchandise and keep her customers happy. She has been in the community bank for four cycles with this business. She is very happy since these loans have helped her to expand her business.

Her dreams are to have her own house and give her children a better future.

loans.use: Buy pants, shirts, pajamas, dresses, blouses, etc.

loans.name: Ecelia

texts.en:
Ecelia P. is from the town of Banga. She is 47 years old. Ecelia is married and has 3 children, aged 23, 20 and 18. She is involved in farming and hog-raising. She plants and harvests rice crops with her husband. She also grows pigs for fattening and sale. Ecelia has big dreams for her children. She says she wants them to have bright futures.

Ecelia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Ecelia has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Ecelia is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase feed and livestock. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve her business and to support her family financially.

loans.use: To purchase feed and livestock

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en: Despite many difficulties in life brought about by poverty, 59 year old Yolanda B. never lost hope that someday an opportunity would come, as long as she believes and has strong faith. It was 1999 when Ahon sa Hirap, Inc., a microfinance institution partner of Kiva in the Philippines visited her house. She immediately joined, because she was so certain that this would be the beginning of her journey towards development. She is also encouraged by the full support of her husband, a construction worker, and their children in this endeavor. As a member of ASHI she did her best to perform well, and she has benefited. The trials and poverty that her family once experienced serves as her inspiration to work hard. Today, with the help of her husband and 5 children, their life is much better than it was before. She was able to send her children to school and to save for the future. She is applying for a loan of 20,000 PHP to finance her growing retail store. She will buy more grocery products, such as: canned goods, sacks of rice, beverages, noodles, soaps and shampoos, and other items to accommodate her increasing number of customers. She wanted to increase her profit so that she could continuously send her children to school and help her husband with their financial needs. She wanted to make money to renovate their house and to buy additional appliances. Her business plan is to build a mini-grocery for her children to manage. She is hoping and praying that ASHI and Kiva friends will support and assist her in her dreams until she reaches them.

loans.use: To buy sacks of rice, canned goods, beverages, soap, shampoo and other grocery products for retail

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en: Rosalina B.'s main source of income comes from preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. She is 63 years old, widowed and has three grown-up children. She is from the village of Brgy. Buliwao, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. Rosalina has been in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2006, Rosalina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Rosalina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Rosalina is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her fifth loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Si Bun

texts.en:
Mrs. Si Bun K. is a villager in Si Sla village in Takeo province. She was born in 1969. She is a farmer who owns a 2-hectare plot of land where she grows rice to sell to support her family.

Her problem is that her field is infertile, far away from an irrigation system, and it has a lot of insects. So, to improve production, Mrs. Si Bun K. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer, gasoline, and pesticide.

Her husband Mr. Kheng Khoem is an ice cream seller door-to-door and he owns an agric machine. Through those activities, they support three children. One daughter is a seamstress in a garment factory and two are students. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, gasoline, and pesticide

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina P. is from the town of Banga. She is 56 years old and married. She has nine children; the eldest is aged 36 and the youngest is 19. To make a living, Josefina plants and harvests rice for sale. Josefina has been engaged in farming for over 35 years now. She says she still works at the farm because she wants to support her family.

Josefina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josefina has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Josefina is requesting a new loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos, which will be used to purchase farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business and supplement her family's income.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Arn

texts.en:
Mrs. Arn M., 46 years old, lives in Si Sla village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Nhean San, are farmers who own a 2-hectare plot of land where they can grow rice to sell to support their family.

She has a problem because her field is infertile and it is far away from any irrigation system. So, to improve production, Mrs. Arn M. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer and gasoline. With the rest of the loan she will hire farm laborers and a plow to plow her field.

She is a mother of two children. One is a seamstress in a garment factory and the other is an ice cream seller. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and gasoline.

loans.name: Nieve Margarita

texts.es:
En la parroquia Quiroga de la  ciudad de Calceta, localidad donde la gente dedicada  en gran parte a la agricultura y cría de  animales, se reúne cada quince días  El Banco Comunal Quiroga.

Son muchos años los que la señora Nieves es socia del Banco Comunal y está muy cómoda ya que dice que las facilidades y beneficios que brinda la Fundación Espoir no lo va a encontrar en ninguna parte. Ella se encuentra casada hace muchos años y tuvo 6 hijos,  los mismos que ya tienen su propia familia solo su hija menor vive con ella y le acompaña. Su marido es agricultor.

Tiene un pequeño puesto de comida en el sector, trabaja todas las tardes ya que en la mañana se dedica a preparar todo lo que va a vender, además de comida prepara y vende ricos corviches y empanadas que a sus clientes les encantan, hay días que cierra su negocio a las 7 pm pero muchas veces a esa hora ya no tiene nada de lo que preparo, trabaja con la ayuda de su hija.

Espera comprar con este crédito unas mesas, sillas y productos para la preparación de sus deliciosos platos.

Su meta es tener un gran restaurante y gozar de mucha salud ella y los suyos.
texts.en:
In the parrish of Quiroga in the city of Calceta, an area where people are dedicated in large part to agriculture and raising animals, the Quiroga community bank meets every 15 days.

Nieves has been a member of the community bank for many years and she is very comfortable since the facilities and benefits provided to her by the Espoir Foundation cannot be found elsewhere. She has been married for many years and had six children, who now have their own families, except for her youngest daughter who lives with her and accompanies her. Her husband is a farmer.

She has a small food stand in the area. She works every evening since in the morning she is dedicated to preparing everything that she's going to sell. In addition to food, she prepares and sells delicious corviches and empanadas (fried food typical of the area) that her customers love. There are days when she closes her business at 7PM but many times, at that hour she no longer has anything to prepare. She works with the help of her daughter.

She hopes to buy with this loan some tables, chairs and products for the preparation of her delicious dishes.

Her goal is to have a great restaurant and that she and her family enjoy great health.

loans.use: Purchase tables, chairs and general groceries.

loans.name: Sieng

texts.en: Mrs. Sieng C. is 42 years of age and is a resident of Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. To pursue a daily income, Sieng C. always purchases small pieces of clothing in bulk at the cheapest price from garment factories and turns the clothing into furniture to sell. She makes the items such as cradles and mats, and she also saves many sets of her items before selling them to middlemen who then take them to retail at the market. She has a life partner in her husband, who assists her in the business and who also works in farming. Sieng C. said that she needs to hire a vehicle to travel from and to the garment factory in order to buy clothing. She hopes to own a vehicle by using a loan to buy one so that she can transport without hiring taxis.

loans.use: To buy a vehicle

loans.name: Genevive

texts.en:
Genevive P. is from the town of Banga. She is 32 years old. Genevive is married and has two children, aged 10 and 2. To make a living, Genevive runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Genevive also grows chickens and she hopes to acquire more chicks to grow.

Genevive joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Genevive has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Genevive is requesting a new loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos, which will be used to purchase a sack of feeds, broiler chicks and additional merchandise to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her family financially.

loans.use: To purchase one sack of feeds, broiler chicks and additional merchandise to sell

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey P., who lives in Prambei Mom village in Takeo province, was born in 1945. She is a mother of two children, both of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory. Srey is a farmer who owns a small piece of land upon which she cultivate rice to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Sorn Tob, is a cattle middleman who is able to earn a large amount to support his family.

Since her husband’s business is going well, Srey wants to try to expand. She would like a loan to buy three more cows to sell.

loans.use: To buy three cows

loans.name: Aurora Pastora

texts.es:
En la parroquia Quiroga de la  ciudad de Calceta, localidad donde la gente dedicada  en gran parte a la agricultura y cría de  animales, se reúne cada quince días  El Banco Comunal Quiroga.

La señora aurora tiene 46 años,  está casada hace 27 años, de esta relación tuvo 5 hijos tres de ellos son mayores de edad, el menor tiene 11 años y recuerda con mucha tristeza que uno de sus hijos falleció hace algunos años.  Su esposo es comerciante.

Ella y su esposo se dedican a la compra y venta de frutas y ganado, trabajan de lunes a sábado casi todo el día, recorren los campos comprando los productos de la zona  como naranjas, mandarinas, limón, sandias, melón, etc. Y las llevan a entregar una pequeña parte en Portoviejo pero el resto lo llevan a Quito ya que allá los venden a mejor precio por ser frutas de la costa. También de allá traen frutas de la sierra la misma que entregan a comerciantes de Portoviejo y Calceta. Con ellos trabaja uno de sus hijos.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en comprar frutas 	ya que tuvo que arreglar el carro y se quedo desfinanciado por lo cual utilizara este crédito para comprar mas de sus productos. Lleva en el Banco Comunal 30 ciclos es socia fundadora y siempre le  ha gustado por los beneficios que ha recibido de parte de la Fundación Espoir.
 
Su sueño es  tener una casa bien construida.
texts.en:
Every fifteen days the Quiroga Village Bank meets in the Quiroga parish in the city of Calceta, a region whose population is largely dedicated to agriculture and raising animals.  

Aurora is forty-six and has been married for twenty-seven years.  They've had five children, three now grown.  The youngest, eleven, remembers with great sadness how one of the other children passed away a few years ago.  Her husband is a merchant.

Aurora and her husband earn their living buying and selling fruit and cattle.  They work nearly all day Monday through Saturday.  They travel the countryside buying local produce like oranges, tangerines, lemons, watermelons, melons, etc.  They deliver a small percentage to Portoviejo, and take the rest to Quito where they can get the best price for coastal fruits.  They also deliver fruits from the mountains of Quito to merchants in Portoviejo and Calceta.  One of their children works with them.

Aurora plans to use her loan to purchase more fruits.  She'll use it to buy more product because she had to fix her car and she's out of money.  She's been with the bank for thirty loan cycles; she's a founding member and has always liked the benefits Fundación Espoir has provided her.  

Her dream is to have a well-constructed house.

loans.use: To buy oranges, melons, pineapples, watermelon, etc.

loans.name: Minda Luz

texts.en:
Minda Luz V. is from the town of Banga. She is 53 years old. Minda Luz is married and has three children, aged 7, 12 and 16. To make a living, Minda Luz raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice and corn for sale. She has been involved in farming for more than 30 years now. Like other mothers, she wants her children to finish college and have bright futures.

Minda Luz joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Minda Luz has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. 

Minda Luz is requesting a new loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos, which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Soeun

texts.en:
Born in 1971, Mrs. Soeun N. is a married woman who lives in Si Sla village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Mos Sok, are farmers who own a two-hectare plot of land upon which they cultivate rice to sell to support their family. Mos is also a construction worker. Through these activities they support seven children, two of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory, while the others are still in school.

Soeun’s problem is that it is time to pay for her children’s school fees, but she does not have enough money to do so. So Soeun is applying for a loan to pay the school fees and will use the rest to hire farm laborers and a cultivator to plow her field.

loans.use: To pay for school fees

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie L. is from the town of Banga. She is 40 years old. Rosemarie is married and has three children, aged 16, 15 and 13. To make a living, Rosemarie plants and harvests rice for sale. She also planted bananas on some part of her land. She sells her harvest to the market.

Rosemarie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosemarie has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Rosemarie is requesting a new loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos, which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's tuition fees.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Pak

texts.en:
Mrs. Pak S. has been spending almost all of her life cultivating crops, a skill she learned from her grandparent who died of senility years ago. Pak S. is married with four children, three of whom are no longer in school and work in different fields, while another one attends school. Her husband works in the farm fields frequently alongside her. Growing crops is an annual action that provides her with formal income. 

Pak S. dreams of having a vehicle; however, her income is only sufficient to support food for the family. This is the reason Pak S. requested a loan to buy a new motorcycle to serve as transportation for family. Additionally, her husband can use it to provide a taxi service for a profit.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle to provide transportation for the family

loans.name: Sam

texts.en:
Born in 1960, Mrs. Sam T. is married to Mr. Ben Sor (in the photo with Sam), and they live in Si Sla village in Takeo province. Sam is the mother of six children; four are attending school, one is a driver, and the other is helping with their parents’ businesses. Sam is a farmer who owns a one-hectare plot of land upon which she cultivates rice to sell to support her family, while her husband is a fisherman and farm laborer.

Sam has a problem in that it is time to work her rice field, but she does not have enough money to do so. Sam is thus requesting a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizer and pesticides, and hire farm laborers. With the remainder of the loan she wants to buy a bicycle for her children to ride to school.

loans.use: To buy rice seed, fertilizer and pesticides, and hire farm laborers

loans.name: Erita Argentina

texts.es:
En la parroquia Quiroga de la  ciudad de Calceta, localidad donde la gente dedicada  en gran parte a la agricultura y cría de  animales, se reúne cada quince días  El Banco Comunal Quiroga.

La señora Erita tiene 49 años de edad,  mantiene una relación de unión libre hace muchos años y tiene 4  hijos todos mayores de edad y solo uno de ellos vive en su casa, a pesar de que todos viven cerca de ella. Su marido tiene un kiosco en calceta donde vende refrescos.

Ella tiene un pequeño negocio de venta de dulces en el centro, por la cooperativa de transportes Calceta  junto al kiosco que tiene su marido, ella tiene una vitrina donde ofrece sus productos que son muy solicitados en especial por las personas que viajan a otras ciudades. Trabajan todos los días desde las 7 am hasta las 17h00, los dulces los compra en Junín.

Este crédito lo va a compartir la mitad para comprar dulces para su negocio y la otra parte para el negocio de  su marido para que compre frutas y jarabe para los refrescos. Este es su cuarto ciclo en el Banco Comunal y le gusta porque no hay que hacer  tantos trámites para recibir los créditos. 

Su sueño es gozar de salud para seguir trabajando.
texts.en:
In the Quiroga parrish in the city of Calceta, an area where people are dedicated in large part to farming and raising animals, the Quiroga Community Bank meets every 15 days.

Erita is 49 years old. She has maintained a common-law relationship for many years and has four adult children and only one of them lives in her house although all live close to her. Her husband has a kiosk in Calceta where he sells refreshments.

She has a small business selling candy in the center of town at the Calceta transportation cooperative next to her husband's kiosk. She has a display case where she offers her products that are in high demand, especially by the people who are traveling to other cities. They work every day from 7AM until 5PM. They purchase the sweets in Junín.

She is going to split this loan in half and use it to buy candy for her business and to buy fruit and syrups for the refreshments for her husband's business. This is her fourth loan with the community bank and she like it because she doesn't have to complete as many procedures in order to receive the loan.

Her dream is to enjoy good health so she can continue working.

loans.use: Purchase fruits, syrup, caramels, chocolates, gum, lollipops, etc.

loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
Elma E. is a jolly but strong 49-year-old mother. Her marriage life was never a success because her husband left her with their two children. However, this trial never became a burden to her; instead, she made it an opportunity to work hard and show that she could raise their children alone. 

The year 2009 is when she heard of Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.(ASHI) – a microfinance institution and partner of Kiva in the Philippines looking for poor women who would like to join the program. Along with four of her friends, she joined ASHI full of hopes and dreams. After a year of good performance and dedication, she slowly gained what she came for. From her loans, she was able to begin a business of buying and selling food, and from her profits, send her children to school. Her eldest son finished a course in a vocational school and is now a technician, while the youngest is still in high school. 

She applies for another loan of 15,000.00 pesos to increase the capital for her buying and selling business. She wants to buy more fruits, vegetables and fish to sell in her community and in the market. Her dreams are for her business to become stable, to buy a motorcycle that they can use to transport their goods, that her youngest will finish a course in college and, most especially, to renovate their house for more comfortable living. She is praying that more friends from ASHI and Kiva will support her and her family.

loans.use: To buy fruits, vegetables and fish for her business

loans.name: Flordelina

texts.en:
This is Flordelina N., a 42-year-old resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Rodrigo N., an employee, and is the mother of three children, two of whom are already in college while the youngest is still in elementary school. By the grace of God, Flordelina has managed to support her older children's schooling up to the college level. At this time, she is working hard to send her youngest to college - a dream for most Filipino parents like Flordelina as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Flordelina operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 pesos worth of cooking oil or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling at a piece rate. Her store is located adjacent to her house. She also manages a direct-selling business in which she sells branded apparel, shoes, cosmetics and other beauty products. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 350 to 500 Philippine pesos (Php) in sales every day for her variety store and direct-selling business.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php26,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Flordelina dreams to be able to give all her children a good and high-quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her fellowship* co-members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Mrs. Tuon  Sao Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan group has nine people, all located in Choes village in Takeo Province. Mrs. Tuon S. was born in 1980. She was selected village bank president by the other members, all of whom will use their portion of the loan for different purposes. She and her husband, Mr. Pot Chhoem, are farmers who own a 1-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support their family. Her husband is also a palm juice collector. Her problem is that her rice field has infertile soil so, to improve production, Mrs. Tuon S. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer. She is a mother of two children, both of whom are enrolled in the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn D. is from the town of Banga. She is 51 years old and married. She has four children, aged 23, 21, 15 and 13. To make a living, Merlyn plants and harvests rice for sale. Merlyn has been engaged in her business for over 23 years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

Merlyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merlyn has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Merlyn is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase farm inputs such as fertilizers. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs such as fertilizers

loans.name: Youn

texts.en: Mrs. Youn S. M. is married to Mr. Choeun Bouv and they are living in Srah Takuon village in Takeo province.  Youn S. M. was born in 1971 and owns a general store in the local village where she sells groceries to support her family. Her husband is a farmer and owns a 1.5-hectare plot of land used to cultivate rice which he sells to support his family. Her husband also buys and resells cattle and motorbikes. Since her husband’s business is going well, she wants to expand it. In order to expand the business, Mrs.Youn S. M. is requesting a loan to buy more cows for her husband to sell. The couple supports two children who are both students. Mrs.Youn S. M. and her husband are featured in this photo.

loans.use: To purchase more cows to sell

loans.name: Nancy

texts.es:
En la parroquia Quiroga de la  ciudad de Calceta, localidad donde la gente se dedica en gran parte a la agricultura, cría de animales  y a la venta de sus productos, se reúne cada quince días  El Banco Comunal Quiroga.

La señora Nancy es socia fundadora del Banco Comunal y lo dice con orgullo ya que gracias a eso se han ayudado muchas de las personas que hoy integran el Banco, y siempre le ha gustado por la seriedad como se han comportado.
 
Ella esta casada y tiene tres hijos todos son mayores de edad, pero dos de ellos aun viven en su casa. Su marido se dedica a labores del campo.

Tiene una pequeña tienda de víveres de consumo, en la cual vende además de productos de primera necesidad algunas medicinas y tarjetas telefónicas. Trabaja todos los días desde las 6am hasta las 20h00, compra sus productos en Calceta y otros se los entregan en el local. Además prepara bolos (helados en funda)  de frutas que se venden como pan caliente dice ella.

Con este crédito quiere comprar unas vitrinas para poner sus productos.

Su sueño es tener una gran tienda en el centro de Calceta.
texts.en:
In the Quiroga parrish in the city of Calceta, an area where the people are dedicated, in large part, to farming, raising animals and selling their products, the Quiroga Community Bank meets every 15 days.

Nancy is a founding member of the community bank and she says this with pride since thanks to this she has halped many of the people who today are members of the bank and she has always liked the seriousness with which they conduct themselves.

She is married and has three children who are adults. But two of them still live at home. Her husband is dedicated to farming work.

She has a small grocery store in which she sells basic necessities, medicines and phone cards. She works everyday from 6AM until 8PM. She buys her products in Calceta and others are delivered to her store. Additionally, she prepares "bolos" (ice cream) made of fruit that she says sell like hot cakes.

With this loan, she wants to buy a glass case in which to display her products.

Her dream is to have a big shop in the center of Calceta.

loans.use: Purchase a glass case.

loans.name: Emelia

texts.en:
Emelia M. is from the village of Solinog Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 38 years old. Emelia is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Emelia owns and operates a retail store selling daily use products such as pancit, sardines, noodles, eggs, biscuits, candies, milk, shampoo, soap and toothpaste. Emelia has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Emelia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Emelia is requesting a loan of 7000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken by Emelia from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Samrith's Group

texts.en: Four members who live in Smaong village in Takeo province make up this group loan. They selected Mrs. Samrith C., 39 years old, to become the group leader. They will use their portion of the loan for different purposes, which can improve their family living. Mrs. Samrith C. is a wedding beautician who goes door-to-door, while her husband, Mr. Sea Ses, is a farmer who owns a one-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support his family. He is also a photographer. She has some problems because her husband’s field has infertile soil. So, to improve production, Mrs. Samrith C. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer. With the rest of the loan, she will hire a plow machine to plow the rice field and hire a farming laborer. She is a mother of three children who are attending school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Jenny Marisol

texts.es:
En la parroquia Quiroga de la  ciudad de Calceta, localidad donde la gente se dedica en gran parte a la agricultura, cría de animales  y a la venta de sus productos, se reúne cada quince días  El Banco Comunal Quiroga.

La señora Jenny  esta casada y tiene dos hijos, su esposo se dedica a labores del campo sus hijos aun se encuentran en el colegio. Lleva varios años en el Banco Comunal dice que está casi desde sus inicios y que siempre le ha gustado por sus pagos que son muy cómodos y los intereses bajos en relación a otros lugares de crédito.

Se dedica a la venta de ropa de todo tipo, su forma de venta es puerta a puerta y dice que le ha ido muy bien ya que son varios años que se encuentra en este negocio, los productos que mas vende son interiores, y pantalones  de damas, pero que también vende bastantes ropas de niños. Trabaja todas las tardes de lunes a sábados, día que se encarga de ir a cobrar ya que deja a crédito. Su mercadería la compra en Quito y Guayaquil porque allá hay mas variedad.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en comprar mas mercadería en especial ropa interior y pantalones ya que tiene varios encargos.
 
Sus sueños son llegar a tener una gran boutique
texts.en:
The Quiroga communal bank meets every 15 days in the Quiroga parish, located in the city of Calceta, a place where the many people work in farming, raising animals, and selling their products.

Jenny is married and has two children. Her husband works in the fields and her children are still in school. She has been with the communal bank for several years, almost since it began, and says that she has always liked the loans because they are very convenient and have low interest rates in comparison with other loan institutions.

She works selling all types of clothing from door to door. She says that it has always gone well for her and that she has been in the business for several years. The products that she sells most are underwear and women’s pants, but she also sells a lot of children’s clothing. She works in the afternoons Monday through Saturday, when she goes to collect what she left on credit. She buys her merchandise in Quito and in Guayaquil because there is much more variety there.

She will use this loan to purchase more merchandise, specifically underwear and pants since she has several orders.

Her dream is to eventually have a large boutique.

loans.use: To purchase women's pants and underwear.

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
This is Nenita E., a 52-year-old resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Julio E. and the mother to four young adults. By the grace of God, Nenita has managed to support her children's schooling up to the college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Nenita operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 pesos worth of cooking oil or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling at a piece rate. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 350 Philippine pesos (Php) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Nenita dreams to be able to renovate her house soon with all of her work with the business. She faithfully meets up with her fellowship* co-members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Khiev

texts.en: Mrs. Khiev S. is a married woman who lives in Smaong village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Tha Ouch, is a duck breeder who earns some money from selling ducks eggs to support his family. Her problem is that her family does not have a motorcycle to support business transportation. So, to improve this condition, Mrs. Khiev S. is asking for a loan to buy a motorcycle. She is a mother of five children, one of whom is a cloth seller, another one is helping in the father’s duck breeding, two are students, and the youngest one is five years old.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Yoem

texts.en: Mrs. Yoem K. Y. lives in Smaong village in Takeo province. She was born in 1973. She and her husband, Mr. Mos Nob, are farmers who own a 2-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support their family. Mr. Mos Nob is also a gecko middleman. (Khmer people use grilled gecko to make traditional medicine.) Although they both work hard, they earn little money to support the family. So, to improve her family living, Mrs. Yoem K. Y. is seeking a loan to buy ten piglets and pig food for breeding to start a new business. With the rest of the loan she plans to buy fertilizer. She is a mother of three children, one of whom is a seamstress in garment factory, while the others are students.

loans.use: To buy ten piglets and pig food for breeding to start a new business

loans.name: Eng

texts.en: Eng S., 41, has been selling food and coffee to people who live in her village. She owns a small restaurant where she operates her business. Eng S. is married and devoted to a young child who is going to the public school. She has another financial earner in her husband who is an internal staff member in the publishing industry. Eng S. is concerned that her restaurant is currently getting old and is not attractive to her customers. She wants to decorate/repair it. By doing this, she will get a comfortable place, which will encourage many customers come to her shop. Because she doesn’t have money to make that possible, Eng S. decided to seek a loan from Kiva’s project partner HKL.

loans.use: To decorate/repair her restaurant.

loans.name: Phuong

texts.en: Mrs. Phuong S. is a villager in Si Sla village in Takeo province. She was born in 1980. She and her husband, Mr. Kosorl Ros, are farmers who own a 2.5-hectare plot of land that they use to cultivate rice to sell in order to support their family. Mr. Ros also is a duck breeder who earns money from selling duck eggs. Since her husband’s duck breeding job is going well, she wants to help him expand it. So, Mrs. Phuong S. is asking for a loan to buy sixty more ducks. With the rest of the loan money, she will buy fertilizer and pesticides, and will hire workers for her farm. She is a mother of two children, one who is studying in school, and the other who is three years old. Mrs. Phuong S. and her husband are featured in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase sixty more ducks

loans.name: Abraham

texts.en:
Abraham O. is from the town of Banga. He is 47 years old. Abraham is married and has three children aged 19, 17 and 11. To make a living, Abraham owns & operates a business planting and harvesting rice and corn for sale. Abraham has been engaged in farming for over 10 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities. He also wants to raise pigs for fattening.

Abraham joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Abraham has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Abraham is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers and two piglets. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and two piglets

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
Nasreen lives in a small city located in the Punjab province of Pakistan called Borewala, which is famous for its shrines. She lives in the area of 447-EB with her family.

She is a working woman who makes and sells chingairs (a kind of tray to keep bread in it). She makes the chingairs with thick rope and sells it in neighboring areas and in the markets as well. She learned this skill from her mother and now she is taking advantage of it by running her own business. She does this work to share the financial burden with her husband.

She is married to M. A. who runs his own medicine shop in the market where he sells medicine to his customers. He has been running the shop for the past five years. He also supplies medicines to the medical clinics and earns a good profit on it.

Nasreen has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy medicines in bulk and increase his sales. 

She is hopeful that her husband will be able to expand his business and provide all kinds of medicines to his customers.

Note: In the photo, the lady who is raising her hand is Nasreen.

loans.use: To buy medicines in bulk to resell

loans.name: Nuon

texts.en: Mrs. Nuon L. is a 47-year-old widow living in Srae Boeng village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 5.2-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. Her problem is that her field has poor soil. So to improve production, Mrs. Nuon L. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer and rice seed. With the rest of the loan she will hire farm laborers. She supports two children, one of whom is attending school, while the other is employed in a private company.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and rice seed

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina A. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Tagasa, Bitoon, Daan Bantayan, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a general store.  Her husband Manuel A., who is 47 years old, works as a Roving Guard to earn his living. They have five children who are 3 to 15 years old. Gina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Gina has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 3,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 11,000, which she intends to use to purchase more stock to sell so she can continue to save for her business and her children's education. Gina A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at Kiva.org.


"

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana D. is from the town of Banga. She is 59 years old and widowed. To make a living, Juliana plants and harvests rice for sale. Juliana has been engaged in her business for more than 35 years.

Juliana joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juliana has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP to be used to purchase sacks of fertilizer, seeds and other inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, seeds and other inputs

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda A. is a resident of GMA, Cavite City, Philippines. A widow at 63 and blessed with an entrepreneurial mindset, Rosalinda spends her time looking after her  flourishing businesses.

Rosalinda operates a food stall where she sells fruit, cooked food and rice. In the evening, she sells balut (fertilized duck egg), which is a local delicacy. In the Philippines, workers and most families only eat home-cooked meals during evenings where all family members are at home. This is not only a usual family tradition but a matter of convenience and frugal living. It is considered a waste of money and time to spend cooking gas and food for one or two persons when buying cooked rice and food costs less. 

Rosalinda's regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php200 in sales every day. To help continue operating her business, she is requesting a Php 8,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more meat, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings. She will also invest a portion of the loan to buy more quantities of balut, which must be replenished each day. She expects a boost in her  income as she expands her business. 
 
Rosalinda dreams of having a simple life. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy more raw ingredients

loans.name: Glenis

texts.en:
In 2006 Glenis I. joined Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI) – a microfinance institution in the Philippines and a KIVA partner. A 41-year-old married mother of two, her eldest is a 17-year-old third year college student and the youngest is a 14-year-old third year high school student. Their primary source of income is her retail store which she established with her loans from ASHI. Her profit from this business helps meet many of their financial needs, especially the school expenses of their children. She is able to supplement her husband’s meager income in providing for their daily needs.

As a member of ASHI and KIVA, Glenis performs her duties and responsibilities with excellence and commitment, the real reason she has been tagged as a model member of the institution. She is now applying for another loan of Php 45,000.00 pesos to buy additional stocks of grocery products, canned goods, sacks of rice and sugar, cases of soft drinks or beverages and packs of cigarettes to accommodate the demands of her customers. More importantly, she wants to earn more so that she can achieve her dreams of having her own grocery stall and continuing to support the studies of her children until they finish college and earn a degree. Glenis believes that with the blessing of God and the support of the people from ASHI and KIVA, she will soon reach her dreams.

loans.use: To buy additional grocery products, sacks of rice and sugar, cases of beverages, packs of cigarettes

loans.name: Tarcela

texts.en:
Tarcela T. is a devoted mother to her only child, Rodolfo Jr. She is married to her loving spouse, Rodolfo T. Sr., a farmer. They live in the beautiful province of Pandan, Antique. She and her husband are engaged in a farming business and also operate hog fattening business. Despite many challenges in their life, they never gave up fighting against poverty.

Tarcela plans to utilize this loan of PHP25,000 to expand her hog fattening business as their primary source of daily income. This loan will be used to pay for more fattening to raise and feed hogs.

During her 6 years at ASHI, she has shown very good performance as a member, and she is being trusted by ASHI for her solid record. Aside from maintaining an excellent performance in repayment, business, and attendance in ASHI, Tarcela has also cared for the needs of her son at home and in school.

This loan will enable her to finally reach her dreams in life: to have a full-fledged pig farm business, a good life, and a happy family as well. She believes that her business will help her family to rise up and fight against poverty, as well as provide for the educational needs of her son until he completes college. She is very grateful to ASHI and KIVA for the continuous love and support of her dreams.

loans.use: To pay for fattening to raise and feed hogs.

loans.name: Vaen

texts.en: Mrs. Vaen M. is a grocery and soup seller in Prey Melong Khang Tboung village in Takeo province. She was born in 1983 and is a widow with three children: two attend school while the small one is only five years old. She is able to earn a large profit to support her family. Since her business is going well from time-to-time, she would like to expand. Mrs. Vaen M. is seeking a loan to buy more groceries. With the rest of the loan, she will buy more beef to make soup to sell.

loans.use: To buy more groceries

loans.name: Chab

texts.en:
Mrs. Chab K. married Mr. Sovanna Em and they live in Srae Boeng village in Takeo province. She is the mother of two children, who are farmers. She is a soup and congee (rice porridge) seller who earns a large profit to support her family. Her husband is a farmer who owns a 3.5 hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell. He is also a duck breeder who makes a small income to support his family. Her husband is shown in the photo with her. 

Mrs. Chab K.'s problem is that her husband’s field has infertile soil. So, to improve production, she is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer. With the rest of the loan, she will rent a machine to plow the rice field and farm laborers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Patrocenio

texts.en:
Patrocenio P. is from the village of Mialen Clarin, Misamis Occidental. He is 30 years old. Patrocenio is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Patrocenio owns and operates a tricycle transport service. Patrocenio has been engaged in his business for more than five years and earns approximately 15000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Patrocenio joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his business and living situation. Patrocenio has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12000 PHP from GDMPC. He is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP, which will be used to repair his vehicle for better service. This will be the seventh loan taken by Patrocenio from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his family's living conditions. 

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To repair existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Merie Ann

texts.en:
Merie Ann D., from the city of Bañadero Ozamiz City, is 28 years old and single. To make a living, Merie Ann owns and operates a business venture in the services sector offering transportation services. Engaged in her business for over three years, she earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Merie Ann joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan from GDMPC, she is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP to repair an existing vehicle for better service. This will be Merie Ann's ninth loan from GDMPC, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Nagina's Group

texts.en:
Nagina is a house wife living in a city called Borewala, which is known for its shrines, in Pakistan. She owns a small house of two rooms and lives in it with her family. She prefers to stay at home by managing the household chores and taking care of her family. 

Her husband's name is S. M.. He is a painter by trade and paints walls, doors and windows. People hire him by making a phone call and he gets his income after completing the work. He also has contracts with different construction companies and works for them by painting their buildings to earn an income for his family. His business is going well but he wants to buy a variety of colors of paints to start a painted boxes sales business as well. In this way, he will earn a good profit when he doesn’t receive any painting orders from his customers. 

Therefore, Nagina has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah for this purpose. With the loan amount her husband will buy the paint boxes of different colors and increase the income by selling them. Nagina is very supportive in nature and always willing to help her family in making their life easier. She is hopeful that her husband will get good profits by starting his paint selling business after making this investment. 

Note: “In the picture, the lady who is raising her hand is Nagina”.

loans.use: To buy paint boxes for paint business.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma P., from the village of Militar, Tukuran Zamboanga Del Sur, is 46 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Emma owns and operates a specialized retail store selling daily use products such as sugar, sardines, pancit canton, noodles,shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Engaged in her business for over three years, she earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month.

In 2009, Emma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from GDMPC that was used to purchase additional products to sell, she is now requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP to invest in expanding the business. This will be Emma's fourth loan from GDMPC, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet Y. is from the town of Banga. She is 41 years old and married. She has 8 children, the eldest is aged 19 and the youngest, 6 years old. To make a living, Janet owns & operates a business raising crops, primarily planting and harvesting rice, for sale. Janet has been engaged in farming for over 19 years. She and her husband work hard to provide for their family. She also hopes to have another source of income for the family.

Janet joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Janet has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
This is Merlinda D. V., 48, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Alexis D. V. and mother to five young adults: two of whom are already working, while two are enrolled in school. The youngest child is still in high school. By the grace of God, Merlinda has managed to support her older children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to send her youngest to college. A dream for most Filipino parents like Merlinda, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance a parent could give to their children.

Merlinda operates a buy and sell business. What she basically does is buy general merchandise from wholesalers and sell them, piecemeal, with a little profit. Products can range from furniture to household appliances, electronic devices, clothing, beauty products, food supplements and other products of the like.
