Customers are attracted to buy, due to the low selling prices and the many options they are offered. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP8,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Merlinda dreams to improve her present life. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, to build social capital, and to pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities and varieties of products, to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena R. is from the village of San Francisco, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 39 years old. Rowena is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Rowena owns & operates a general store, primarily selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Rowena is just starting this business.

In 2008, Rowena joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Rowena has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Rowena is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Rowena from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Estrelita

texts.en: "With hard work nothing is impossible". Estrelita G. is from Barangay Buliwao, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 46 years old and is married with four school-aged children. Estrelita owns and operates a general store, selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over eleven years and earns approximately 5,200 PHP a month. In 2006, Estrelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Estrelita is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her 7th from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Jonard

texts.en:
Jonard M., from the village of D'ban Calamba Mismais Occidental, is 36 years old, married, and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Jonard owns and operates a service-based business providing repair services to local community members. Engaged in his business for over six years, he earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Jonard joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid his previous loan of 17000 PHP from GDMPC that was used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided, he is now requesting his fourth loan of 17000 PHP to purchase materials needed to provide service. Jonard plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Arlyn

texts.en:
This is Arlyn G., 30, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Reymond G. and is the mother of three young, hardworking adults. By the grace of God, she has managed to support her children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Arlyn operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, five pesos-worth of cooking oil, or an egg.

Arlyn earns by buying supplies at the wholesale price and selling in small quantities. Her store is located adjacent to her house and her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, Arlyn is requesting a Php 10,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Arlyn dreams of being able to renovate her house soon, with all of her work in her business. She faithfully meets up every week with her fellowship* co-members to share stories of her work.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Matahum

texts.en:
Matahum C., from the village of Langub Calamba Misamis Occidental, is 46 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Matahum owns and operates a specialized retail store selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, powder, soap, sugar, salt, and biscuits in the local community. Engaged in her business for over 10 years, she earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Matahum joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from GDMPC that was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital, she is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP, her fourth, to purchase additional products to sell. Matahum plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Shamim's Group

texts.en:
Shamim lives in the city of Borewala, Pakistan, famous for its shrines. She owns a small house of two rooms and lives in it with her family.

A talented lady, Shamim owns and operates her embroidery business at home. She collects orders from nearby areas and completes them on time to earn an income for her family. She started this business five years ago by making embroidered clothes for her relatives but now she receives good orders from nearby areas as well and has become an earner for her family.

Shamim’s husband drives a rented rickshaw, providing transport facilities to his passengers. He works hard to put three meals a day on the table for his family. At the end of the day, the owner of the rickshaw gets half the earned amount and the remaining amount doesn’t allow Shamim’s husband to meet the family’s financial expenses.

Therefore, Shamim has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy his own rickshaw and this will help him to increase his income and cut out his rental cost.

Shamim is hopeful that this will result in an increased income for her family so that they will be able to enjoy better facilities in life and she will be able to give a good future to her children as well.

In the photo, Shamim is the lady who is raising her hand.

loans.use: To buy a rickshaw for her husband's business

loans.name: Herminio

texts.en:
Herminio Y. is from the town of Banga. He is 46 years old and is married with six children, the eldest being aged 21 and the youngest 5.

Herminio owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. He says he wants his family to be happy and healthy always.

Herminio joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI.

Herminio is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay his children’s tuition fees and improve his business.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Estrelita

texts.en: Estrelita A. is from the village of Bannagao. She is 59 years old and is married with seven adult children. Estrelita owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. Estrelita is very positive that her business will continuously progress. In 2006, Estrelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Estrelita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 9th from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Antonia

texts.en:
Antonia O. is from the village of Tru-cut Sapang Dalaga Misamis Occidental. She is 56 years old. Antonia is married and has 3 adult-age children. To make a living, Antonia owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling fruits  like banana and marang, a local fruit similar to a breadfruit, in the local community. (You can see marangs on the shelf in the photograph).  Antonia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Antonia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Antonia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & for working capital. Antonia is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Antonia from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda D. is from the village of San Francisco, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 36 years old. Imelda is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Imelda owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Imelda has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Imelda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Imelda has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Imelda is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase young livestock to raise & sell in future. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Imelda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase young livestock to raise & sell in the future

loans.name: Nazia's Group

texts.en:
Nazia lives in a city called Borewala which is famous for its shrines in Pakistan. She lives in the area of 447-EB with her family. Her house consists of 2 rooms. 

A very caring lady, Nazia stays at home, manages the household chores and takes care of her family.  Her husband's name is S. M.. He  is painter by profession and paints walls and homes. He has a business place in the market where he advertises his services to people and other construction companies. 
 
People and construction companies make contracts with him and he meets their work on time to earn good income.
 
Nazia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan amount her husband will buy paint boxes of different colors for his painting business.  The paint boxes will enable him to finish the painting work on time and build up his regular customer base. 

Nazia is hopeful that this investment will prove beneficial for her husband’s business and he will be able to grow his business on a larger scale by increasing his clientele base. 

Note: “In the picture, the lady who is raising her hand is Nazia”.

loans.use: To buy paint boxes for painting business

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia A. is from the village of Bannagao. She is 55 years old. Delia is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Delia owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Delia has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Delia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Delia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand product offering. Delia is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 9th loan taken out by Delia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees for her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rumbo Al Exito Group

texts.es:
Cuando Rosa formo su familia  pensó en hacer algo para ayudar a su esposo, anteriormente hiso varios trabajos  pero por dedicarse a su hijita  quería hacer algo en su misma casa, cuando su  esposo recibió un dinero producto de las utilidades de su trabajo ambos pensaron en utilizar ese dinero para invertirlo en algún negocio  así deciden poner una bodega lo hicieron con muy pocas cosas pero con muchas ganas de trabajar ahora ya tienen  cerca de 3 años con el negocio  aun cuando hay varias bodegas cerca de la suya han logrado tener muchos clientes que siempre acuden a su negocio para realizar sus compras, Rosa vende productos de pan llevar como arroz, azúcar, fideos, bebidas etc. Su negocio ha prosperado mucho  ahora tiene mas cosas para ofrecer a su clientela y lo que le ha sido de gran ayuda han sido sus prestamos de EDAPROSPO esto le sirve para seguir comprando mas productos para tener variedad.
 sus ganancias le han ayudado para tener algunas comodidades dentro de su hogar, mas adelante quiere lograr tener una tienda mas amplia y grande para convertirla en un minimarket ,actualmente ella es la secretaria del grupo “RUMBO AL ÉXITO”  formado por 8 socias vecinas de ventanilla.

*Rosa es la 4ta de las paradas esta con polo celeste.
texts.en:
When Rosa started her family she thought of doing something to help her husband. She previously worked in different jobs but she wanted to do something from her own home to be able to dedicate herself to her daughter. When her husband received money from his work, they both thought of using it to invest in a business, so they decided to set up a grocery store. They started with a few items but they had a lot of desire to work and they have now had the business for almost three years. Although there are several grocery stores nearby, they have been able to attract many customers that always come to their store to do their shopping. Rosa sells basic items such as rice, sugar, pasta, drinks, etc. Her business has done very well and she now has more items to offer to her customers. What have been of great help are the loans from EDAPROSPO, which help her to continue purchasing more products to have variety.

Her earnings have helped her to obtain some comforts in her home. In the future, she wants to have a larger store and convert it into a mini-market. She is currently the secretary of the ‘Rumbo al éxito’ communal bank, which consists of eight members who are neighbors. * Rosa is the fourth one from the left with the blue top.

loans.use: To purchase products for her grocery store.

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma G. a hardworking 41 year old mother who hopes to send all her 8 children to school for a better education. As a mother, she understand that the only way she can improve the quality of life of her children is by sending them to school to earn a degree. She believes that education is the only treasure that her children can inherit from her. That is why she joined Ahon sa HIrap, inc., a microfinance institution and partner of KIVA here in the Philippines. She believes that with access to capital she can improve her business and earn more for the school expenses of her children.
  
In the years of her membership she has performed well as a member and as a mother in order to benefit all the program of the institution. Today she is applying for another loan of Php 20,000.00 pesos to buy raw materials such as textile and rags for the production of their pot handlesr, place-mats, and doormat weaving business. The business is run by the couple and with the help of their children during their free time and weekends. The demand of these products is high because of durability and the product quality which the couple maintain. 

Her hope for the business is to increase the production. She also prays that she can profit more so that they can keep up the schooling of their children and daily needs. She is confident that GOD sent people from ASHI and KIVA to help and support her dreams for her family.

loans.use: To buy raw materials such as textile and rags to use for weaving pot handlers, doormats and placemats

loans.name: Roath

texts.en:
Mrs. Roath T. lives in Roluos village in Takeo province. She was born in 1959. She and her husband, Mr. Man Chhouk, are farmers who own a 4 hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support their family. She is also a Khmer cake maker. She is the mother of three children:  one is a laborer in Thailand, one owns a threshing machine and the other one is a student. Her husband is in the picture with her. 

Mrs. Roath T. has a problem because it is time to grow rice but she does not have money to support her field. So, to improve production, Mrs. Roath T. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer, rice seed and pesticide. With the rest of the loan, she will rent a machine to plow her field.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, rice seed and pesticide

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida D. is from the village of San Francisco, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 52 years old. Zenaida is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Zenaida owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Zenaida has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 2500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Zenaida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Zenaida has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Zenaida is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Zenaida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Leonita

texts.en:
Leonita G. is a 63 year-old widowed woman from Libertad, Antique. She is blessed to have two children.  A member of the San Roque center of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI) Antique North West Branch, Leonita is a very industrious woman determined to achieve a better life.  Despite hardships caused by poverty, Leonita remains strong and dedicated in her pursuit to improve her family’s standard of living. The love and support of her children makes her life quite meaningful.

To earn a living, Leonita raises hogs as a  business. She has been engaged in this business for almost six years. She joined ASHI, a microfinance institution and Kiva partner in the Philippines, in 2004. During the course of her membership, she has been an excellent performer with respect to regular attendance at meetings, loan repayment, and projects. She is now seeking her sixth loan for the amount of 25,000 PHP to purchase additional inventory of hogs to raise.

With access to additional working capital through ASHI and Kiva, Leonita is hopeful her dreams of giving her children a better future will be achieved and to have an expanded pig farm business someday. Leonita’s desire to offer her children a brighter future fuels her dedication to her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory of hogs to raise.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Chhung

texts.en: Mrs. Chhung M. is a married woman living in Rung village in Takeo province. She and her husband are farmers who own a 1.5-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support their family. She is a farming laborer while her husband is a fisherman. Her problem is that her rice field has infertile soil. So, to improve production, Mrs. Chhung M. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer, rice seed, and pesticide. With the rest of the loan, she will hire a plow machine to plow her own field. She is a mother of two children who are students. Her husband is shown in picture with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, rice seed, and pesticide

loans.name: Bisoboka Women's Group-Lugazi

texts.en: Jane N. is 45 years old and the single mother of 5 children. She belongs to the Bisoboka Women’s Group in Lugazi. For the last 15 years, she has been running a drug store/pharmacy business in the up-and-coming active trading center of Kizigo. Jane went through apprentice training as a nurse before deciding to start her business. In the beginning, she went door-to-door selling medications in her neighborhood. Jane describes herself as a hard worker with a purpose who makes monthly profits of up to 60,000 shillings. She is requesting a loan to purchase more drugs for her pharmacy.

loans.use: To purchase drugs for her pharmacy

loans.name: Vanna

texts.en: Mrs. Vanna N. got married to Mr. Savorn Vat and they live in Kab Nuem village in Takeo province. She was born in 1986. She and her husband are farmers who own a 1-hectare plot of land where they can grow rice to sell to support their family. She is also a wedding beautician and her husband is a taxi driver. This couple tries to work a lot but they only earn a little money. So, to improve her family living, Mrs. Vanna N. is applying for a loan to buy a cow for breeding to start a new business. She is a mother of two children who are too young to work or study. Her husband is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding to start a new business

loans.name: Willy

texts.en: Willy M., 28, has been at the helm of his clothes-selling business in Mpigi Town for three years. In a week this business, which he started with savings from his earlier poultry business, generates 100,000 shillings for him. Willy, who is the father of two children, says he began this business with advice from a close acquaintance. He says this loan will come in handy in helping him purchase more bales of clothes for resale.

loans.use: To purchase bales of clothes for resale

loans.name: Ghokale Group-Jinja

texts.en: Monica W., 43, has an easy-going demeanor that has been of paramount importance in helping her strike a chord with clients. Monica, who belongs to Ghokale Group-Jinja principally sells goats and cattle in Lvunamba. This happily married mother of six has been doing this for the last six years. Before that, she was more involved in a grocery business. Though she still operates it, the grocery now plays second fiddle to her more lucrative goat and cattle sales businesses. In a week, she makes 100000 shillings. With this loan, she reckons she will be able to buy more goats and cattle for resale and increase her business profits.

loans.use: To purchase cattle and goats for resale

loans.name: Nila

texts.en:
Nila B. is from the village of Sepac, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is 52 years old. Nila is separated from her spouse and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Nila owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of revenue for the business comes from selling scrap metal, iron, bronze, bottles and other used products. Nila has been engaged in her business for more than six years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Nila joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Nila is requesting a loan of 10000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken by Nila from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Yung

texts.en: Mrs. Yung S. H. was born in 1978 and is a villager in Angk Svay Chek village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Lorng Dy Ya, are farmers who own a one-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support their family. She is also a knitter and her husband is a fisherman. Her problem is that her field is far away from an irrigation system. So, to improve production, Mrs. Yung S. H. is asking for a loan to buy a pump machine and fertilizer. With the rest of the loan, she will dig a well. She is a mother of a child who is four years old. Her husband is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy a pump machine and fertilizer

loans.name: Step By Step Women's Group-Mukono

texts.en:
Beat N.’s beauty salon in Kitega –Mukono has had mixed fortunes over the last decade. But the 40-year-old's own initiative and entrepreneurial versatility enabled her to begin this business, and all this while, she has given nothing but a credible account of her business abilities. The happily married mother of four credits a sense of diligence as one factor that has stood out for her as a stock in trade. In a month she makes 120,000 shillings, and with this loan she is planning to buy more hair products, weavers and other requisite beauty salon equipment.

Beat belongs to Step by Step Women's Group in Mukono.

loans.use: To purchase hair products, weavers and other salon equipment

loans.name: Nhaet

texts.en: Mrs. Nhaet T. is a villager in Chheu Teal Phluoh village in Takeo province and she is 37 years old. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice for her family. She is also a fish seller in the local market where she is able to earn a large profit to support her family. Since her business is going well from time-to-time, she wants to expand. So, to improve her own business, Mrs. Nhaet T. is seeking a loan to buy more fish to sell. She is a widow with two children who help in their mother’s businesses.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Kyagalanyi Masajja Development Group-Kampala

texts.en: Before he ventured into taxi-driving services on the advice of a close friend, 27-year-old Godfrey L. had an inclination for fishing. Godfrey belongs to Kyagalanyi–Masajja Development Group-Kampala. This happily married father of three also sells poultry. In a week he makes 50,000 shillings. What lies at the root of his success is hard work, although hard circumstances have tested his patience, nerve and persistence. With this loan, he wants to purchase more chickens for his poultry-sales business.

loans.use: To purchase chickens for a poultry business

loans.name: Ganna

texts.en:
Ganna is married. She is an entrepreneur from Korolyovo where she works in the local mall selling bed sheets, blankets, pillows, and other retail items. Ganna has been in this business for 10 years. Her venture has grown up to 50,000 Grivnyas in inventory and about 5,000 Grivnyas in monthly profit. 

Ganna is requesting a loan of 8,000 Grivnyas to diversify assorted merchandise she offers for sale in her outlet. This type of inventory is always in demand. People purchase the items for themselves as well as for gifts. Ganna is hoping to generate additional income to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase more inventory

loans.name: Abdusalom

texts.ru: Шарипов Абдусалом проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст, 42 года. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Абдусалом имеет высшее не оконченное образование. Сейчас он занимается торговлей. У него имеется магазин, где он продает продукты питания. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 4 года. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en:
Abdusalom S. lives in the city of Kulob. He is 42 years old, married and has 3 children. His wife is a homemaker. Abdusalom has an incomplete higher education. Currently, he is involved in retail sales. He has a store, where he sells food products. Abdusalom has been involved in this business for 4 years. He is requesting this loan in order to increase product turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing product turnover

loans.name: Nyakaina Central. Rukungiri Group

texts.en: M. Enos, 80 years old, is a member of the Nyakaina Central group. He lives in Nyakaina, Rukungiri.  He is a retired teacher who has operated an agricultural farm for over 50 years. He raises cattle and sells milk as his main sources of livelihood alongside cattle fattening and banana sales. He is a married father of seven children and is hard-working.  He looks forward to improving his standard of living as a model farmer in the area.  M. is seeking a loan to help him purchase more cattle and restock his farm, in order to be able to earn more sales revenue out of his milk sales. With the increased revenue, he will be able to cater to his family's needs and educate his children.

loans.use: To purchase cattle for his farm

loans.name: Los Amigos Responsables Group

texts.es:
La alcancía comunal “LOS AMIGOS RESPONSABLES” se encuentra ubicada en la Libertad, distrito de Comas, departamento de Lima, está conformado por 9 socios, trabajan con EDAPROSPO – prosperidad desde hace 5 meses. Sus miembros realizan diversas actividades de producción, comercio y servicio.
María quien a su vez asume el cargo de tesorera, tiene 44 años, es casada, trabaja realizando encuestas en esta campaña política en la empresa (DATUM), además en esta temporada aprovechara para vender turrones. El reciente préstamo lo utilizará en la compra de mercadería (turrones) por esta campaña.  
Todos nuestros socios agradecen el apoyo brindado y están comprometidos a cumplir con los pagos según el cronograma otorgado por prosperidad.
texts.en:
The Los Amigos Responsables communal bank is located in La Libertad in the district of Comas and the department of Lima. It consists of nine members who have been working with EDAPROSPO – PROSPERIDAD for the past five months. The group members have different businesses in production, sales and services.

María, who has assumed the position of group treasurer, is 44 years old and married. She is working taking surveys during the current political campaign with the company DATUM. In addition, she will also take advantage of the campaign season to sell turrones (a nougat candy). She will use this loan for the purchase of merchandise (turrones).

All of the borrowers are grateful for the support provided and promise to make their loan repayments according to the timeline granted by PROSPERIDAD.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise (turrones, a nougat candy) for the campaign season.

loans.name: Crispina

texts.en:
Crispina E. is an active entrepreneur managing a sari-sari (variety) store business. Her previous loan from ASHI has provided working capital to expand her business and purchase more inventory for her store. With the loan, Crispina has witnessed that her monthly income has almost doubled since she has attracted more customers with additional stock.

Prior to ASHI, Crispina had no access to capital to support her entrepreneurial dreams. Positive growth from her business has helped Crispina finance the education of her four children. Since joining ASHI, Crispina has experienced positive changes in her life and uses the additional income to support daily expenditures of their family. Crispina hopes her business will continue to flourish so she can provide long-term financial stability for her family. 

Therefore, she is now requesting a KIVA loan, this time for 14,000 PHP, to purchase more inventory of food products for her store. This will allow her to grow her business further so that her children can fulfill his dreams of completing a college degree and experience a life that’s full of satisfaction.

With the support of ASHI and Kiva lenders, Crispina is hopeful that her business endeavor will provide steady income and improvements in her family’s quality of life that is currently far below the umbrella of poverty. Crispina’s hopes that her business will expand for them so they will have savings for future use.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory of food products of her store.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is divorced. She runs a small business selling plumbing, cutting, welding and other supplies at the central market in Beregovo town. Elizabeth started this business 4 years ago. She learned fast that a large variety and small prices are key factors in her business. This business is the only source of income for Elizabeth.

Elizabeth is requesting a loan of 10,000 Grivnas to purchase assorted inventories. She would spend additional income to improve her living conditions. Elizabeth lives with her son in a small apartment.

loans.use: to purchase inventory

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria C. is 54 years old and has four children. She has been a widow for almost seven years. Since her husband’s death, she shoulders all the responsibility for taking care of her children and sending them to school. In 2004 she became a member of Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI) – a partner microfinance institution of Kiva in the Philippines. From then on ASHI became her partner in providing for her family's daily needs and improving their lives. Today all of her children have college degrees and their own jobs. The family's primary source of income is selling fish, a business that Victoria started from her loan with ASHI.  

She is applying for another loan of PHP 20,000 for additional capital to buy fish from small fishermen in the community. She sells these fish in nearby municipal markets and cities. She wants to improve her business to make it more stable. By doing this, she knows that she can create jobs and help the fishermen she buys from to improve their own standards of living. She is thankful that ASHI and Kiva give her the opportunity to have access to capital and to improve her family's quality of life. She hopes that the two institutions will support her in her dream of providing employment within her community, especially to out-of-school youth.

Please ignore the date on the picture. It was not set on the camera to reflect the actual date when the picture was taken. This is the most recent picture of Victoria.

loans.use: To buy fish for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay his children's education expenses

loans.name: Hanifaan Nazar Ali's Group

texts.en:
Hanifaan lives in a small city called Borewala which is famous in Pakistan for its shrines. She owns a small house of two rooms in an area named Habib colony and lives in it with her family. She is a caring lady and prefers to spend her time at home managing the household chores and taking care of her family.

Her husband's name is N. A. and he is a private entrepreneur who deals in a leather-selling business. He supplies the leather to the factories to make a living for his family. He is very responsible by nature. By being the only breadwinner, he works hard for his family so they never face any difficulty with the basic necessities of life. 

Through serving his customers for 10 years, he is given respect by them and they appreciate him for his hard work. By the grace of God, he has obtained larger orders from his customers and for timely fulfillment of these orders he needs to take out a loan. Therefore, Hanifaan has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah. With the loan amount, her husband will buy leather to fill his orders on time.

Hanifaan is confident that by using the loan amount her husband will be able to fill the larger orders on time thus enabling him to earn a good income for his family.

Note: In the photo, the lady who is raising her hand is Hanifaan.

loans.use: To buy leather to fill larger orders on time

loans.name: Tusooka Kwavula Women's Group 1-Lugazi

texts.en:
Due to her unwavering steadfastness 42-year-old T. Jannet has not compromised her business values, even in the face of provocation, threats, competition and, above all, challenging business conditions. This has been the hallmark that has set her drug store or pharmacy business in Lugazi town apart from others in the last 13 years. Her customers range from the lowly to the middle class and live in her area of operation and even from beyond.
Jannet belongs to Tusooka Kwavula Women's Group. It has helped her to have a supportive family and the first person on hand for her has been her husband. This kind of business, which involves selling and prescribing drugs, is tailor made for somebody who has gained an apprentice nurse training and Jannet is a qualified nurse. She worked first in a health center. Jannet says that credit for her success so far boils down to her hard work and tenacity. In a month, she makes 430,000 UGX, and with this loan she hopes to buy more drugs that she will, at length, resell.

loans.use: To purchase more drugs for resale

loans.name: Paz Y Desarrollo Group

texts.es:
La alcancía comunal “PAZ Y DEZARROLLO”, está conformada por 14 socios quienes se desempeñan en labores D. comercio minorista e informal, trabajan con EDAPROSPO- Prosperidad desD. hace 12 meses.
Ruth emprendedora y entusiasta, actualmente asume el cargo D. secretaria, tiene 30 años,  es casada y tiene 4 hijos.
DesD. hace 23 años se dedica a la venta D. helados, además apoya en el chifa D. su mama llamado “TOÑITO”, se inicio en este negocio porque anteriormente vivía en la casa D. su suegra vendiendo abarrotes, luego se mudo a la casa D. sus padres , cuando llego el verano logro ahorrar y con ese dinero puso el negocio D. los helados. Con el ingreso D. su negocio y el apoyo D. su esposo ha logrado comprar una herramienta para su esposo que necesita para su negocio como (martillo eléctrico, taladro).
Con el reciente préstamo, Ruth lo destinara en la compra D. helados para su negocio. Agradecen el financiamiento para sus actividades comerciales y seguirán cumpliendo con sus pagos puntualmente.
texts.en:
The Paz y Desarrollo (Peace and Development) communal bank is comprised of 14 members who work in informal and retail sales.  They have been working with EDAPROSPO – Prosperidad for the past 12 months.

Ruth is an enterprising and enthusiastic woman.  She currently works as a secretary and is 30 years old, married, and has four children.  For the past 23 years she has worked selling ice cream and also helps at her mother’s Chinese restaurant called Toñito.  She started in the business because she used to live in her mother-in-law’s house selling groceries.  She then moved to her parent’s house and when summer arrived, she was able to save and she used this money to establish the ice cream business.  With the income from her business and her husband’s support, she was able to buy a tool that her husband needs for his work (an electric hammer, a drill).  With the current loan, Ruth will invest in the purchase of ice creams for her business.  

They are grateful for the funding for their businesses and will continue to make their loan payments on time.

loans.use: To purchase ice creams

loans.name: Tusooka Kwavula Women's Group 2-Lugazi

texts.en: N. Jane, 49, belongs to Tusooka Kwavula Group 2-Lugazi. This single mother of four has, for the past decade, been in the decision-making hierarchy of her hotel and restaurant businesses in Lugazi town. Before she got established in this business, she was more involved in selling snacks. She also sells firewood and charcoal. She attributes her success, albeit with the many challenges she has inevitably faced, to hard work. In a month, she makes 1,000,000 UGX, and with this loan she wants to pay the refurbishment costs for her restaurant.

loans.use: To refurbish her restaurant

loans.name: Suhrob

texts.ru: Усмонов Сухроб проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст, 37 лет. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Сухроб имеет высшее образование. По профессии не работает. Сейчас он предоставляет услугу, такси. В этой области более 5 лет. Кредит берет для закупа автомашины. Клиент хочет продать свою машину и купить новую.
texts.en:
Suhrob U. lives in the city of Kulob. He is 37 years old, married and has 5 children. His wife is a homemaker. Suhrob has a higher education, but does not work in his field. Currently, he provides a taxi service. Suhrob has been in this field for over 5 years. He is requesting this loan for the purchase of a car. The client wants to sell his car and buy a new one.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a car

loans.name: Farida Khayath Group

texts.en:
Farida is one of the members of the Farida Khayath group. She lives in the 6th district of Kabul, Afghanistan. She has four other members in her family; her father is an old man, so she is responsible for earning money for her family. Farida is a tailor and she can sew different kinds of clothes. She needs a loan to purchase some sewing materials to progress her business. She is pleased that through this loan she will have a successful life in the 
future and she can solve all her family's problems.

loans.use: To purchase sewing materials

loans.name: Fatima Muhammad Yaseen's Group

texts.en:
Fatima is a resident of the city of Borewala which is famous in Pakistan for its shrines. She owns a two-room brick house in the area named Habib colony and lives in it with her family. She is a housewife and prefers to stay at home. By being a caring wife, she performs her responsibilities of a good mother as well. Her family respects and loves her a lot. 

Her husband's name is M. Y.. He is a butcher by trade and operates his own butcher's shop in the market where he deals specifically in chicken meat. He earns well on a daily basis but his business is greater on occasions. He has a good clientele base and serves them with good fresh meat. 

Fatima has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan amount, her husband will buy the chickens in larger quantity and increase his selling. 

Fatima remains worried about her children's future but she thinks that she will be able to provide them with better living facilities if her husband's business improves.

Note: In the photo, the lady who is raising her hand is Fatima.

loans.use: To buy large quantities of chickens for resale

loans.name: Naseem Manzoor Ahmad's Group

texts.en:
Naseem is a resident of the city called Borewala famous in Pakistan for its shrines. She is a vigorous lady. Through being a housewife, she handles her clothes selling business well. She gives the necessary time to her family and to her business. She started her clothes selling business four years ago to supplement her family's income. 

She buys clothes from the city of Faisalabad which is famous for its textile industry and sells the clothes to different clothes shops and in the community as well. She also gets orders from clothes shops due to her good collection of clothes and earns a good profit by completing them on time.

Her husband's name is M. A. and he is a carrier by trade. He uses a donkey cart for loading items such as construction supplies and fruits and vegetables delivering them to designated places. He has been doing this work for over five years.

Naseem has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan amount, her husband will buy a new donkey cart because his current cart is not in good condition making it difficult for him to put loads into it and he faces problems in doing his job properly.

She is hopeful that with the new cart her husband will be able to work better and earn more income.

Note: In the photo, the lady who is raising her hand is Naseem.

loans.use: To buy a new donkey cart for a carrier business

loans.name: Kosar Muhammad Awais' Group

texts.en:
Kosar is a resident of the city of Borewala famous in Pakistan for its shrines. She owns a small house of two rooms in the area of Haneef Park and lives in it with her family. 

She owns and operates a business selling clothes. She takes orders from people in her neighboring areas and provides them with a different variety of clothes to earn an income for her family. She buys clothes from the city of Faisalabad which is famous for its textile industry and where the cost of clothes is cheap.  

Her husband's name is M. A. and he is involved in the business of selling bangles. He has a small bangles shop in the market where he offers his customers colorful bangles of every kind such as steel, glass and embroidered. Bangles are a jewelry item which every women loves to wear on special occasions and in their routine life as well. 

Kosar has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan amount, he will buy bangles in bulk quantities which will help him to increase his sales.

By increasing her husband's income, Kosar is hopeful that her family will be able to live a better standard of life.

Note: In the photo, the lady who is raising her hand is Kosar.

loans.use: To buy bangles for reselling

loans.name: Umed

texts.ru: Холов Умед проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст, 27 лет. Женат, детей не имеет. Образование среднее. Клиент занимается торговлей на рынке "Саховат". У него собственная торговая точка, где он продает мужскую одежду и обувь. В этой области имеет богатый опыт. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en:
Umed H. lives in the city of Kulob. He is 27 years old, married and has no children. He has a secondary education. The client is involved in retail sales at the "Sahovat" market. Umed owns his retail outlet, where he sells men's clothing and shoes. He has a rich experience in this area. He is requesting this loan in order to increase goods turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing goods turnover

loans.name: Samuel Kivya

texts.en:
Samuel has operated his auto repair garage in Naivasha town since 2000.  He is 46 years old, married to Grace Nyiva and they have two children.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his second loan. He paid his first loan well and on time. He is planning to use this loan to buy a new toolbox with new tools for his garage.

loans.use: To buy a new toolbox and new tools for his garage

loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
Elma D. is from the village of Bolinao. She is 41 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Elma owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Elma has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Elma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Elma is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand the products offered. This will be the fifth loan that Elma has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand the products offered

loans.name: Joseph Njuguna

texts.en:
Joseph bought his motorbike last year which he has been using to transport people from one place to another.  He is 28 years old, married to Elizabeth Njambi and they have one child.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his second loan. He paid his first loan well and in good time. He plans to use the money to carry out repairs on his motorbike and also renew his PSV license.

Joseph hopes to own a minibus in future which he will use in the transport business.

loans.use: To repair his motorbike and renew his PSV license

loans.name: Legoyia Ketoi

texts.en:
Legoyia has been practicing livestock farming in Naivasha town for the last nine years. He is 26 years old, married to Masialle Legoyia and they have three children.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to use the cash to buy 10 calves which he will rear and sell later at a profit.

Legoyia is planning to buy a big piece of farmland where he will practice livestock farming on a large scale.

loans.use: To buy 10 calves to rear and resell

loans.name: Elizabeth Jepwambok

texts.en:
Elizabeth Jepwambok C., a hardworking 50-year-old lady, is married to Philip Bargoiyet C. and together they have four children aged 27, 25, 23 and 7 years respectively. She has been operating a general shop for about 15 years and earns a monthly income of Kshs 15,000.

Elizabeth learned about and joined KADET LTD a while back. Now applying for her sixth loan of Kshs. 30,000 from KADET LTD to buy a stock of nine bags of sugar, she plans to use the profits from the expanded business to start a second enterprise in dairy farming which is also very marketable in this area.

Elizabeth hopes to grow her business, become the leading local investor, and see her children realizing their dreams in life through education.

loans.use: To buy nine bags of sugar

loans.name: James Kariuki

texts.en: James has operated his retail shop selling basic household goods and clothes in Naivasha town for the last five years.  He is 39 years old, married to Eunice Musenya, and they have four children. James was introduced to KADET by his friend and, having repaid his previous loans, is now applying for his third one with which he will add clothes in his shop for resale. James is also hoping to own a wholesale shop in the future.

loans.use: To buy clothes for resale in his shop.

loans.name: Sharif

texts.ru: Салоев Шариф проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст, 50 лет. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Шариф имеет среднее образование. Занимается животноводством. Разводит скот у себя дома. Он в основном откармливает и продает скот. В этой области имеет богатый опыт. Кредит берет для закупа скота.
texts.en:
Sharif S. lives in the city of Kulob. He is 50 years old, married and has 5 children. His wife is a homemaker. Sharif has a secondary education. He is involved in animal husbandry. He breeds livestock at home and primarily fattens and sells livestock. Sharif has an extensive experience in this area. He is requesting this loan for the purchase of livestock.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Terisita

texts.en:
Terisita R., from the village of San Francisco, Cauayan City, is 35 years old, single, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Terisita owns and operates a general store selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Engaged in her business for over 10 years, she earns approximately 3500 PHP a month.

In 2009, Terisita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan from ASKI that was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital, she is now requesting her fourth loan of 8000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. Terisita plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her store.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Marivic A. is from the village of Bolinao. She is 48 years old. Marivic is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Marivic owns and operates a business venture in the agricultural sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. Marivic has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Marivic joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marivic has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizer, such as manure. Marivic is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Marivic from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Kurash Ole

texts.en:
Kurash has been rearing animals for sale in Naivasha town for the last three years.  He is 35 years old and married to Yianai Nakaanita.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his first loan.  He plans to use the cash to buy 20 young goats, which he will rear and sell later for a profit.

Kurash also is planning to start processing animal skins and hides to sell.

loans.use: To buy 20 young goats, which he will rear and sell later for a profit.

loans.name: Leonard

texts.en:
Leonard N. is 28 years old and single. He supports a family of eight, which includes his mother and his siblings. He does small-scale horticultural farming, which he started two years ago. This business is able to give him a monthly profit of Kshs 15,000.

Leonard has borrowed a loan of Kshs 25,000. This is his second loan in KADET, and he intends to use Kshs 3,600 for fertilizers, Kshs 5,400 for irrigation pipes, Kshs 2,800 for seeds and the remaining Kshs 13,200 for wages and other working expenses.

Leonard anticipates using the profits from the business to rent more farmland to expand his business. Having repaid the first loan successfully, Leonard hopes that he will be able to repay this loan and expand his business and also marry in the next two years.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, irrigation pipes, seeds and other farm expenses

loans.name: Benedicta

texts.en:
Benedicta D. is 74 years old, is widowed, and resides in Pandan which is located in the Province of Antique.

Benedicta has a store in her house where she sells basic necessities and all types of products that people use in their homes. She is requesting a loan so that she can have the funds needed to buy more food products and basic household necessities. This will allow her to attract more customers and increase her sales.

Benedicta’s business is very important because it enables her to provide better financial stability for her family, enabling them to live in a decent manner. She hopes to provide them with everything necessary to move forward against poverty.

Benedicta dreams of the best for her family: to have an expanded business and to have a happy family. She has shown herself to be hard-working and strong-minded enough to make her dreams come true and she is hoping that her business will continue to be more productive and improve the overall quality of life of her entire family.

loans.use: To buy more food products and basic household necessities

loans.name: Oscar

texts.en: Oscar M. is from the village of Bolinao. He is 61 years old and is married with three adult children. Oscar owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. He has been engaged in his business for over thirteen years and earns approximately 3,200 PHP a month. In 2008, Oscar joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Oscar is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand his product offering. This loan will be his 6th from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand his product offering

loans.name: Tiapita Ene

texts.en:
Tiapita has been practicing livestock farming in Naivasha town since 2000. She is 36 years old, is married to Kitupei Ole Siano, and they have two children.

Tiapita was introduced to KADET by her friend and this will be her first loan. She plans to buy animals which she will rear and sell during the peak season at a profit.

Tiapita also wants to start making traditional ornaments which she will sell to her community and also to tourists who are normally attracted by them.

loans.use: To buy animals to raise and sell

loans.name: Rotet Tumanka

texts.en:
Rotet has been practicing livestock farming in Naivasha town for the last two years. She is 32 years old, is married to Silio Tumanka, and they have three children.

Rotet was introduced to KADET by her friend and this will be her first loan. She plans to buy ten goats and six sheep which she will rear and sell later at a profit.

loans.use: To buy ten goats and six sheep to raise and sell

loans.name: Rodori

texts.en:
Rodori G. is one of the good-performing and active member of Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance institution partner in the Philippines since 1999. She is 46 years old and is the mother of five children. She got married at the early age of 18 and only finished her junior year in high school. With this experience she was encouraged to engage in business so that she can provide her family with a better living and send her children to school.

Rodori joined ASHI to have access to capital that she and her husband utilized in fish trading, their primary source of income. As part of the success of their fish-trading business she was able to put up a store that she manages. The profit in this secondary business helps with their daily financial needs and school allowances for her children.

Again, Rodori is applying for a loan of Php 20,000 to buy an additional stock of fish for trading and fingerlings (small fish) for their fishpond. She is optimistic that their income will increase so that she can earn and save more for the expense of her children’s schooling. She is dreaming that all her children will finish a degree in college and find a stable job in the future.

Rodori is thankful for what ASHI and Kiva provide to her family. All the blessings that they benefit from are fruits of the assistance and support that the two institutions offer. She is praying that these institutions will reach more poor but deserving families in the future and change their lives.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell and fingerlings for her fishpond

loans.name: William

texts.en:
William O. is a 50-year-old married father of four children. William is a supplier of building materials in Shanzu Mombasa and has been supplying them to builders for four years. 

William is borrowing his second loan from KADET LTD, and with this loan, William plans to buy building bricks and cement for resale. 

William hopes to educate his children well and to become a leading supplier of construction materials in the future.

loans.use: To purchase building bricks and cement.

loans.name: Genedina

texts.en:
Genedina S. is from the village of San Francisco, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 43 years old. Genedina is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Genedina owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Genedina has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Genedina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Genedina has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Genedina is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Genedina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Juliet's Group

texts.en:
Juliet R. is from the village of Centro Sur, Alcala, Cagayan. She is 43 years old. Juliet is the group leader of an eight-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Juliet is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Juliet owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Juliet has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Juliet joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juliet has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. Juliet is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Juliet from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna J. is a 30 year old married mother of two children. Anna is owner of a salon in Changamwe and has been in the business for six years.
Anna joined KADET LTD recently and is borrowing her first loan to finance her business. She plans to use this loan to purchase of beauty products and cosmetics for use in her salon. She hopes to use the anticipated profits towards savings and to open another salon in Malindi or in Mombasa town.
In the future Anna hopes to own a hairdressing college in Mombasa.

loans.use: To purchase beauty products and cosmetics for her salon.

loans.name: Maria Charito

texts.en:
Maria Charito A. is from Barangay Lantap, Bagabag,Nueva Vizcaya. She is 47 years old. Maria Charito is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Maria Charito owns & operates a business raising livestock, primarily raising pigs for breeding. Maria Charito has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Maria Charito joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Maria Charito has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Maria Charito is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Maria Charito from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies.

loans.name: Jackson

texts.en:
Jackson Kisingu is a 40 year old gentleman. He is married to a lady called Margaret. Together they have three children who are 16, 11 and five years old, respectively. Jackson operates a motorcycle repairs shop in an area that has very many boda bodas (motorbike transport services). This ensures that his business is very busy and he is able to make good profits for every month. He also gets additional income from his wife’s salary as she is employed as a high school teacher.

Jackson just joined KADET LTD and he has applied for his first loan, which he plans to use to buy more spare parts for the motorcycle repairs business. He expects that his income will be boosted and he plans to use this to improve the living standards for his family.

Jackson hopes to buy three more motorcycles and a public service van to offer transport services to many people in the future.

loans.use: Towards buying motorcycle spare parts.

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma A. is from Barangay Lantap, Bagabag,Nueva Vizcaya. She is 42 years old. Vilma is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Vilma owns & operates a business raising livestock, primarily raising pigs for breeding. Vilma has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 4200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Vilma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Vilma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Vilma is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Vilma from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies.

loans.name: Agnes  Kamene

texts.en:
Agnes Kamene M. is a widow, aged 42 years. She has two children: one in polytechnic and the other in form two. She is the sole provider for the family. She was introduced to KADET LTD by a Credit Officer in charge of Tala office.

Agnes is a business lady operating a tailoring shop at Nguluni market, which is an rural area in Tala. She also sells curtains in the same market. The monthly income for the business is KES20,000. She loves her work a lot and wants to use the loan to buy more materials to make curtains and clothes to sell so as to enable her to pay school fees for her children.

Agnes believes that in future she will have a wholesale for distributing curtains and tailored clothes. She is a very creative and ambitious business lady.

loans.use: To increase the stock of fabrics and curtain materials in her tailoring shop.

loans.name: Robelita

texts.en: Robelita A. is from the village of Centro 2. She is 38 years old and is married with three school-aged children. Robelita owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community.
