She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. She said that she is happy managing her business. In 2006, Robelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Robelita is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her 8th from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Wilma's Group

texts.en: Wilma D. is from the village of Malitao, Echague, Isabela. She is 51 years old and is the group leader of this ten-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Wilma is married and has two adult children. She owns and operates a business making and selling food, primarily preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month. In 2009, Wilma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Wilma is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 4th from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Mokinyo

texts.en:
Mokinyo S., aged 23 years, is married to Bushet Mona and together they have two children aged four years, and one year. They live in Bissil which is a rural area in Kajiado.

Mokinyo operates a restaurant in Bissil which is a busy market centre. His clients are mostly adults and he mostly cooks traditional foods. He has been running this business for the last two years and his monthly profit is about Kshs 13,000 (approximately US$161).

Mokinyo was introduced to KADET by the credit officer in charge of Kajiado. Mokinyo wants to use Kshs 5,000 of his loan to increase his stock of foodstuffs and Kshs 25,000 to open a butchery within the same building for easier supervision.

Mokinyo aspires to have a big restaurant and butchery which, from the income, will enable him take better care of his family and educate his children.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for his restaurant and to open a butchery

loans.name: Adela

texts.en:
Adela B. is from the town of Panglao. She is 46 years old and is married.

Adela owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years.

Adela joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI.

Adela is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like soft drinks. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell like soft drinks

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia is a resident of Borewala which is a small city in Pakistan known for its shrines. She owns a small house of two rooms and has been living in it with her family for the last fifteen years.

Razia is a seamstress, sewing clothes for her neighborhood clients and earning an income for her family. She sews with perfect measurements which is admired by her customers.

Razia started this business four years ago and, during these years of experience, she has never received any complaint from her customers about her sewing. She is good at her art and that’s the reason that she receives regular orders. She charges between 100 and 150 PKRs which doesn’t feel to her customers like a big amount to pay.

Razia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her sewing business. With the loan, she will buy another sewing machine and hire a worker who will assist her in her work. In this way she will be able to complete larger orders on time and be able to produce quality work.

Razia is hopeful that, by improving her business, she will be able to provide better living facilities for her family and secure a bright future for her children.

In the photo, Razia is the lady who is raising her hand.

loans.use: To buy another sewing machine for sewing business and hire a worker

loans.name: Milagrina's Group

texts.en:
Milagrina S. is from the village of Mangandingay Cabarroguis, Quirino. She is 59 years old. Milagrina is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Milagrina S..

Milagrina is widowed and has 1 adult child. To make a living, Milagrina owns & operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Milagrina has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Milagrina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Milagrina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Milagrina is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Milagrina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Benjamin Kipkoech

texts.en:
Benjamin has practiced livestock farming in Naivasha town for the past 15 years.  He is 37 years old, married to Margaret Jeptoo, and they have four children.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his second loan. He paid his first loan well and on time. He is planning to use this cash to buy three cows, which he will later sell at a profit.

Benjamin hopes to grow his livestock farming in future and become a leading supplier of animal products in Naivasha town.

loans.use: To buy three cows to sell later.

loans.name: Saeeda's Group

texts.en:
Saeeda is the resident of Borewala, which is a small city in Pakistan known for its shrines. 
Saeeda is a 39 year old, uneducated lady. She loved getting an education when she was young but, unfortunately, her parents couldn’t fulfill her wish due to their poor financial condition.
   
Saeeda got married at the age of 20 and has given birth to four children. Her elder son runs a small bakery in the market where he sells ready-made baked items such as breads, biscuits and cakes on order. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her son’s business. With the loan amount her son will buy bread, biscuits and cakes in bulk quantities for his bakery. 

Saeeda is very supportive person and she is always ready to help her family in improving their living standards. She hopes that her son will get good profits from his business by making an investment towards it. 

Note: “In the picture, the lady who is raising her hand is Saeeda”.

loans.use: To buy bakery items for reselling.

loans.name: Konul

texts.en: Konul O. is a 37 year old trader who keeps her own shop in Agsu city. She has run her business for the last four years. She sells tea, sugar, candies and other food products in her shop. Konul started her business with the help of an AqroInvest loan that she used for buying more goods for her shop. She has a successful loan history. Her monthly income is about 300-500 AZN and she would like to increase it. Konul applied for a 1000 AZN loan to increase inventory in her shop and to increase her income.

loans.use: To purchase more goods for her shop, to increase income.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith T. is from the town of Trinidad. She is married and has 3 children. To make a living, Judith owns & operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She sells sugar, oil and other products. 

Judith joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Judith has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Yasmeen's Group

texts.en:
Yasmeen is a resident of Borewala, which is a small city in Pakistan known for its shrines. She is a housewife, stays at home and does her household responsibilities. She has proven herself a very good wife and a very good mother who is raising her children very well. Her husband's name is M. A.. He is involved in a timber-selling business. He sells timber through his shop, which he has in the market.  

Yasmeen loves animals and loves to take care for them as well. She has young goats at her home and she takes care of them by giving them food and water on time. Yasmeen has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan amount, her husband will buy timber and improve the success of his business.  

Yasmeen is hopeful that the loan amount will help her husband in increasing his income by selling to the maximum number of customers. 
Note: “In the picture, the lady who is raising her hand is Yasmeen”.

loans.use: To buy timber for timber-selling business.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita T. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 59 years old. Teresita is married and has 3 children aged 32, 27 and 18. To make a living, Teresita owns & operates a fishing business, primarily buying and reselling assorted fish. Teresita also sells herbal products. She hopes to acquire more products that she can sell.

Teresita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fish and herbal products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish and herbal products to sell.

loans.name: Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Parveen is the resident of Borewala, which is a small city in Pakistan known for its shrines. She got married to M. R., who operates a small restaurant in the market where he offers different kinds of Punjabi foods and tea to his clients. 

Parveen, herself, is a housewife but she also helps her husband in his business by cooking foods for his restaurant. He sells Daal chawal (a dish made of lentils and rice and served with pickle) and Naan chanay (a dish made of chick peas serves with bread) to his customers. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan amount, her husband will buy food items such as chick-peas, lentils, rice, spices and cooking oil for his restaurant business. By buying the items in bulk, he will be able to make good and tasty food for his customers and to increase his sales as well. Parveen is hopeful that this investment will bring positive changes for her husband’s business and make his income double in size. 

Note: “In the picture, the lady who is raising her hand is Parveen”.

loans.use: To buy food items in bulk quantity for restaurant business.

loans.name: Peter Kintalel

texts.en:
Peter is 27 years old. He buys, raises and sells animals at a profit, especially during peak seasons. He has been doing this type of business in Naivasha town for the past five years. Naivasha is locally well-known as a place for meat roasting {Nyama Choma} and many people go to Naivasha on vacation and weekends to eat roasted meat. So, Peter's business of animal raising is marketable in this place.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his first loan. He  plans to use the money to buy 23 young sheep, which he will raise and sell later, at a profit, during peak season.

loans.use: To buy 23 young sheep which he will raise and later sell, at a profit.

loans.name: Norng

texts.en:
Mrs. Norng P. R. lives in Chheu Teal Phluoh village in Takeo province,  She is 29 years old and a farmer, with 3 children who all attend school. She owns a 2-hectare plot of land where she cultivates rice to sell to support her family and she also works as a farming laborer.  Her husband, Mr. Sara Neat (pictured), is a fisherman. 

Though they both work hard, the couple earns a low income.  To improve her family's standard of living, Mrs. Norng P. R. is applying for a loan to buy four piglets and pig food to start a new business breeding pigs.  With the remainder of the loan, she plans to buy fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy four piglets and pig food

loans.name: Jameela's Group

texts.en:
Jameela is a resident of Borewala, which is a small city in Pakistan known for its shrines. She lives in the area of 435/EB in a two-roomed brick house with her family. 

Jameela is a very good-natured woman who has spent most of her life in serving for her family and relatives. Her family and relatives respect her a lot for her caring and supportive nature towards them. Her husband's name is M. J.. He is a driver by trade. He has been in this profession for the last several years. Earlier, he drove for someone else and then he started driving for himself. Since beginning his own driving business up to now, he gained experience on rickshaw. He purchased a rickshaw five years ago from the savings. He provides transport services to his customers and makes an income for his family.  

Jameela has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband. With the loan amount, her husband will repair his rickshaw. The rickshaw engine is creating problem and, if it never gets repaired, it will seize and put M. into trouble with his business.  

Jameela is hopeful that, by repairing the rickshaw, her husband will continue his driving for a longer period and able to make a good profit as well.

loans.use: To repair a rickshaw.

loans.name: Hot

texts.en: Hot Y., 40, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Seim Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. Y. provides services of protecting vehicles for an income of USD 4 per day. Her husband is in the military, earning an income of about USD 4 per day. The family has to spend USD 60 on food, USD 10 on public transportation, and USD 40 on children’s education every month. Y. is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase a motorbike to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Men

texts.en:
Men S., 37, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Seim Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. S. sells pork, frog meat, and fermented fish for an income of USD 5 per day. Her husband recharges batteries, earning an income of about USD 5 per day. The family has to spend USD 20 on food, USD 30 on public transportation, and USD 15 on children’s education every month.  

S. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a motorbike in order to transport the meat she has to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Ben

texts.en:
Ben L., 33, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Seim Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. L. produces traditional baskets for an income of USD 4 per day. Her husband is a driver, earning an income of about USD 6 per day. The family has to spend USD 80 on food, USD 20 on public transportation, and USD 60 on children’s education every month. 

L. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase more traditional baskets to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more baskets to resell.

loans.name: Morm's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Morm K. was born in 1945 and she is the leader for this village bank loan.  She was selected by the 5 other members, who live in Boeng village in Takeo province.  The members use their portions of the loan in varied ways. 

Mrs. Morm K. and her husband, Mr. Phum Neat, are farmers who own a 1-hectare plot of land where they cultivate rice to sell to support their family. Though it is time to farm the field, Mrs. Morm K. does not have the money to support it.  To improve production, Mrs. Morm K. is seeking a loan  in order to farm this year. She is a mother of two children, one of whom is a student, while the other is a farmer.

loans.use: To farm a plot where rice is cultivated

loans.name: Kim

texts.en:
Kim C., 27, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Seim Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. Yorn sells fish for an income of USD 6 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of about USD 6 per day. The family has to spend USD 50 on food, USD 20 on public transportation, and USD 10 on children’s education every month.  

C. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase a motorbike to for the family to use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Joseph  Mutuku

texts.en:
Joseph is married and is servicing a fourth loan from KADET LTD, and has no history with any other MFI. Joseph will use the loan to buy equipment for mining and also to buy another place for mining. He was introduced to KADET LTD by other existing clients, and his business is located near customers who build houses,who actually requires stones for construction.

With the extra profits, Joseph will grow his business and do furnishing on his home. He is very hardworking.

loans.use: The loan will be used to buy mining equipment.

loans.name: Phourng

texts.en:
Phourng H., 44, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. H. is a housewife while her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of about USD 2 per day. The two children are employed at a local garment factory, earning an income of USD 5 each per day to help cover the family's expenses. The family has to spend USD 100 on food and USD 15 on electricity supply every month. 

H. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase a motorbike to for the family to use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her fourth loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. H.'s husband appears in the photograph because H. was not available.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Hoa

texts.en: Hoa T. N. is 22 years old with two young children. She has had a shop that sells fish, shrimp, crabs, and snails in the local market since 2006 and makes 4,000,000 VND  interest income from this business per month. She has used her SEDA loans effectively and repaid on time. Now she wants to borrow 7,194,000 VND to upgrade her store

loans.use: to upgrade her store

loans.name: Silas

texts.en:
Silas is 48 years old and is married with five children who are between 10 and 22 years old.

Silas is a lawyer and he has been in this profession for about eleven years. His office is open from 8 a.m. until 5 p.m. every day.

Silas needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to buy some equipment to be used in his business. With this loan, he will also try to renovate the place from which he operates his service.

If successful, Silas hopes that he will improve the quality of his services and, in addition to that, he really hopes that his clients will increase as well as his profits. Through operating his business, he hopes for a better future for his family.

loans.use: To buy some equipment and to renovate his office

loans.name: Hem

texts.en:
Hem S., 52, is a widower and resides with his child in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. S. is a police officer, earning an income of about USD 4 per day. His child is an air-conditioner repairman, earning an income of USD 4.3 per day to help cover the family's expenses. The family has to spend USD 40 on food and USD 6 on electricity supply every month.  

S. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase a motorbike to for his son to commute to work. In the future, he would like to use any additional profit to repair his house. This is his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Im's Group

texts.en:
This group loan has six members who are located in Trapeang Tuem village in Takeo province.  The group members will use their portions of the loan in various ways to support their businesses. The group leader selected by the other members is Mrs. Im U.,  who was born in 1975.  She and her husband are farmers who own a plot of land where they can grow crops to sell to support their family.  Her husband also is a palm juice collector. 

It is time for Mrs. Im U. to grow crops in her field, bU. she does not have the money to do this.  To improve production, Mrs. Im U. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer and peanU. seed to grow.  With the rest of her portion of the loan she will buy a pan to make palm sugar. She is a mother of six children.  Five are enrolled in local school, while the youngest one is four years old.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and peanut seed

loans.name: Peter Karomo

texts.en:
Peter has been selling shoes and clothes in Naivasha town for the past six years. He stocks everything from children's to adult's clothing. He is 39 years old, married to Mary Njoki and they have three children.

Peter was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his third loan. He paid all his previous loans well and on time.  He is planning to use the cash from this loan to add stock of clothes and shoes to sell.

Peter hopes to start selling his shoes and clothes by wholesale, to retail sellers in town.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and shoes to sell.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda D. is from Barangay Lantap, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 41 years old. Yolanda is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Yolanda owns & operates a business raising livestock, primarily pigs for breeding. Yolanda has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Yolanda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Yolanda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Yolanda is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Yolanda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies.

loans.name: Sart

texts.en:
Sart S., 48, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. S. is a goldsmith, earning an income of about USD 2.5 per day. Her husband is a security guard for a private company, earning an income of 3.3 per day. Three of her children are employed at a local garment factory, earning an income of about USD 2 each per day to help cover the family's expenses. 

The family has to spend USD 70 on food and USD 15 on electricity supply every month. S. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase a motorbike to for the children to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Thoa

texts.en: Thoa T. N. is 30 years old with two young children. She grows rice and vegetables and is raising 200 chickens for eggs. She sells eggs wholesale and retail to earn her daily income. She joined our credit program in 2008 and has always repayed on time. Currently, she wants a loan of 6,322,000 VND to buy chicken feed.

loans.use: to buy chicken feed

loans.name: Hong

texts.en:
Hong S., 38, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. S. sells food and dessert for an income of about USD 8 per day. Her husband is a supervisor at a Korean school, earning an income of about USD 2 per day. 

The family has to spend USD 120 on food and USD 15 on electricity supply every month. S. is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase beverages to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. S.'s husband appears in the photograph because S. was not available.

loans.use: To buy more beverages to resell.

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Mrs. Chea S. is a villager in Kdol village in Takeo province. She was born in 1956. She is a tailor at her home where she is able to earn some money to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Sam Chory, is a farmer who owns a half-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support his family. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand. So, to improve her own business, Mrs. Chea S. is applying for a loan to buy more sewing machines. With the rest of the loan she plans to buy fertilizer and hire farm laborers. She is a mother of two children, one of whom is a student, while the other is helping the parents’ businesses. Her husband is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy more sewing machines

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina O. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 49 years old. Josefina is married and has 2 children aged 29 and 25. She is in retail business. She sells different products, such as detergent soap, shampoos and supplements. She doesn't have a store yet and only displays her product at the front of her home. She works hard to be able to earn better and to build her store.

Josefina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Josefina has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Josefina is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Tuy

texts.en:
Tuy S., 48, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. S. sells chicken porridge, earning an income of about USD 3 per day. Her husband is a construction foreman, earning an income of about USD 6 per day. 

The family has to spend USD 80 on food, UDS 20 on children education, and USD 15 on electricity supply every month. S. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase construction supplies to improve her husband’s business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits to repair her house. This is her fifth loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy construction supplements.

loans.name: Justus Musyoka

texts.en:
Justus is married to Agnes and they still do have children.

Justus was introduced to KADET LTD  by existing customers, and is servicing his second loan in KADET LTD. He has no history with any other MFI, he plans to use the loan to buy electrical wires and also modern equipment for operation.

He operates his business in a busy market, where he reaches his customers with ease. With the extra profits, he desires to expand his business and to buy household items.

Justus hopes and dreams are to be an electrical consultant. Justus describes himself as hardworking.

loans.use: The loan will be used to buy electrical wires.

loans.name: Ry

texts.en: Mrs. Ry P. was born in 1970. She is a villager in Thnong Roleung village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Morn Oem, are farmers who own a small piece of land to cultivate rice to sell to support their family. She is also a secondhand clothes seller in a local market where she is able to earn a large profit to support her family. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand. So, to improve her goal, Mrs. Ry P. is applying for a loan to buy more secondhand clothes to sell. She is a mother of five children, one of whom is a construction worker, three are studying in school, and the other does home work.

loans.use: To buy more secondhand clothes to sell

loans.name: Kem

texts.en:
Kem P., 45, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. P. is a garment factory worker, earning an income of about USD 3 per day. Two of her children are employed at a local garment factory, earning an income of about USD 3 each per day to help cover the family's expenses. 

The family has to spend USD 72 on food and USD 10 on children education every month. P. is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase a motorbike for the family to use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Duyen

texts.en: Duyen T. D. is 29 years old and lives with her family in Dao thuc village. Her main activities are growing rice and raising 300 hens. She  sells eggs to cover her daily household expenses. When she has time, she works as a wood caver to earn more money. She has participated in the credit program since 2007 and has effectively used her loans and repaid them on time. Currently, she wants to borrow 6,322,000 VND to buy fertilizer, pesticide, and vaccination medicine to avoid bird flu .

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, pesticide, and vaccination medicine to avoid bird flu .

loans.name: Ethelyn

texts.en:
Ethelyn S. was encouraged to join ASHI because of the values of helping women to prove their skills through lending them working capital for a business as a micro-entrepreneur. Ethelyn marked the day that when she joined ASHI. She began to dream, hope, and to find a way to move away under hardship of poverty. To supply additional income for her family, Ethelyn is interested to continue her copra business. Copra is coconut meat, dried under the heat of the sun and used for making soap, cooking oil, shampoo, and etc.

Ethelyn would like to receive a loan amounting 10,000 PHP to purchase more inventory of coconut for copra. As a proud member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a first Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines, Ethelyn is thankful to obtain secured capital to support her goals in life. Her long term goals are to build a profitable copra business, send her four children until finish college, and invest in her home. With the support of Kiva partner, she is dedicated to expand her business and determined to achieve financial stability for her family.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory of coconut for copra.

loans.name: Pheng

texts.en:
Pheng R., 45, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. R. sells cow meat for an income of about USD 6 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of about USD 4 per day. Two of her children are employed at a local garment factory, earning an income of about USD 3 each per day to help cover the family expense. 

The family has to spend USD 85 on food and USD 10 on electricity supply every month. R. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase cows to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan fR. CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. R. in the long-sleeve yellow shirt appears in the photograph with her family.

loans.use: To buy cows to resell.

loans.name: Thoa

texts.en: Thoa T. N. is 22 years old and has a small son.  She is a very hardworking farmer. She grows rice and corn in a paddy of 2,500 square meters. In addition,she  raises 100 hens. Thoa sells eggs and agricultural products to earn income to cover daily household expenses. She has participated in credit programs since 2008, and has effectively used and repaid her loans. Currently she is asking for a loan of 5,450,000,000 VND to buy fertilizer, pesticide and poultry feed.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide and poultry feed.

loans.name: Chaem

texts.en: Mrs. Chaem S. N. was born in 1983. She is a villager in Angk Svay Chek village in Takeo province. She owns a general store in the local village where she is able to earn a large profit to support her family.  She is married to Mr. Makra Ouch, a farmer who owns a 1-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support his family. He also owns a narrow hall for rent. Since her husband’s business is going well, she wants to expand. So, to improve this purpose, Mrs. Chaem S. N. is asking for a loan to buy more chairs. With the rest of the loan she plans to buy fertilizer, gasoline, and hire farm laborers. She is a mother of a child who is too young to work or study. Her husband is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy more chairs

loans.name: Hanh

texts.en: Hanh  T. D. is 19 years old with 1 small child. She works as a wood carver. She is always busy with orders from customers. She earns 2,000,000 VND per month. To increase her  family income, Hanh wants to open a furniture workshop that makes tables, desks and beds.  Currently,she is requesting a loan of 5,014,000VND to buy wood for furniture making.

loans.use: To buy wood for furniture making

loans.name: Yos

texts.en:
Yos Y. is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. Y. and her husband are farmers. They grow rice for the family's use. The two children are employed at a local garment factory, earning an income of about USD 5 each per day to help cover the family's expenses. 

The family has to spend USD 78 on food and USD 7 on electricity supply every month. Y. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a plot of land in the village to expand her house. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to run a business of selling groceries in front of her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a plot of land in the village.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine K. is a married lady. She has no children yet. Her business is located at busy market area called Likoni in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many many tourist attraction sites, as well as the Indian ocean's white beaches. She has been selling such items as charcoal, milk and other items for the last three years to the local people. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is lack of funds to pay for the business license. She is therefore taking a loan of KES20,000 to acquire a business license and to restock her business. She hopes that she can grow her business, serve more clients and get more income. She hopes to be a wholesaler in future. She also sees herself having children in future. She describes herself as quiet and committed to her business.

loans.use: Paying business permit and add stock of general items.

loans.name: Chum's Group

texts.en:
This village bank has four members located in Krang Thnong village in Takeo province. Mrs. Chum S. was born in 1982 and is the group leader selected by the other members. Each group member will use her portion of the loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. Chum S. is a silk-cloth seller, and she is also a farmer who owns a 2.1-hectare plot of land where she cultivates rice to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Leng Chum, is an iron welder at Phnom Penh city. She has a problem because her husband does not have iron weld supplies to use. To improve this business, Mrs. Chum S. is seeking a loan to buy more iron weld supplies to use. She is a mother of two children who are too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy more iron weld supplies to use

loans.name: Bau

texts.en: Bau T. D. is 48 years old.  She has 2 children who are attending  vocational school and college.   She has a small grocery shop at home to serve the purchasing needs of nearby villagers. Her shop has run well since 2004.  It creates a stable income for her family. Bau has been a client of Seda since 2004 and she has used loans effectively in her business. Bau wants to buy more kinds of products to meet the increasing demand of her customers and is requesting a loan of 7630000 VND for this purpose.

loans.use: To buy more kinds of products to meet needs of her customers.

loans.name: Yem

texts.en:
Yem C., 30, is married and resides with his wife and a child in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. C. is a construction foreman, earning an income of about USD 14 per day. His wife grows mushrooms for an income of USD 2.16 per day. 

The family has to spend USD 35 on food and USD 7 on electricity supply every month. C. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase more construction supplements to improve his business. In the future, he would like to use any additional profit to repair his house. This is his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy construction supplements.

loans.name: Tinh

texts.en: Tinh T. N. is  43 years old with 2 children who are in high school. She has opened a furniture workshop for where she makes tables, chairs, beds and wardrobes. Her workshop is  always busy with contracts. Each month Tinh earns 4,000,000 VND. She has participated in Seda's credit program since 2004 and has used loans very effectively in running her business. Currently,Tinh needs to borrow 8,502,000 VND to purchase wood.

loans.use: To purchase wood for furniture making.

loans.name: Un

texts.en:
Un S., 30, is married and lives with her husband and a child in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its palm products.

S. sells groceries for an income of about USD 5 per day while her husband transports water to sell, earning an income of about USD 4 per day. The family has to spend USD 82 on food every month.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase more groceries to stock her store. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to stock her store

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is 38 years old and is married with three children who are 6, 8 and 10 years old.

Betty is well-known in the business of roasting meat. She has been in this business for about two years and her business hours are from early in the morning until late in the evening.

Betty, after realizing that the number of her customers is increasing day after day, needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company so as she can build another place where she can roast her customers' meat.

If successful, Betty will hopefully earn more profits and these profits will allow her to keep reinvesting in her business as well as creating some other sources of income. In addition to that, she will continue building a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To build another place where she can roast meat

loans.name: Mrs. Khien Hing Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan has thirteen borrowers who live in Prey Khcheay village in Takeo province. Mrs. Khien H., who was bO. in 1963, became a village bank president when she was selected by the other members of the group. They will use their portion of the loan for different purposes. 

Khien is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice that she sells to support her family. She is also a pig breeder. Her problem is that her pigs are too small to sell, but she does not have money to support the pigs' growth. To improve this condition, Mrs. Khien H. is seeking a loan to buy pig food.  With the rest of the loan, she plans to buy fertilizer and hire farm laborers. Her husband, Mr. Him Nhoem, is a driver. She has four children who all are studying in school.

loans.use: To buy pig food, fertilizer, and hire farm laborers.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia D. T. is from the town of Bien Unido. She is 53 years old and married.

Virginia owns and operates a fishing business, using the fish to make and sell "tinabal" or salted fish. The fish is packed in salt in a plastic container for days to age.

Virginia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI.

Virginia is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets

loans.name: Tea

texts.en:
Tea M., 25, is married and lives with her husband and a child in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its palm products. M. is employed at a local garment factory, earning an income of USD 2.50 per day. Every month the family has to spend USD 44 on food and USD 10 on electricity supply.

M.’s husband produces metal axes, earning an income of about USD 4 per day. M. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase more metal to improve her husband’s business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.

This is M.’s first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. M.'s husband appear in the photograph because M. is not available.

loans.use: To enable her husband to buy more metal to produce more axes

loans.name: Puth

texts.en: Puth S., 38, is married and lives with her husband (who we see here in the photo) and five children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia. This part of the country is known for products made from palm. S. is a housewife while her husband makes a living producing rice wine. He earns about $4 per day, and the family has to spend about $44 a month on food and $10 a month on electricity. S. is requesting a loan of $1,000 to buy pigs to raise and sell. In the future, she would like to use the profits she makes from this business to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. We see her husband in this photo because she was not available during our visit.

loans.use: buy pigs to raise for sale

loans.name: Khanh

texts.en: Khanh T. D. is 53 years old. She has 3 children. Two of them are attending vocational school. Khanh is a farmer. To earn income, she grows rice, vegetables and tomatoes in paddies of 3,000 square meters. She has worked in this business for many years. To increase her daily income, Khanh also raises 300 hens. Every day, she sells eggs wholesale. Khanh has been a SEDA client since 2004, She has always repaid her loans on time. Currently, Khanh is requesting a loan of 5,450,000 VND to buy fertilizer and poultry feed.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and poultry feed.

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Chea C., 53, is married and lives with her husband and two children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. She makes a living selling beverages and food, earning an average of $5 per day. Her husband raises pigs, earning an income of $2 per day. The family has to spend $75 a month on food, $3 for electricity, and $30 to educate their children. C. is applying for a loan of $1,200 to buy more beverages and food to sell to her customers. In the future, she would like to use the profits she makes from her work to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. We see C. in the photograph with her daughter.

loans.use: buy more beverages and food to sell

loans.name: Adelaida's Group

texts.en:
Adelaida M. lives in the village of Ubong, Solana, Cagayan. She is 45 years old and leads a five-member loan group that is part of ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Adelaida is married, has four school-aged children and makes a living by raising ducks and selling their eggs. She has been in this line of work for more than three years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Adelaida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from ASKI. and is applying for a new one, also for 6,000 PHP, to buy more livestock, feed and other supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by this loan to pay her children's tuition fees. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern parts of the country. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Perlita

texts.en:
Perlita O. lives in the village of Brgy. Lantap, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 54 years old, married, has six grown children and makes a living by raising pigs. She has been in this business for more than 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from her work.

In 2006, Perlita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She is applying for a loan, her first, for 10,000 PHP, to buy livestock, feed and other supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by her business to improve her family's living conditions. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern parts of the country. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy livestock, feed and other supplies

loans.name: Sean

texts.en: Sean R., 49, is married and lives with her husband and three childR. in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. She is a housewife and her husband earns about $3 a day by selling firewood. Each month, the family spends $50 on food, $5 on electricity, and $0.5 on their childR.'s education. R. is applying for a loan for $1,000 to buy a tuk-tuk (or motorized rickshaw) so that her son (who we see here in the photograph) can start a business as a driver. The family plans to use the additional income made possible by this loan to repair its house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a tuk-tuk or motorized rickshaw

loans.name: Philip

texts.en:
Philip K. is sixty-three years old, married, and has five children aged between twenty-eight and fifteen. His business is located at a very busy area called Likoni in Mombasa. Mombasa is in the coastal region of Kenya and it is well known for its many tourist attraction sites, not forgetting the Indian ocean's white sandy beaches. 

He has been selling such items as rice, flour, cooking oil, sugar, and vegetables to the local people for the last fifteen years. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is that his customers do not pay debts as per their agreement, slowing down his cash flow. However he works very hard to keep his business doing well. 

He is using his loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more rice, flour, cooking oil, sugar, and vegetables to sell and meet the demands of his customers. He hopes that one day he will retire and pass the business on to his son who will continue managing it. He also hopes to finish building his house, which he plans to rent out to get from it at the end of every month. He describes himself as cool, patient and determined.

loans.use: Rice, flour, cooking oil, sugar and vegetables.

loans.name: Poach

texts.en:
Poach S., 51, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Prey Veng Province, Cambodia, an area known for being a cross-border business area with Vietnam. 

S. is a farmer and grows rice for an income of $3 US per day. Her husband is an ice-cream seller, earning an income of $5 per day.  S. is requesting a loan of $1200 to purchase a motorbike for the family's use.

 In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buying a motorbike

loans.name: Mrs. In Saroeung Village Bank Group

texts.en: Seventeen people, from the Romiet village I. Takeo province, are requesting a village bank loan. They will each use their portion of the loan for various purposes. Mrs. I. S., born I. 1967, was selected by the other members to be the village bank president. She is a farmer who owns a half-hectare plot of land for cultivating rice to sell to support her family while her husband, Mr. Chan Phrum, is a construction worker. Although they do work a lot, they can earn only a little income. So, to improve this condition, Mrs. I. S. is applying for a loan to buy a cow for breeding to start a new business. She is a mother of three children, one of whom is a seamstress I. a garment factory, while the others are attending school. One of the members I. this village bank loan is blocked I. the photo.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding to start a new business

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria R. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 55 years old. Gloria is married and has six children. Her eldest is 34 and the youngest is 24. Gloria owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Gloria sells fruits, vegetables and dried fish.

Gloria joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Gloria is requesting a new loan of 5000 Philippine pesos (PHP) which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Phun

texts.en:
Phun S., 31, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Prey Veng Province, Cambodia, an area known for being a cross-border business area with Vietnam. S. is a farmer and grows rice for an income of $2 US per day. Her husband is a blacksmith, earning an income of $6 US per day.  

S. is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase snacks and beverages to sell at home. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buying snacks and beverages to sell

loans.name: C2873 Abizeranye Group

texts.en:
Jean de Dieu is 30 years old and single.  Jean de Dieu is the leader of a group called Abizeranye. The group is known for selling a variety of goods and for their transportation business.  This group has been in this business for about three years and the business hours are from early in the morning until late in the evening.

Jean de Dieu and his team need to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, Jean de Dieu and his team will hopefully expand his business by purchasing one additional motorcycle and a variety of goods, mainly foodstuffs.  If successful, this team will hopefully earn more profits and these profits will allow this team to keep reinvesting for better financial stability.

loans.use: To buy another motorcycle

loans.name: Lea

texts.en:
Lea D. is from the village of Brgy. Lantap, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 31 years old. Lea is single. Lea owns and operates a livestock business. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Lea has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 4,200 Philippine pesos (PHP) when she sells one of her grown animals. Though still single Lea is now saving for her future. 

In 2008, Lea joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Lea has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. Lea is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Lea from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisher-folk and small entrepreneurs. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Moussa

texts.en:
Moussa is a 35-year-old married man living in Chtoura with his wife and three children. Moussa owns a pickup which he has used to transport vegetables and fruit from one place to another since 2000. Moussa works hard on improving his service, as it’s his only source of income. His clients are most army barracks in addition to grocery shops. His good reputation and his strong will are his strengths.

Moussa is requesting a loan for the first time from A. Majmoua, in order to do necessary maintenance on his pickup, in addition to taking care of some other personA. things that need to be done. Moussa hopes he can open a big grocery shop specializing in the best vegetables and fruit in the market.

loans.use: To do necessary maintenance on his pickup

loans.name: Prak

texts.en:
Prak S., 56, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Prey Veng province, Cambodia, an area known for its business with Vietnam. Prak is a farmer and grows rice for an income of 4 USD per day. Her husband is hired to harvest rice, earning an income of 4 USD per day.

Prak is requesting a loan of 1200 USD to purchase spare parts to repair their harvester so as to improve her husband’s business. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.

loans.use: To buy spare parts to repair their harvester

loans.name: Petronilla

texts.en:
Petronilla A. is 27 years old, married and has two children, one three years old and the other, only three months. She is from the town of Trinidad within Bohol province on the Visayas islands. Petronilla runs a general store from which she sells a variety of different products to the local community. She also plans to buy and sell rice at her store.

Petronilla joined CEVI to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Petronilla is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Bella Ballesteros' Group

texts.en:
Bella B. is 38 years old, married and has two school-aged children. She is from the village of Namnama within the municipality of Cabatuan, a part of Isabela province on the Luzon islands. Bella is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Bella runs a food stall from which she operates a canteen or eatery in the community. Bella has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 5000 PHP monthly.

In 2009 Bella joined ASKI to gain access to its financial services. Bella successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase additional inventory and gain working capital. Bella is requesting a new loan, her third from ASKI, of 13,000 PHP which will be used for the same purpose. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business.

About ASKI:

Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc., or ASKI, is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and -women, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy additional inventory and gain working capital

loans.name: Som

texts.en:
Som S., 54, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Prey Veng province, Cambodia, an area known for its business with Vietnam. Som sells porridge for an income of 5 USD per day. Her four children are employed at different workplaces, earning an income of about 2 USD per day to help cover the family expenses.

Som is requesting a loan, her first from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia, of 1000 USD to purchase construction materials to help with one of the children’s businesses. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.

loans.use: To buy construction materials for one of her children

loans.name: Barnabas Oyugi

texts.en:
Barnabas Oyugi O. is 50 years old, married to Lorence Mokeira Oyugi and is the father of five school-aged children. He has a cereal store that he has been running for the last two years on a busy street in Narok Town. Barnabas believes he works hard and only needs the resources to attain his goals.

Barnabas learned about KADET through a friend who is a KADET-registered client. He is requesting a loan, his fourth, to increase his stock of beans and maize. This being the season for harvesting maize and beans, he is hoping to buy more stock to sell later when the price and demand are high. With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, he plans to open another shop and create employment for other people. His dream is to be able to build his own store and house.

loans.use: To spend 40,000 KES to buy more stocks of beans and maize.

loans.name: Salim

texts.ru: Salim P. 30 let. On ne jenat i jivet v Absheron regione. Salim  uje 8 let kak zanimayetsya etim biznessom. Etomu biznessu on nauchilsya u svoyeqo otca kotoriy toje bil masnikom. Ranshe on derjal skot sam i prodoval ix masnikam a potom on reshil sam otkrit svoy maqazin masnika. Seychas Salim nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit skot dlya prodaji masa.
texts.en:
Salim P. is thirty years old. He is single and lives in the Absheron region. Salim has been in business for eight years. He started this business with his father, who was also a butcher. Previously, he kept a herd of cattle and sold them to a butcher, but then he decided to open his own butcher shop. Now, Salim needs 2000 AZN to buy cattle in order to sell meat.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cattle for butchering

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna M. is 55 years old and a widow. She is from the village of Calamagui within San Pablo municipality, a part of Isabela province on the Luzon islands. Edna raises pigs to fatten and sell. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3500 PHP whenever she sells one of her pigs.

In 2009 Edna joined ASKI to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from ASKI which she used to purchase piglets to raise and sell in the future. Edna is requesting a new loan, her fourth from ASKI, of 8000 PHP that will be used to purchase more piglets. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business.

About ASKI:

Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc., or ASKI, is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and -women, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: Rorng

texts.en:
Rorng S., 29, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Prey Veng Province, Cambodia, an area known for its business with Vietnam. Rorng is employed as a garment factory worker for 2 USD per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of 3 USD per day.

Rorng is requesting a loan of 700 USD to purchase a motorbike for the family’s use. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. In the future, she would like to use any profits to repair her house.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Mr. Sau Sam Aun Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank group has twelve people located I. Trapeang Phlu village I. Takeo province. Born I. 1981, Mr. Sau S. A. was selected by the members to be the village bank president. He is a motorcycle taxi driver earning money to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Photha Bieng, is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. His problem is that his wife’s field has poor soil. S., to improve production, Mr. Sau S. A. is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer. He is a father of two children, one of whom is enrolled I. local school, while the youngest one is seven years old. Other members of the group will use their portion of the loan I. various ways.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Catherine Sempeyo

texts.en:
Catherine Sempeyo K. is 22 years old and a widow who supports two members of her family. She has been running an agro-veterinary shop for the last four years in Nkareta, a shopping center in the outskirts of Narok Town. Catherine believes she is hard-working, and she only needs the resources to attain her goals.

She learned about KADET from other women who are already registered as clients. With a loan of 40,000 KES she is planning to increase her shop’s stock by buying more agro-medicines. With the profits she hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, her fourth from KADET, she plans to open another shop and create employment for other people. Her dream is that she will be able to build her own house and run the shop from her own premises.

loans.use: To buy more agro-vet medicines

loans.name: Chuk

texts.en:
Chuk T., 26, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Prey Veng Province, Cambodia, which is known for being a cross-border business area with Vietnam. Chuk T. is a farmer for an income of $3 US per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of $6 per day.

T. is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase a new motorbike for her husband to operate his business more efficiently. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buying a motorbike

loans.name: Khursheed Abdul Razaq's Group

texts.en:
Khursheed lives in the small Pakistani city of Borewala, which is famous for its shrines. She is very good at embroidery and takes orders from local people to provide them with finished products to earn an income for the family. She started this business three years ago and now handles a good number of customers.
Khursheed's husband is A. R.. He owns and operates a book-selling business. He has a small shop in the market from where he sells religious and course books and comics. He has been in this business for the past five years. Khursheed has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy religious and course books and comics to increase his trade. Khursheed hopes that her husband will successfully improve his business by using the loan money. She plans to buy an embroidery machine for her embroidery business with the profit from her husband’s business.
Note: Khursheed is the lady in the picture who is raising her hand.

loans.use: To buy books for her husband's book-selling business

loans.name: Ligaya Suarez's Group

texts.en:
Ligaya S. is from the village of San Jose, Enrile, Cagayan. She is the leader of a six-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.
Ligaya is 40 years old, married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Ligaya operates a family member's business venture in the food sector preparing and selling pork and chicken barbecue. Ligaya has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Ligaya joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her 1st from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. 

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: C2351 Twiyubake Group

texts.en:
Jacqueline is 30 years old and married with four children who are between 3 and 11 years old.  Jacqueline is the leader of the group called Twiyubake and this group is commonly known for selling cooked food in a restaurant. In addition to that, some of these group members sell clothes in the center of that area.  It is after doing their business that they sit together and realize their income in general.  Jacqueline and her team have been in this business for about three years and the business hours are from 5 am to 8 pm every day.

Jacqueline and her team are requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, this team will expand its business by purchasing different styles of clothes to sell and equipment to be used in the restaurant to increase the quantity of food they cook as their customers increase.  If successful, Jacqueline and her team will hopefully earn more profits, which in turn will allow her to keep reinvesting for better financial stability. In addition to that, they will continue improving the their families' lifestyle.

loans.use: To purchase more styles of clothes

loans.name: Irshad Muhammad Bota's Group

texts.en:
I. lives in the small Pakistani city of Borewala, which is famous for its shrines. She is a 42-year-old talented lady who, as well as being a housewife, operates a business selling hand fans. She makes hand fans (from wood, cloth and hard papers) and sells them to local markets in Borewala as well as the local community to supplement her family's income. The hand fans are very popular in Pakistan because they help the air when electricity is not available. I. sells a good number of hand fans every month and earns a good profit.
I.'s husband has a business repairing bicycles. He operates a small shop in the nearby market from which he repairs bicycles and sells spare parts to his customers. I. has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy the latest repair tools and spare parts for his business. I. is hopeful that her husband will be able to increase his income by investing money in his business.
Note: In the picture, the lady who is raising her hand is I..

loans.use: To buy bicycle repair tools and spare parts

loans.name: Tho

texts.en: Tho T. D. is 26 years old with 2 small children. Before doing farming, she was a worker in a shoe factory.  Currently, she is growing rice, herbal vegetables and sweet potatoes. Tho sells these agricultural products to earn daily income. In addition she raises 300 ducks and sells their eggs.  Tho joined SEDA in 2004.  She has used loans very effectively to invest in her business. Tho is requesting a loan  of 5,450,000 VND to build a pen for her ducks and to buy feed for them.

loans.use: To build a pen for ducks and to buy feed for them.

loans.name: Loan

texts.en: Loan T. N. is 44 years old and has 2 children in high school. She is a worker in a shoe factory but the salary is not high. Loan cannot cover the financial needs of  her family. Therefore, after finishing at the factory, she raises chickens for meat in order to increase her daily income. Loan joined Seda in 2004 and has always repaid her loans on time. Now, she she is requesting a loan of 5,014,000 VND to build a chicken house.

loans.use: To build a chicken house.

loans.name: Najma Liaqat Ali's Group

texts.en:
Najma is a resident of Borewala, a small city in Pakistan that is known for its shrines. She owns and operates an embroidery business from her home. She started making embroidered clothes for her neighbors three years ago and now she receives regular orders from them due to her good work. She is an expert in her art and knows different embroidery techniques, and this helps her to attract more customers. She does this work to supplement her family's income.
Her husband, L. A., is a driver by trade and drives a rickshaw that he rents. He provides transport facilities and charges according to the distance of the journey. At the end of the day, he has to pay half of his earnings to the rickshaw owner. For this reason he is unable to meet the financial expenses of his family. Therefore, Najma has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband. With the loan, her husband will buy a rickshaw. This will enable him to improve his earnings. By owning his own rickshaw, L. A. will be able to drive it for long hours without the tension of paying rental costs and having to return it at the end of the day.
Note: In the picture, the lady who is raising her hand is Najma.

loans.use: To buy a rickshaw for her husband

loans.name: Maman Kinsimédé Maman

texts.fr: A. est une femme de 41 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 4 enfants, son époux exerce comme activité la soudure. elle s'est lancée il y a de cela 2 ans dans le commerce de produits d'alimentation générale. elle s'est installé dans une petite boutique pour exercer son activité. elle a déjà obtenu de WAGES un crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé, elle sollicite un deuxième prêt pour gonfler son stock avec 4 cartons de spaghetti, 2 cartons de détergents OMO, 3 paniers de tomates et divers autres produits d'alimentation générale.
texts.en:
A. is a 41-year old woman, married and the mother of four children. Her husband works as a weldor. About two years ago, she opened a small store and started selling general food products. She already had a loan from WAGES, which she has properly repaid. She is now seeking a second loan to expand her stock by buying four boxes of pasta, two boxes of detergent (OMO brand), three baskets of tomatoes and other general food products.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing food products

loans.name: C2354 Twiyubake Group

texts.en:
Leatitie is 33 years old and married with four children. The oldest one is 11 and the youngest one is 3 years old. Leatitie's husband is a driver and both work hard to develop their family, In addition to that, Leatitie is group leader of the group called TWIYUBAKE in their local language. All members of this group have different business such as a store selling various products, a pub, selling clothes and so on. Leatitie sells cow meat. 

Leatitie is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to expand her business through by purchasing more products. With the expansion, the group members expect to be able to satisfy their customers.

loans.use: To purchase cows for their meat

loans.name: Anoko Vivi

texts.fr: L. est une femme de 33 ans, elle est une infirmière de formation. elle est mariée et mère de 4 enfants. elle a a annexé à son activité la vente de produits pharmaceutiques dans sa propre boutique qu'il appelle " SECOURS MEDICALS SITOU". elle s'approvisionne à Lomé. elle exerce ce commerce depuis 2005. face à une baisse de son stock de marchandises. elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de divers produits pharmaceutiques.
texts.en:
L. is a 33-year-old woman who trained as a nurse. She is married and has four children. She also runs a shop called "SECOURS MEDICALS SITOU” where she sells pharmaceutical products. She gets her stocks in Lomé. She has been in this business since 2005. Her stocks are currently depleted and she is seeking a loan from WAGES to buy various pharmaceutical products.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of pharmaceuticals

loans.name: Dukoreshamaboko Yacu Group

texts.fr:
Harindintwali Razar, née à Rubavu, province d’Ouest du Rwanda en 1970, il est célibataire, son niveau éducationnel est primaire. Il vit Rabavu.
