Il appartient dans un groupe solidaire appelé DUKORESHAMABOKO YACU,  qui est un groupe solidaire dont les membres sont  les maçons et ils se garantissent mutuellement, Razar et son groupe travaillent pour faire vivre leurs familles en améliorant leurs conditions de vie et en payant les minervaux pour leurs enfants pour ceux qui en possèdent, Razar, lui il est maçon. En fait, le groupe a contracté un prêt au sein d’Amasezerano Community Bankings.a pour acheter des formes destiné a la fabrication des blocs ciment et claustras utilisé en construction des maisons, une partie du profit sera réinvesti pour maintenir la stabilité financière du groupe et épargner afin de préparer pour le bon future.


au
texts.en:
Harindintwali Razar was born in Rubavu, the Western province of Rwanda, in 1970. He is single. He finished primary school. He lives in Rubavu. He belongs to a solidarty group named Dukoreshamaboko Yacu, whose members are masons guaranteeing each other’s loans. Razar and his group work in order to support their families and offer them better life conditions, including payment of school fees for those members who have children. Razar is a masons himself. The group has taken out a loan from Amasezerano Community Bankings to purchase block forms in order to manufacture concrete blocks and parturitions used in building houses. A part of the profits will be reinvested in order to maintain the financial stability of the group as well as put away in savings to prepare for a better future.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing block forms to manufacture concrete blocks and partitions

loans.name: Yehia

texts.en: Yehia is 38 years old, married and the father of five children. He lives in Chtoura. Since 1997 Yehia has worked as a pick-up driver selling fruits and vegetables all over his neighborhood and in nearby villages. Yehia is requesting a loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, to do some necessary maintenance work on his pick-up in addition to paying for some necessary things he needs. His reputation makes him strong in his locality and market. He hopes to open a wholesale grocery store in the future.

loans.use: To do necessary maintenance on his pick-up

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is a mother of four sons and two daughters. Mariam's husband is not able to take care of the family for personal reasons that are out of his control. Mariam is responsible for child-raising and expenses now. She receives a small salary from the Palestinian Authority.

Mariam needs a better source of income for a big family, so she decided to rent a small store to start selling fruits and vegetables. Mariam took a $1,500 loan from FATEN for this purpose and to help her eldest son Imad find a job, as he is thinking of working across the border, which might endanger his life.

Mariam's Son Imad appears in the picture here because she does not want her picture published.

loans.use: Rent a store

loans.name: Mary Waithira

texts.en:
Mary is 34 years and married to 40-year-old farmer Patrick Waweru. They have two children aged 10 and 12. Mary's business is situated at Githunguri in Kiambu, a place known for the highest milk production in Kenya. She has been practicing dairy farming for the last six years and earns a profit of 9,000 KES. 

Mary has no history with any other micro finance institution. She is applying for her first loan with Kiva partner, KADET, which she plans to use to buy another cow so that she can supply enough milk to meet the demands of her customers. She will plow her anticipated income back into her business. Mary plans to grow her farming business to be able to produce over 100 liters of milk daily. She is a very trustworthy and hardworking lady.

loans.use: To buy another cow

loans.name: Angelique

texts.en:
Angelique is 57 years old and married.  Angelique has owned a small shop where she sells beverages and some pastries.  She has been in this business for about three years and the business hours are from early in the morning until late in the evening.

Although Angelique has been in this business for a long time, her capital is still too low to expand meaningfully.  To end this, she needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With the use of this loan, Angelique will hopefully earn more profit, which in turn will allow her to start saving for a better future and continue taking care of her family.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Sadiq

texts.en: Sadiq P. is a widow and raises four children alone.  He is a successful entrepreneur who has been making bread in Imishli city since 2007. He is an experienced bread baker and bakes the traditional bread at home. Sadiq has been in this business for more than four years. His children help him with his business. Having many customers, Sadiq is able to sell the majority of his products from his home. His monthly turnover is 150 to 200 AZN. However, he also has a shop in the central local market to sell the bread. Now Sadiq is requesting a loan of 800 AZN. He is planning to purchase flour at wholesale, which is the basic requirement of his business. His dream is to open his own store one day.

loans.use: To purchase flour at wholesale

loans.name: Florigen

texts.en:
Florigen N. is a married woman who lives in Ponta Tagda Zone 5, Brry. Tagda, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a dried fish business. Her husband, Felomino N., is 46 years old and works as a fisherman to earn his living. He also helps with his wife's business activities. The couple has four children who are 19 to 28 years old.
Florigen joined Kiva partner, NWTF-Project Dungganon, in 2000 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Florigen has been gradually lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 49,500 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 30,000 PHP, thus raising her family's standard of living.
This time, for her 18th loan, she is borrowing 50,000 PHP, which she intends to use to buy more dried fish to resell so that she could continue to save up for the future expansion of her business and have savings for future use. Florigen N. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means 'honorable'). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them 'Dungganon' – a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of the community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more dried fish for resale

loans.name: C4580 Abahuje Group

texts.en:
Jean de Dieu is 40 years old and married with two children who are 10 and 12 years old.  Jean de Dieu is the leader of a group called Abahuje and this group has owned a barbershop for a long time.  The business hours are from 8 am to 6 pm every day.

Jean and his team are requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, the group will buy additional equipment such as chairs and they will start a new barbershop of women.  If successful, this team will hopefully earn more profits, which in turn will allow them to keep reinvesting for a better future for their business as well as their families.

loans.use: To buy equipment

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Embryo implantation

loans.name: Felista Mokami

texts.en:
Felista Mokami M. is 61 years old and she supports seven members of her family.
She has operated a quarry for the last seven years. This business has been successful due to demand from local customers, who buy building stones for building rental houses in the developing estates of Narok.
She learned about KADET LTD from KADET staff marketing awareness efforts in her area. This will be her first loan. She is planning to use the money to hire more people at the quarry in order to increase her output.

Her future dream is to buy modern machines and own a bigger quarry. 
She is a hardworking woman and determined to achieve her set target.

loans.use: To spend Ksh 20,000 to hire more people to increase quarry output.

loans.name: Rosie

texts.en: Rosie L. is a 37-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a general store.  She lives in Mauswagon, Brgy. Sibucao, San Enrique, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable.  She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 5,000. Rosie is requesting a loan of PHP 11,000 so that she can buy additional items for her general (sari-sari) store.  This will be her 13th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 14,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom.  Rosie aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.  About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines and click the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Buy additional items for general store

loans.name: Grace Wanjiru

texts.en:
Grace Wanjiru is a 30-year-old lady married to Simon N.. They have three children aged 10 years, seven years, and five years. She has been practicing farming for five years and has earned an income of Kshs 15,000. Dairy farming is doing well in Githunguri Kiambu.

She has no other history with any other MFI, so this marks her first loan with KADET LTD. She is requesting Kshs 20,000 to buy a dairy cattle. She looks forward to the anticipated income from the proceeds of this loan.

This purchase will improve her dairy farming because the best breeds produce a good quantity of milk. In the future, Grace hopes to have four "best" dairy cows that she can breed on her farm. She is a very hard working lady.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is a married woman with five children. Three of her children currently attend school and the other two have graduated. She lives at her own house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She has operated her beverage selling business for over five years. From home, Asha sells juice and ice cubes to her neighbors and school children. Her major challenge in the business is seasonality. During the rainy winter season (June-July) the demand for juice is low compared to during the hot dry season (January-February). She hopes to be self-reliant in the future and expand her business.

Asha decided to join Yehu to get a loan with the hope of improving her business. With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to repair her refrigerator (which she stands next to in the photo) as well as purchase a sack of sugar and packets of flavoring that she uses to make natural juices.

loans.use: To repair refrigerator, and purchase a sack of sugar and flavoring to make natural juices.

loans.name: Sahiba

texts.ru:
Sahiba H. 40 let. Ona zamujem i imeyet 3 detey, doch kotoroy 18 let ona v etom qodu postupila v universitet , doch 15 let kotoraya uchitsya v shkole i zanimayetsya sportom , i sin kotoromu 11 let toje uchitsya v shkole. Sahiba sama doma zanimayetsya so svoimi detmi i ochen starayetsa chtob oni xorosho uchilis.

Sahiba uje 7 let kak prepadayet detam uroki i uchit ix reshat testi dlya postupleniya v universiteti. Etomu biznessu ona nuchilas u svoyey mami kototraya toje bila uchitelnicey. Seychas Sahiba nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit kniqi testi noviye kotoriye doroqo stoyat dlya toqo chtobi uchit detey.
texts.en:
Sahiba H. is forty years old. She is married and has three children. Her eighteen-year-old daughter entered the university this year. Her fifteen-year-old daughter goes to school and plays sports, and her eleven-year-old son goes to school also. Sahiba studies with her children at home and works very hard to ensure that they study well. For seven years now, Sahiba has been teaching children lessons on how to pass university entrance exams. She started this business with her mother who was also a teacher. Now, Sahiba needs 2000 AZN to buy new books and expensive tests in order to teach her students.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy new books and expensive tests

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is a farmer from Kisii town in western Kenya. She has been farming for the last twenty years and has employed four people from her community. Her farm produces tea, maize, milk, beans, nappier grass and bananas, which are all sold locally. She also earns income from hiring out her tractor.

Eunice is 52 years old and a widowed mother of 7 children, who are between the ages of 14 and 33. Four of the children are currently attending school.

She successfully repaid her previous loan of 45,000KES from Juhudi Kilimo and has requested this loan of 70,000KES to purchase a dairy cow. The proceeds from this loan will go towards her children's educations and also improve the livelihood of her family. Her biggest challenges are limited land for planting nappier grass, lack of a good breed of animals, and diseases. She would like to acquire more quality dairy cows that will increase her milk production in future.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is 50 years old. She is married with seven children who are now between the ages of 16 and 32. Six of the children are currently attending school. She is a farmer from Litein town in Rift Valley, Kenya. She has been farming for the last 12 years and has employed two people from her community. She sells her milk to the local market. She also earns income from her cereals business.

She has requested this loan of 45,000 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will help her pay school fees for her children. She would like to acquire four more dairy cows in the future. Her major challenges are lack of water and diseases. She is happy with the work of Juhudi.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is 33 years old and married with one child.  Samuel owns a shop where he sells a variety of goods such as printers, notebooks, and some other items as the picture indicates.  Samuel has been in this business for about two years and the business hours are from 7 am to 6 pm every day.

Samuel needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, Samuel will purchase some additional items to satisfy the demands of his customers.  If successful, Samuel will hopefully earn more profits, which in turn will allow him to keep reinvesting for better financial stability.  In addition to that, he will create some other sources of income in order to create more jobs for the people in his community.

loans.use: To purchase additional items to sell

loans.name: Johana

texts.en:
Johana is a dairy farmer from Litein town in Rift Valley, Kenya. He has been farming for the last twenty years and has three employees. His mixed farm produces tea, which he sells locally, and milk, which he sells through Brookside Company. He is also in the business of buying and selling livestock. He is 57 years old and married with seven children who are between the ages of 4 and 28. Five of the children attend school.

He has requested this loan of 40,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow. He says that the income from the sale of milk will go towards the education of his children. His biggest challenge is disease, which affects his production. In the future, he would like to buy a piece of land and build a dairy unit for his cows.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en:
Fatima is a mother of four daughters and four sons who lives in Jenin and works in tailoring. Fatima has a tailoring machine in her house, she produces clothes made to order for individual customers.

Fatima wants to enroll in a professional tailoring course along with two of her children, aged 19 and 20, since they help her with her work. She hopes to expand her project in order to be able to serve a larger number of clients.

Fatima took a $2,000 loan from FATEN in order to pay the tuition fees. Fatima appears in the picture here in FATEN's office.

loans.use: Training tuition fees

loans.name: Marie Chantal

texts.en:
Marie Chantal is 27 years old and married with two children who are 2 and 5 years old.  Marie Chantal owns a shop where she sells a variety of goods, mainly cosmetic goods and some other goods, as her picture indicates.  Marie Chantal has been in this business for about five years and the business hours are from 5 am to 10 pm every day.

Marie Chantal needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, Marie Chantal will purchase a variety of goods, mainly foodstuffs, which in turn will allow her to satisfy the demands of her customers.  If successful, Marie Chantal will hopefully earn more profits and these profits will allow her to keep reinvesting in her business for better financial stability.  In addition to that, she will continue taking care of her family.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of goods to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Tom

texts.en:
Tom is a member of Omwando group, which is being funded by Juhudi Kilimo. He has been farming for eight years in Kisii town in western Kenya. His mixed farm produces maize, milk, and nappier grass, which are all sold locally. He also earns income from his kiosk in the same area. Tom is 28 years old and married with one child who is six months old.

He has requested this loan through Juhudi of 35,000 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will help him improve the livelihood of his family. In the future, he aspires to acquire a piece of land and expand his dairy farming and also expand his kiosk business. His biggest challenges are lack of enough financing to buy farm inputs (e.g., fertilizers) and changes in weather that affect his production.

He is grateful to Juhudi for implementing these rural-based projects to help the poor improve their living standards.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is a married woman with three children, all of whom have graduated from school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family. Amina established her restaurant business three years ago. Her main customers are neighbours and passersby. Her major challenge is theft. Amina hopes to run a big restaurant in the future. In addition, she operates a video library business and a real estate rental agency. 

She decided to join Yehu because of its simple procedures and accessibility to sustainable financial services. With the loan of Kshs 35,000, Amina wants to purchase a bundle of maize flour, a sack of rice and plates to serve food for her restaurant.

loans.use: To purchase maize flour, rice and plates to serve food.

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome is a dairy farmer from Kisii town in western Kenya where she has been farming for the last 25 years. Her farm produces maize and milk which are sold locally. She also earns income by selling horticultural products at a local market. Salome is 43 years old. She is married with 5 aged children all of whom attend school.

She fully repaid her previous loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 35,000KES and has requested this loan of 40,000KES to purchase a dairy cow. The extra income generated from this loan will be used to pay school fees for her children and expand her businesses. Her major challenge is lack of capital  to buy farm supplies like fertilizers and dairy feed. In future, she would like to expand her farming activities by acquiring more dairy cows.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Marciana

texts.es:
La Señora Marciana es cliente recurrente de la Fundación    Paraguaya, ya ha obtenido otros crédito con excelente cumplimientos,  está casada con el Señor Carlos Romero son  padres de dos hijos.
 .    
La Señora Marciana posee una despensa en su domicilio ubicado en el Km 5 ½, Avenida Monday de la Ciudad de Presidente Franco y el señor Carlos es de profesión mecánico de motos, que también realiza trabajos en su domicilio.

Se trata de personas emprendedoras, lo demuestra con los crecimientos que obtuvo con el trabajo que viene realizando hace varios años.
En esta oportunidad solicita el préstamo para la compra de mercaderías para su despensa como fideos, arroz, harina, verduras, enlatados y otros productos de primera necesidad.
texts.en:
Marciana is a previous borrower of the Fundación Paraguaya and has gotten other loans with her excellent payment history. She is married to Carlos Romero and they are the parents of two children.

Marciana has a store in her home, located at Kilometer 5 ½, Monday Avenue in the city of Presidente Franco. Carlos is an auto mechanic and also does work in their home.

They are enterprising people and Marciana demonstrates it with the growth achieved in the work she has been doing for several years.

She is now requesting a loan for the purchase of merchandise for her store such as pasta, rice, flour, vegetables, canned goods, and other basic needs items.

loans.use: Purchase of rice, pasta, oil, baked goods, canned goods, cold cuts, and other items.

loans.name: Tsunday

texts.en:
Tsunday is the chairman of Omwando group in Kisii town, western Kenya which is being funded by Juhudi Kilimo. He has been farming for the last 5 years. His mixed farm produces maize, kale, bananas, nappier grass, and milk which he sells locally. He is also a taxi driver in the same town. Tsunday is 32 years old and married with two children, two and four. His eldest child attends school. 

Tsunday has requested this loan of 40,000KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will help improve the livelihood of his family. He faces the challenge of lack of finance that delays his business operations, and pests and diseases which affect his crops and animals. He hopes that in future, he will be able to increase the number of his dairy cows and start poultry farming.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Leoncie

texts.en:
Leoncie is 35 years old and married with two children who are 3 and 6 years old.  Leoncie is commonly known for selling clothes and this is her fourth successful year in this business.  Her business hours are from 6 am until late in the evening. 

Leoncie needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, she will expand her business by purchasing different styles of clothes to sell.  With these additional styles of clothes, Leoncie will hopefully earn more profits, which in turn will allow her to keep reinvesting for better financial stability. In addition, she will keep providing all the basic needs for her family.

loans.use: To buy different styles of clothes to sell

loans.name: Askia Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe ASKIA est constitué  de 4 femmes mariées  et 3 célibataires  qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 33 ans et ont en moyenne  2 enfants. Elles vivent  dans des  familles monogames à SANOUBOUGOU  I, un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de tissus, de pagnes, de bazin avec  ADISSA T., de charbon de bois, de bois de chauffe, de céréales etc.
ADISSA T. compte acheter avec son  prêt, 50 mètres de bazin au  grand marché, auprès des grossistes.
Les tissus sont vendus au  grand marché de Sikasso et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 27.000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  pour l’appui de son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elle ambitionne d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
The Askia group is made up of four married women and three single women, who average 33 years of age and have on average three children each. They live in monogamous families in Sanoubougou 1, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso (Mali's third administrative region). They are collaborating for the first time with the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, with the goal of satisfying their customers. This group of women trades in materials, "pagnes" (highly decorative West African fabric) and, in the case of Adissa T., damask fabric; they also trade in charcoal, firewood, cereals, etc. With her loan, Adissa T. is planning to buy 50 meters of damask fabric from wholesalers at the large market. The materials are sold for cash at the large market in Sikasso and within her family, to a customer base made up of men and women. She is expecting to make an average monthly profit of 27.000FCFA, of which part will be used to help her husband with the daily expenses and the remainder invested in her business. She would like to increase her turnover in order satisfy customer demand better.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy damask fabric

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is 44 years old and married with 6 school-aged children. All the children are currently attending school. She is a farmer from Kisii town in western Kenya where she has been farming for 20 years. Her mixed farm produces tea, maize, and milk which she sells locally.

She has requested this loan of 40,000KES from Juhudi Kilimo to expand her banana farming and start a cereals business. The extra income from this loan will be used to pay school fees for her children. She faces the challenge of lack of finance to purchase enough farm supplies like fertilizer and animal feed. In future, she would like to expand her dairy farming by increasing the number of her dairy cows from the current three to five.

loans.use: To expand her banana farming and start a cereals business.

loans.name: Rusaria

texts.en:
Rusaria is a fifty-seven-year-old widowed mother of 9 children between 15 and 30. Two of the children are currently attending school. She is a farmer from Kisii town in western Kenya. She has been farming for the last 10 years. Her farm produces tea, bananas, beans, maize, and tomatoes which are sold both locally and through Kenya Tea Development Authority. She also earns income from the sale of clothes at the local market.

Rusaria has requested this loan of 45,000KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a dairy cow that will increase her milk production and improve her family's health. Her biggest challenge is disease which affects her production. She hopes that in five years time, she will be able to acquire at least 6 quality cows.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Abakundisuka Group

texts.fr:
Albert S., née à Ruhuha l’Est du Rwanda, il a 30 ans, il est marié et il a 3 enfants, son ainé a 7 ans et son cadet a 1 ans, son niveau d’étude est primaire. Elle vit avec sa famille à Ruhuha Bugesera. 1 enfant va à l’école.
Il appartient dans un groupe solidaire appelé ABAKUNDISUKA cultivateurs de riz,  qui est un groupe dont les membres sont  agriculteurs de riz et ils se garantissent mutuellement, Albert et son groupe travaillent pour faire vivre leurs familles en améliorant leurs conditions de vie, Albert  comme tout autre membre du groupe il a sa partie dans cette vallée ou il cultive le riz. Le groupe a contracté un prêt au sein d’Amasezerano Community Banking pour acheter les engrais chimique pour félitiliser leur champ. Quand le groupe récolte, une partie de la récolte est vendue et une autre est utilisée pour les familles.
N.B:Certains hommes sont eprisonés et sont remplacés par leurs femmes.
texts.en:
Albert S., born in Ruhuha in the Eastern province of Rwanda, is 30 years old. He is married with three children, from 7 to 1 year of age. He finished primary school. [He] lives with his family in Ruhuha Bugesera. One of his children goes to school. He belongs to a solidarity group named Abakundisuka, whose members are rice farmers guaranteeing each other’s loans. to support their families and offer them a better life conditions Albert, like other members of the group, has his land parcel in this valley and cultivates rice. The group has taken out a loan from Amasezerano Community Banking in order to purchase chemical fertilizers for their field. After harvesting, one part of the produce is sold and the other is used by the families. NB: Some of the men are in prison and are replaced by their wives.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing fertilizers

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Fifty-five-year-old Esther is a widowed mother of five children who are now between the ages of 19 and 30. Three of the children are currently attending school. She is a farmer from Kisii town in western Kenya. She has been farming for 15 years and employs one farmhand. Her farm produces maize, beans and bananas, which are all sold locally. She also earns income from her rental houses in the same area.

She has requested this loan of 70,000 Kenyan shillings through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a dairy cow. She says this loan will enable her to purchase a quality dairy cow that will increase the production of milk and her income. The profits from the sale of milk will help her cater to the basic needs of her family. 

In five years time, she would like to acquire more dairy cows that will be producing at least 200 liters of milk daily. Her biggest challenges are insecurity, lack of a market and diseases that affect production.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Martin Julio

texts.es:
El Sr. Martín es cliente recurrente de la Fundación Paraguaya está casado con la Señora Francisca Agüero son padres de dos mujeres.

El Señor Martín es de profesión mecánico dental, realiza los trabajos en A.J. Hermanos consultorio odontología.
También posee una pequeña despensa en su domicilio ubicado en el Barrio Santa Ana de la misma ciudad.

Son personas responsables, eso se ve reflejado en el histórico de pago que posee en nuestra Institución y de las referencias obtenidas de los mismos.

El préstamo en esta ocasión es para la compra mercadería para el negocio de venta de productos de uso domésticos y de primera necesidad como carne, fideos, arroz, panificados, productos para limpieza, todo tipo comestibles, embutidos, enlatados, y otros.
texts.en:
Martín is a returning client of the Paraguaya Foundation.  He is married to Francisca Agüero and they have two grown children.  

Martín is a dental technician who works at A.J. Brothers dental office.  He also owns a small store which is located in his home in the Santa Ana neighborhood of the same city.

They are responsible people, which is reflected in the history of payment they have with the Foundation and the references they were given.

This loan is for the purchase of merchandise for the store, such as household products and necessities like meat, noodles, rice, bread, cleaning products, all types of food, sausages, canned goods, etc.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise for a general store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Floridah

texts.en: Floridah J. M. is forty years old, single and has five children aged between twenty four years old and nine years old. Her business is located at Development house in the Central Business District of Nairobi. She owns a salon in which she serves mostly working women in the CBD.  She has been doing this business for the last twenty months and she says that this business is profitable. The major challenge that Floridah has is lack of operating capital. However, she works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 50,000 to buy blow driers and other salon tools to enable her give good service to her clients. She hopes to grow her business and start supplying hair additions to other salons. She sees herself owning land and building rental houses some day. She describes herself as hardworking, determined and focused.

loans.use: Blow driers.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les six membres du groupe BENKADI sont  toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans et 6 enfants. Elles vivent   dans des  familles polygames à SANOUBOUGOU I, un des quartiers de la  ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur sixième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Tous les prêts précédents  se sont bien dénoués. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels la restauration avec DJENEBA T., la couture, les articles de fête, le bois de chauffe, les chaussures etc.
DJENEBA T.  compte acheter avec son  prêt,  200kg de riz  + 5 paquets de condiments alimentaires + 1 chargement de charrette en bois de chauffe pour faire la restauration.
Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de SIKASSO et dans les villages voisins. 
Les plats sont vendus au  grand marché de Sikasso et  quelques fois en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, le plus souvent au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  pour les dépenses quotidiennes et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The six members of the Benkadi group are all married, average 35 years of age and have on average six children each. They live in polygamous families in Sanoubougou 1, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso (Mali's third administrative region). They are on their sixth loan from the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, with the goal of satisfying customer demand. All their previous loans have been repaid in full. This group of women have a variety of trades, including restauration in the case of Djeneba T., sewing and selling party items, firewood, shoes etc. With her loan Djeneba T. is planning on buying 200kg of rice, five packets of condiments and one barrow load of firewood for her restauration business. She gets her supplies at Sikasso's large market and in neighboring villages. Her dishes are sold, mainly for cash, at Sikasso's large market and sometimes within her family to a customer base made up of men and women. She is expecting to make an average monthly profit of 35,000FCFA, of which part will be used for daily expenses and the rest invested in her business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of ingredients for restauration

loans.name: Teresiah

texts.en:
Teresiah F. M. is twenty one years old, single and does not have any children. Her business is located at Jua Kali market in Nairobi. She makes and sells cookers, sauce pans, metal boxes etc to the local people from within the industrial area and also customers coming from afar like Machakos, Isiolo and Narok. 

She has been doing this business for the last thirteen months and she says that this business is profitable. The major challenge that Teresiah has is lack of raw materials to make her end products and the fact that customers are not loyal since there are other people in the area doing the same business as hers. However, she works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 50,000 to buy more scrap metal for making more items to sell and grow her business. She hopes to grow her business, become a millionaire and help other people. She describes herself as active, God fearing and goal-oriented.

loans.use: Scrap metal

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 54 years old. She is married with 6 children who are now between the ages of 17 and 30. Four of the children are currently attending school. She is a dairy farmer from Litein town in Rift Valley, Kenya. She has been farming for 30 years and has employed three people from her community. Her main products are milk and maize which she sells to the local market.

She has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 50,000KES to purchase and feed a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will help her in paying school fees for her children. In the future, she would like to acquire four more dairy cows and a dairy unit. Her primary challenge is lack of enough water especially during the dry season.

loans.use: To purchase and feed a dairy cow.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet W. M. is twenty nine years old, married to a business man and they have two children, aged eleven years old and four years old. They hope to give their children a good education to the university level. Her business is located at Jua Kali market in Nairobi. She makes and sells metal boxes to the local people mostly found within the industrial area and also customers coming from far like Kikuyu and Kisumu. She has been doing this business for the last seven years and he says that this business is profitable. 

The major challenge that Janet has is lack of raw materials to make her end products and the fact that customers are not loyal since there are other people in the area doing the same business as hers. However, she works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more scrap metal to make more items to sell and grow her business. She hopes that one day she will be able buy her own a big piece of land while still doing her business. She describes herself as hardworking and dedicated to her work.

loans.use: Scrap metal

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth M. K. is thirty nine years old, married to a civil servant and they have four children aged between nineteen years old and three years old whom  they hope to give good education to the university level. Her business is located at Jua Kalo market in Nairobi. She makes and sells cookers, pans, scrap metal etc to the local people mostly found within the industrial area. He has been doing this business for the last eighteens years and she says that this business is profitable. 

The major challenge that Ruth has is lack of raw materials to make her end products. However, she works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 50,000 to buy more scrap metal for making more items to sell and grow her business. She hopes that one day she will be able buy her own lorry which she will be using to transport the scrap metal. She describes herself as hardworking, dedicated to her work, generous and God fearing.

loans.use: Scrap Metal

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Jean Baptise Desire

texts.en:
Jean Baptiste is 55 years old and married with five children.  Jean Baptiste is commonly for selling a variety of drinks and this is his third successful year in this business.  

Although Jean Baptiste has been in this business for about three years, his profits are still too low to cover all the basic needs of his family and save for his future.  To end this, he needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, he will be able to satisfy the demands of his customers as well as the basic needs of his family. In addition, he will keep reinvesting in his business for better financial stability.

loans.use: Expanding his business

loans.name: Cesiri Group

texts.fr:
CESIRI est un groupe constitué de  3 femmes mariées  et d’une veuve ayant une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans, 5 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles monogames à SANOUBOUGOU I, un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur deuxième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Tous les prêts passé ont été bien remboursés. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce  de divers en générale tel la vente du bois de chauffe avec AMI F.,  des condiments ,  et de l’encens.
AMI F.  compte acheter avec son  prêt  6 chargements de charrette en bois en bois de chauffe. Elle s’approvisionne dans les villages voisins, auprès des paysans.
Le bois est vendu en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 50.000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  pour l’appui de son mari dans les dépenses  et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
Cesiri is a group made up of three married women and one widow, who average 40 years of age and have on average five children each; the majority of them live in monogamous families in Sanoubougou 1, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso (Mali's third administrative region). They are on their second loan from the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, with the goal of satisfying customer demand. All their previous loans have been repaid in full. This group of women trade in various items, such as firewood in the case of Ami F., condiments and incense. With her loan Ami F. is planning on buying six barrowloads of firewood. She gets her supplies from peasants in neighboring villages. The wood is sold for cash by the family to a customer base made up of men and women. She is expecting to make an average monthly profit of 50,000FCFA, of which part will be used to help her husband with the daily expenses and the rest invested in her business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy firewood

loans.name: Mike

texts.en: Mike M. O. is 32 years old, married to a business lady and they have one child, age one and a half years old, whom they hope to educate to the university level. His business is located in an open air market in Nairobi known as Jua Kali and is well known as "Kombewa Workshop". He makes and sells metal boxes, wheelbarrows, chicken feeders, etc., to the local people. He has been doing this business for the last ten years and he says that his business is profitable. He works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep his business doing well. The major challenge Mike has is lack of raw materials to make his end products. Mike is using this loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more scrap metal for making metal boxes. He hopes to have a big store with over 20 workmen. He also sees himself having more children and becoming rich in the future. He describes himself as dedicated and a team builder.

loans.use: To buy scrap metal

loans.name: Felisa

texts.en: Felisa A. is a married woman who lives in the seaside town of Dauin, Negros Oriental, just across from one of the Philippines' famous dive sites, Apo Island. She earns her living by operating a general store. Her husband, Ricarte A., who is 73 years old, works as a photographer to earn his living and also helps with his wife's business activities. They have a 24-year-old child. Felisa joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 because she wanted something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, and by the sweat of her brow, Felisa has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty. Her previous loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of 9,500 PHP, improving the family's standard of living. This time, for her 14th loan, she is borrowing 18,000 PHP, which she intends to use to buy more merchandise to resell in her general store. She plans to continue to save up for future home repairs. Felisa A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To fund operations

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
This is 55-year-old Fatmata T.. She is married and has four children, ages 40, 38, 36 and 16 years. She has four additional dependents who live with her because they are her stepchildren and need support while they are doing their tertiary education. In 2005, Fatmata T. established her business selling provisions such as milk, Ovaltine, sugar, etc., as well as cosmetics and drinks. She began her business in order to generate more income to cover their household expenditures. Working 7 days a week and 12 hours a day, she earns about 1,448,960 leones (SLL) every month from this business. 

Fatmata T. requires a loan of 4,500,000 SLL in order to purchase more drinks, provisions and some cosmetics. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profit by approximately 173,875 SLL. In the future, Fatmata T. plans to assist her stepchildren with their education and provide support to her family. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more provisions, drinks and some cosmetics

loans.name: Alfred

texts.en:
Alfred, a dairy farmer from Litein town in Rift Valley, Kenya, has been farming for the last 15 years and employs two farmhands. His main products are milk and maize which he sells locally. He depends solely on the income from his farming activities to meet the basic needs of his family. Alfred is 54 years old, married, and has been blessed with nine children who are now between the ages of 9 and 29. Seven of the children are currently attending school.

He has requested this loan of 50,000KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that the extra income from this loan will help him provide for the basic needs of his family and pay school fees for his children. In the future, he would like to have a pure breed of dairy cows and build a dairy unit. His major challenges are lack of water and fluctuations in the price of milk.

loans.use: To puchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en: Eunice M. A. is 30 years old and married. Her husband works as part of an air crew.  They have one three-year-old child  whom they hope to provide with a good education to the university level. Her business is located at the Central Business District of Nairobi in a commercial building known as Development House. Her business name is Eugeon Agencies. She supplies toners and cartridges to government institutions. Eunice has been in this business for the past six years. She says that the business is profitable but the major challenge she has is delay in payment. However, she works very hard from early morning to late evening to ensure that her business does well. She is using her loan of KES 50,000 to buy more toners and cartridges to supply to more institutions. She hopes to diversify into other businesses. She sees herself become very rich in future. Eunice describes herself as active, honest, and dedicated to her business.

loans.use: To purchase toners and cartridges.

loans.name: Rafaela

texts.es:
La   Sra. Rafaela  es viuda tiene  1 hija, ella se dedica a la venta D. cosméticos, en forma ambulante, la misma le genera un buen ingreso.

La forma D. trabajo es la ir junto al cliente y ofrecer, la mayoría D. la ventas es acredito ya que es la forma más fácil D. colocar los producto comenta  Rafaela.

Así con la ayuda D. su hija están saliendo adelante con mucho sacrificio y dedicación.
Con el día a día, demuestra ser una trabajadora honesta, responsable y con ganas D. seguir progresando.
Ella solicita el préstamo para la compra D. varios producto que le habían solicitado sus clientes como perfumes, cremas, maquillajes entre otros.
texts.en:
Sra. Rafaela is a widow. She has one daughter and sells cosmetics as a door-to-door salesperson. This generates a good income for her.

Her form of work is to go to her customers and offer her products. The majority of her sales are on credit, and she comments that this is the easiest way to sell her products.

Thus, with the help of her daughter, they are making progress, with great sacrifice and dedication.

With her day-to-day work, she shows that she is an honest and responsible worker who wants to continue progressing.

She is applying for the loan to purchase various products that her clients have asked for, such as perfumes, creams, and make-up, among other items.

loans.use: Buy make-up, perfumes, colognes, skin creams, oils, and other items.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Afr. Mus Agency Pri. Group

texts.en:
These are teachers of the African Muslim Agency Primary School in Makeni. This school was built by missionaries in 1991 to help educate orphans in and around Makeni City. The school has a total of 25 staff and 301 pupils.

This is not the first loan that teachers of the African Muslim Agency Primary School have benefited from SMT/Kiva lenders. Previous SMT/Kiva loans have made a lot of improvements in the lives of these dedicated teachers. Some invested in business, others paid school fees for their children, others bought pieces of furniture such as chairs, etc. Having repaid their last loan successfully, they are again seeking for a new loan of SLL 10,800,000 to enable them further develop themselves. 

Alpha M. Tarawalie is the leader of the group. He is 38-year-old. He was born in Makama, an outskirt of Makeni. He married a student and they have four children – two in secondary schools and two in primary schools. Alpha has been a teacher for seven years now. He will use this loan to pay school fees for his children.

loans.use: To pay school fees for his children

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq  membres du groupe DANAYA  (1 femme mariée  et 4 veuves) avec une moyenne d’âge de 45 ans  ont en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogames à MEDINE un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur septième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de pagnes avec BINTOU D. , d’oranges , de savons et de charbon de bois.
BINTOU D. compte utiliser  ce nouveau prêt, pour acheter  30  pièces de pagnes. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché  de Sikasso et à Bamako.
Les pagnes sont vendus au  grand marché de Sikasso et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 75.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The five members of the Danaya group (one married woman and four widows) average 45 years of age and have on average three children each. The majority of them live in monogamous families in Medine, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso (Mali's third administrative region).

They are on their seventh loan from the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, with the goal of satisfying customer demand. This group of women sell "pagnes", which are highly decorative pieces of fabric (this is the case for Bintou D.), oranges, soaps and charcoal. 

With her loan Bintou D. is planning to buy 30 pieces of "pagne" fabric. She gets her supplies at Sikasso's large market and in Bamako. She sells her "pagnes" for cash at Sikasso's large market and within the family, to a customer base made up of men and women. 

She is expecting to make an average monthly profit of 75,000FCFA, of which part will be used for the family's daily expenses and the rest invested in her business.

loans.use: Purchase of "pagnes"

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en: Nancy N. is a married woman who lives in Gingaw, Central Tabao, Zone 4, Valladolid, Negros Occidental. She earns her living selling fish. Her husband, Johny N. Sr., who is 66 years old, helps with his wife's business and works as a fish vendor. They have 11 children who are 19 to 41 years old. Nancy joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she wanted something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, and by the sweat of her brow, Nancy has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty. Her previous loan of 17,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her increase her monthly profit to 10,000 PHP, improving the family's standard of living. This time, for her 14th loan, she is borrowing 19,500 PHP, which she intends to use as additional capital for her fish vending business. She plans to continue to save up for future home repairs. Nancy N. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To fund operations

loans.name: Francois

texts.en:
Francois is 29 years old. He is married with two children and he takes care of one dependent who is five years old.  Francois is commonly known for selling bananas and he has been in this business for about three years.

Francois needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, he will purchase a large quantity of Irish potatoes and some additional quantity of bananas which will hopefully satisfy the demands of his customers.  If successful, Francois will hopefully earn more profits, which in turn will allow him to keep reinvesting for better financial stability and he will continue taking care of his family.

loans.use: To purchase a large quantity of Irish potatoes and bananas

loans.use: To purchase 15 bags of charcoal for resale.

texts.en: Corazon O. is a widow who lives in Sitio Tuburan, Brgy. Cambaog, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a pottery business. Corazon joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 10 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Corazon has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 18,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her increase her monthly profits to PHP 12,000, raising the family's standard of living. For her 11th loan, she is borrowing PHP 18,000, which she intends to use to buy materials for pottery making so that she can continue to save up for future home repairs. Corazon O. is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. loans.name: Sara

texts.en:
Sara has been operating her mixed farm in Kitale town, western Kenya for the last 10 years. Her farm produces milk, vegetables and eggs, which she sells locally. She is 43 years old and married with five school-aged children. All the children attend school.

She has requested this loan of 31,200 Kenyan shillings through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. With this loan, she will be able to provide her family with enough milk for consumption and sale. The extra income will be used to provide for the basic needs of the family. 

Her major challenges are transportation problems and a lack of storage facilities for her milk. In five years time, she plans to have four dairy cows and be the main supplier of milk to the local market.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Emmy

texts.en:
Emmy is 34 years old and he is still single.  Emmy is commonly known for making soap.  Emmy has been in this business for about two years and the business hours are from 7 am to 6 pm every day.

Emmy needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, Emmy will buy an additional machine and some other equipment to be used in his production.  With this additional equipment, Emmy will hopefully earn more profit, which in turn will allow him to start saving for a better future for his business as well as his family.

loans.use: To buy some equipment

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en: Arlene A. is a married woman who lives in Abuno, Brgy. Pajac, Lapu-Lapu City, Cebu. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: a sari-sari (general) store, multicab (a small passenger van) transport and t-shirt printing. Her husband Jaime A., who is 53 years old, works as a multicab driver to earn his living. Their children are between 11 and 19 years old. Arlene joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 10 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Arlene has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loans have helped her build her working capital so that she could stock up her general store with a wide variety of merchandise, which now enables her to earn an average monthly income of 70,000 Philippine pesos (PHP), uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 11th loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use to buy rice and chicken feeds to sell in her general store so that she can continue to sustainably expand her general store and achieve her dream of opening another sari-sari store in a new location, while continuing to improve the living conditions of her family and to save up for the education of her children. Arlene A. is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. loans.name: Daisy

texts.en: Daisy D. is a 43-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating three business ventures: fish vending, direct selling of personal products and selling ready-to-wear clothes. She lives in Brgy. Tuyom, Cauayan, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her three businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 8,400 Philippine pesos (PHP). Daisy is now borrowing 10,000 PHP so that she can purchase more stock to sell. This will be her fifth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 8,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Daisy aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") way. The accompanying photo of Daisy was taken after she attended the weekly NWTF-Project Dungganon Center Meeting that all group-based clients must attend. The meetings give each borrower the chance to share ideas with their group, learn new business skills and pay back their weekly installments. loans.name: Marie Louise

texts.en:
Marie Louise is 24 years old and still single.  Marie Louise is commonly known for selling cosmetic goods and this is her eighth successful year in this business.

Although Marie Louise has been in this business for a long time, her capital is still too low to expand meaningfully.  To end this, she needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, Marie Louise will hopefully earn more profits, which in turn will allow her to keep reinvesting for better financial stability.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Jonaly

texts.en: Jonaly C. is a married woman who lives in Katipunan, Brgy. Sagua Banua, Valladolid, Negros Occidental. She earns her living through fish vending. Her husband Jun C., who is 33 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have three children who are from 6 to 14 years old. Jonaly joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 20 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Jonaly has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 17,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 21st loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,500, which she intends to use to add to her own capital to buy a new motorized fishing boat so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Jonaly C. is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. Her husband Jonah N., who is 41 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have five children who are 3 to 13 years old. loans.name: Santa Rosa De Pachacclla Group

texts.es:
El Bancomunal Santa Rosa D. Pachacclla, pertenece a la localidad D. Yauli en Huancavelica, inicia su ciclo 5 con 18 socias, las cuales tiene diferentes negocios D. agricultura y comercio.
Martina es socia del Bancomunal, tiene 3 hijos los cuales están en edad escolar, su negocio es la compra y venta D. carne, desD. muy pequeña se inició en el negocio al fallecer su padre, ella ha ido incrementando su venta D. a pocos, con los préstamos que recibe D. FINCA le permite comprar en cantidad, Martina es madre sola, por ello siempre trabaja para sacar adelante a sus hijos. Martina solicita un préstamo para la compra D. carne al por mayor, su sueño es tener una carnicería en un local estable en el mercado.
texts.en:
The Santa Rosa D. Pachacclla communal bank is part of the district of Yauli in the Huancavelica province. The group is beginning its fifth loan cycle with 18 members, who each have different businesses in the areas of farming and business.

One of the communal bank members, Martina, has three school-aged children. Her business is the purchase and sale of meat. She started in the business from a young age when her father passed away and her sales have been increasing little by little. The loans received from FINCA allow her to purchase in quantity. Martina is a single mother and she always works to get her children ahead. Martina is requesting a loan for the purchase of meat at wholesale price. Her dream is to have a butcher’s shop at a stable stand in the market.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of meat

texts.en:
Analyn D. is a married woman who lives in Bara Bat-os, Brgy. Mambulac, Silay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: a general store and frozen foods and rice retailing businesses. Her husband, Romeo D., aged 30, works as a truck driver to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have two children who are four and six years old. 

Analyn joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past five loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 5,500, uplifting her family's standard of living. This time, for her sixth cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 18,000, which she intends to use to purchase more merchandise to resell in her general store so that she can continue to save up for future house repairs and her children's education. Analyn D. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Nempapa Tean

texts.en:
Nempapa is a farmer and has two children: Sanayan and Nterere. She joined KADET through other existing members. Nempapa is in the business of selling clothes and jewelry and plans to use her loan to add more jewelry stock. She operates in a busy marketplace, where her customers are able to get the items and, at the same time, most tourists who come to Kenya can get jewelry easily from her shop.

Nempapa will use the extra profits from the loan so her children can go to college. She hopes to stock tourist products. Nempapa believes she is hard-working and ambitious.

loans.use: To increase her stock of jewelry

loans.name: Patrick Nyutu

texts.en:
Patrick M. is a 50-year-old gentleman who is married with three children aged 25, 22 and 18 respectively. He is the sole breadwinner in the family as his wife does not work. He is a welder who has been welding for the past 12 years and he is able to make a profit of about Kshs 28,000 every month. Besides, he has some dairy cows which help him in his secondary business of selling milk.

Patrick is a client who has been in KADET for a while. He is now servicing his third loan after successfully repaying the other two well and on time. He is planning to use the loan to buy stock of metal bars for his welding business. He hopes to make a profit which he will use to boost his business.

Patrick has future plans to open other branches so he can improve his family's living standards.

loans.use: To buy stock of metal bars for welding

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita T. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Tagasa, Brgy. Bitoon, Daanbantayan, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a fishing  business.  Her husband, Cesario T., aged 40, is a fisherman, and works with Nenita to earn a living for their family. They have five children who are aged between five and 20 years. The two older ones have started working and the two youngest ones are currently going to school. 

Nenita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 2,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her fifth cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 11,000 which she intends to use to pay for repair work on her fishing boat and minor house repairs. 

She hopes to earn enough so that she can continue to save up for her children's future education and have enough to invest in other business activities such as poultry and livestock-raising.  Nenita T. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: To repair her fishing boat and for minor house repairs

loans.name: Arlina

texts.en:
Arlina D. is a 40-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a car wash and a car repair shop. She lives in Bali-bali, Cogon, Compostela, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 14,400. 

Arlina is now borrowing PHP 26,000 so that she can have additional working capital to expand the operations of her automotive repair shop and car wash businesses. This will be her 12th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 22,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Arlina aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

loans.name: Amalia

texts.en:
Amalia O. is a married woman who lives in Basak Mercado, Brgy Basak, Lapu-Lapu City, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: a sari-sari (general) store and a vegetable vending business. Her husband, Fernando O., aged 42, works as a Brgy. Tanod (a community security guard) to earn his living. They have seven children who are aged between six and 24. The two oldest ones already have their own families, another works to help the family and two of the younger children currently go to school. 

Amalia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past eight loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 14,000 helped her increase her monthly income to PHP 42,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her ninth cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 14,000, which she intends to use to purchase more products to sell so that she can continue to save up for her children's education, family security and expansion of her businesses. Amalia O. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James M. G. is 42 years old, married to a tailor and they have two children aged 22 and 13 whom they hope to give a good education to university level. His business is located with many businesses in a residential area called Eastleigh in Nairobi. He has been selling TVs, DVDs, music systems and other electronic products to repeat customers and walk-in customers. Besides this business, he also owns a clothing business in an open air market known as Muthurwa in Nairobi. He has been doing this business for the past two years and he says that it is profitable. 

The major challenge that James has is that there are too many people in the area with the same kind of business as his so customers are not very loyal as they are spoilt for choice. However, he works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep his business going well. He is using his loan of Kes 50,000 to buy more electronic products and clothes to grow his businesses. He plans to expand his clothing business and he hopes to own several boutiques in different towns in future. He describes himself as very hard-working, generous and dedicated to his work.

loans.use: To buy electronic products and clothes to sell

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.en:
Jeanne is 53 years old and is married with four children. She is well-known in the business of selling a variety of goods, which also includes the sale of tea. She has been in this business for about two years and her business hours are from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.

Jeanne needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to expand her shop through purchasing a variety of goods like rice, sugar, beans, cooking oil and some other foodstuffs. With these additional goods, she will hopefully earn more profits which, in turn, will allow her to keep reinvesting for better financial stability in the future. In addition to that, she will continue taking care of her family.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of goods like rice, sugar, beans, cooking oil and some other foodstuffs for sale in her shop

loans.name: Eduvegis

texts.en:
Eduvegis R. is a 41-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures: buying and selling livestock and a barbecue vending business. She lives in Brgy. Talisay, Santander, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 9,000. 

Eduvegis is now borrowing PHP 10,500 to provide additional working capital. This will be her fifth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 10,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Eduvegis aspires to improve her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. 

The accompanying photo was taken after the weekly center meeting that Eduvegis attends to share business experiences, learn new business skills/ opportunities and also to repay her weekly installments.

loans.name: Phylis Mwende

texts.en:
Phylis is married to Japheth and they have three children, namely Mercy, Wayua and Munene who are aged 15, 12 and 5 respectively. She is in the clothes business and has been in this business for 10 years. Phylis's business is located in a busy marketplace and thus has a number of customers.

Phylis joined KADET when a credit officer explained what we do to her. Phylis is servicing a second loan in KADET and has had no other loans with other microfinance institutions (MFIs). The current loan will be used to open another boutique and also to save for future restocking with the extra profits that Phylis will save.

Phylis hopes to be a big textile seller/wholesaler and she describes herself as ambitious and focused.

loans.use: To open another boutique

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
Francisca P. lives in Caisong, Brgy. Basak, Lapu-Lapu City, Cebu City. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: a sari-sari (general) store, and mineral water selling and purchase order card businesses. She has two children who are aged 27 and 32. Francisca joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired to something better for her family. 

Her past 10 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon have gradually helped her build her capital and her previous loan of PHP 25,000 helped her increase her monthly profit to PHP 56,000, gradually uplifting her family's standard of living. This time, for her 11th cycle loan, she is again borrowing PHP 25,000, which she intends to use to buy more stock such as rice, water and beverages to resell in her sari-sari store so that she can continue to save up for her family's future security and for home repairs. Francisca P. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Marie Louise

texts.en:
Louise is 26 years old and is married with four children. She is well-known in the business of selling shoes and this is her second year in this business. Her shop is open from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. every day.

Louise needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to expand her business through adding women’s shoes as well as children’s. With this business expansion, she will hopefully earn more profits which, in turn, will allow her to keep reinvesting for better financial stability and enable her to continue providing the basic needs of her family.

loans.use: To expand her business by adding women’s shoes as well as children’s

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en:
Estrella U. is a 59-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures: a general store and a carenderia (a small cafeteria). She lives in Sambag, Brgy. Tubod, Minglanilla, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and carenderia businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 42,000. 

Estrella is borrowing PHP 45,000 for her 12th cycle loan so that she can purchase more stock to sell in her general store. Her previous loan of PHP 29,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Estrella aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

Luzminda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired to something better for her family.
