Piled high with utensils, paper goods and anything else one would need, these stores are your one-stop shop in Nepal. Although usually packed into a space no larger than 100 square feet, these stores carry a sizable and diverse inventory. With the help of Kiva loans, pasal owners are able to keep inventory up and customers happy. Competition is fierce, but with extra capital and a bit of creativity, the opportunity for profit is there.

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community. 
For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates: BPW Partner Page     
Join our lending team: BPW Lending Team

loans.use: Increasing inventory of store

loans.name: Ramona Cecilia

texts.es:
Ramona de 56 años, Tiene una pequeña tienda en la parte delantera de su casa. vive en una zona periurbana llamada “Duran” este lugar esta caracterizado por su ecología en disolución.   

Inicio con su tienda porque no quería depender de su esposo, y también porque su sector no había un lugar donde vendieran víveres, poco a poco la ha venido surtiendo con aceites, arroz, bebidas etc. Sus dos hijas en ocasiones le ayudan en la tienda ya que trabaja desde las 08h00am.  

Para surtir mas su negocio ella quiere comprar con el préstamo enlatados, arroz, bebidas. En el futuro quiere terminar de construir su casa.
texts.en:
Ramona, 56 years of age, and has a small store in the back part of her house. She lives in a suburban zone called Duran, characterized by an ecology in decline. She began her store because she didn't wish to depend upon her husband, and also because her sector didn't have a place selling foodstuff. Little by little, she has begun to stock it with cooking oil, rice, drinks, etc. Her two daughters help in the store on occasions, and it opens for business at 8:00am. To better stock her store, with this loan she wishes to buy canned goods, rice, and drinks. In the future, she wants to finish constructing her house.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING MILK PRODUCTS, RICE AND DRINKS TO SELL

loans.name: Sabina

texts.en:
This is 25-year-old Sabina R.. She is single and has no children. In 2007, she established her general store. By working 6 days a week and 9 hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid 2 loans from Patan BPW. She used her most recent loan to increase store inventory. In the future, Sabina plans to expand her business. She thanks you for your support.  

In the Kathmandu Valley, the small grocery stores, called pasals, are an important part of the local economy. Fresh produce, milk and staples such as rice, lentils and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home. Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margins. By keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase profitability. While a typical pasal might be no more than 100 sq. feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, in-coming produce and shrewd businesswomen. 

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community. 

For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates: BPW Partner Page     
Join our lending team: BPW Lending Team

loans.use: to increase inventory

loans.name: Tamemsu Development Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Tamemsu Development” group from Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They are petty-businesspeople who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, to seek a loan of SLL 800,000 for each member of the group. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses, attract more customers, make more sales and profit and consequently, improve their living conditions. 

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Ramatu C..  Ramatu was born in Makonteh village 45 years ago. She is married and has three children. Her husband is a trader and all three of her children are attending secondary school.

Ramatu sells firewood and has been a businesswoman for 20 years now. She will use her share of the loan to buy a large quantity of firewood to sell.

loans.use: To buy a large quantity of firewood to sell

loans.name: Marie

texts.en: Marie is 29 years old and is married to a motorcyclist. She has one 8 year-old-child who is attending school. She has been selling onions and different kinds of spices for six years. She is known for her good quality products. She is requesting a loan to expand her business by buying more onions and spices in order to open a wholesale shop.

loans.use: to buy onions and spices

loans.name: Ana

texts.en: “Traditionally, the pet industry wasn’t very cool, especially the products available for larger dogs,” explains Ana, the owner of Paco Collars. With her line of handcrafted leather collars and leashes, Ana is looking to change that, one pet at a time. Paco Collars is located in Berkeley, California, and is part artists’ workshop, part retail store, and part classroom. Ana and her employees craft high-quality collars and leashes right in the shop, as well as hosting classes in leatherwork. Ana started her business in 2002 after she began getting requests from friends for collars similar to the one she had made for her own dog, Paco. “A business adviser suggested that I make the designs and send them to be manufactured in China,” she says, “but that was the opposite of what I wanted to do. I was excited to create jobs for artists, and to keep the manufacturing process local.” Ana now employs five part-time workers, and calls in extra help for big orders. However, as demand for her products has increased, She has had trouble finding financing to buy new machines because she doesn’t have an established credit history. A $1,000 loan from Opportunity Fund will allow her to purchase new supplies to boost her inventory and, at the same time, build a credit history for future loans. “You can’t make money unless you can process money,” she says, “but you can’t process money unless you have a line of credit. A company needs it’s own line of credit – this loan is pivotal.” In the future, Ana would like to see a branch of Paco Collars open in New York City. “Our goal is to create a brand within the pet industry. We want to build the most responsible, ethical company we can, sticking to the things we believe in, but bigger.” Find out more about Ana and Paco Collars at http://pacocollars.com.

loans.use: To buy more supplies to increase her pet collar and leash inventory and to build a credit history

loans.name: Nadine

texts.en:
Nadine is 35 years old, married to a carpenter and has 6 children. Her children range from 4 to 18 years old and are all at school. For 15 years, she has been selling timber beds and cupboards.

Her loan will be used to increase her business by buying more timber to make beds and cupboards. She hopes to make a profit to help pay for her children's school fees and to have some savings. Her business is well-known because she has good timber and makes good products. Her desire is to have her own wholesale shop.

loans.use: to buy timber

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.es: La Sra. Marcelina se encuentra  en su segunda secuencia, doña Marcelina se dedica ala venta D. buzos D. algodón la cual es realizada  todos los días por las tardes en la feria que se desarrolla el calle final Tiahuanaco D. la ciudad D. el alto.  Ella vive en domicilio propio en villa ingenio también D. la ciudad D. el alto, con ella viven su esposo que se dedica a la carpintería y sus pequeños hijos D. asisten a la escuela D. la zona.  El crédito será destinado para incrementar mercadería , también desea reunir mas dinero y agarrar una tienda e incursionar en otra actividad, esta muy agradecida con la institución por el apoyo brindado.
texts.en:
Sra. Marcelina is in her second loan cycle. Doña Marcelina makes her living selling cotton clothing, which she does every afternoon in the Tiahuanaco Street market, in the city of El Alto. She lives in her own home in the town of Villa Ingenio, which is also in the city of El Alto. She lives with her husband, who is a carpenter, and their small children, who attend the local school. The loan will be used to increase her merchandise. She would also like to raise more money, open a store and venture into other activities. She is very thankful to the institution for the support they have granted her.

Translated from Spanish by Marni Siegal, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Luis Oswaldo

texts.es:
Luis de 60 años, tiene una papelería en la parte delantera de su casa, vive en una zona urbana llamada “Suburbio” caracterizada porque la mayoría de habitantes son comerciantes informales. 

Empezó su negocio hace 5 años atrás con un pequeño capital que tenia. Poco a poco con esfuerzo a podido aumentar el negocio con víveres y papelería. Trabaja desde las 06h00am hasta las 21h00pm. Vende papelería, cuadernos, plumas, laminas etc. Pero también vende víveres como enlatados, bebidas para tener mas ingresos.  

El quiere con el préstamo comprar papelería, arroz, bebidas etc. En el futuro quiere incrementar su negocio y mejorar su casa.
texts.en:
Luis is 60 years old and owns a stationary store in the front part of his home. He lives in a suburb where the majority of the inhabitants are informal merchants. Luis started his business five years ago with a small amount of money that he had. Slowly with his efforts he has been able to expand his business with groceries and stationary. He works from 6:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. and sells stationary, notebooks, pens, sheets, etc. He also sells groceries such as canned goods and beverages in order to have more income. With the loan he wants to buy stationary, rice, beverages, etc. In the future he wants to expand his business and improve his home.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Manzo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy stationary, rice and beverages.

loans.name: Sobeh Association Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Sobeh Association” group. They are small-scale businesspeople based in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 500,000 for each of them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Rugiatu T.. Rugiatu is 35 years old and was born in a place called Komrabai in northern Sierra Leone. She is married with four children. Her husband is a teacher and her children are attending primary and secondary schools.  For 15 years now, Rugiatu has been selling palm oil and firewood. With this loan, she will expand her business by buying palm oil and firewood in large quantity.

loans.use: To buy palm oil and firewood in large quantity

loans.name: Saeeda's Group

texts.en:
Saeeda lives in Lahore which is the second largest city of Pakistan and is famous for its history and culture. She is 45 years old and is married to M. R. who is a rickshaw driver by trade. He provides transport facilities to earn an income for the family, while Saeeda supports her family through her sewing business. She gets regular orders from her nearby clients and charges between 100-150 PKRs. Her timely completion of orders and well-stitched clothes bring her customers back again and again for her services.
   
She has given birth to three children: two sons and a daughter. Her eldest son and daughter are in the 10th grade while her younger son is in the 8th.
 
Saeeda has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan amount, her husband will buy a rickshaw. Currently he drives a rented rickshaw which doesn’t make enough income for him even if he works harder and longer.
  
Saeeda hopes that her husband will be able to increase the household income and that he will work harder and with more dedication being the owner of his own rickshaw. 
 
She is a regular user of Asasah and is in her 2nd loan cycle. In the previous loan year she has proved herself a responsible person who has never missed any meeting and paid installments on time.

loans.use: To buy a rickshaw

loans.name: Alice

texts.fr: A. Alice est mariée à HOUENOU Théophile, un peintre auto. Le couple a trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Alice vit avec sa famille depuis une douzaine d’année au quartier Sènadé à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Alice n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de sa famille, Alice vend des tissus de différentes sortes (hitarget, bazins, etc.), des ustensiles de cuisine et des glacières par le système de distribution. De façon secondaire, Alice mène comme activité, la vente de fournitures scolaires. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et aussi à Lomé, pays voisin du Bénin, que Alice achète ses produits. Alice exerce cette activité depuis onze ans et a déjà bénéficié de cinq crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qui ont tous été bien remboursés. Alice désire actuellement renforcer son activité et accroître son chiffre d’affaire ; raison pour laquelle Alice sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un sixième prêt.
texts.en:
Alice A. is married to Théophile HOUENOU, an automotive painter. The couple have three children, all of whom attend school. Alice and her family have lived for a dozen years in the Sènadé neighborhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Alice did not attend school. To support herself and her family, Alice sells different types of fabric (hitarget, bazin [damask], etc.), kitchenware and ice chests through the distribution system. Alice runs a secondary business selling school supplies. Alice buys her products at Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin and also in Lomé, a neighboring country of Bénin. Alice has run this business for 11 years and has already received five loans from ALIDé that have been fully repaid. Alice is requesting a sixth loan from ALIDé because she now wants to bolster her business and increase her sales.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabric, kitchenware and school supplies.

loans.name: Pioneros De Huaquillay Group

texts.es:
Digna es socia D. la alcancía comunal “PIONEROS D. HUAQUILLAY”, está conformado por 7 miembros emprendedores quienes viven en la zona D. Huaquillay, distrito D. Comas, departamento D. Lima, trabajan con EDAPROSPO-prosperidad desD. hace 8 años.

Digna tiene 50 años, es separada, tiene 3 hijos D. los cuales 2 son menores D. edad. Delia desD. hace 20 años se dedica a la venta D. micas en las afueras D. un banco, se inicio en este negocio porque en un inicio empezó vendiendo pimienta y comino como ambulante en un mercado, pero a raíz D. que aperturaron un banco cerca a su domicilio y habían muchas personas circulando decidió cambiar D. giro D. negocio. Con el esfuerzo D. su trabajo ha logrado solo pueD. cubrir loa gastos D. alimentos, servicios y educación D. sus 2 menores hijos. El gran sueño D. Digna es poner un negocio en su propia casa.

Con el préstamo otorgado Digna lo utilizara en la compra D. mercadería. Agradecen el apoyo brindado e iniciativa para su constitución como Alcancía Comunal y prometen cumplir con los pagos establecidos en las fechas pactadas.
texts.en:
The “PIONEROS D. HUAQUILLAY” communal bank is maD. up of seven entrepreneurial members who live in the Huaquillay zone of the Comas district and Lima department.  They’ve been working with EDAPROSPO-Prosperidad for eight years.

Digna, who is a part of the group, is 50 years old.  She is separated and has three children, two of who are minors.  Delia has been selling plastic items outsiD. a bank.  She started doing this because at one time she had been selling pepper and cumin on foot in a marketplace, but they opened a bank near her home and there were many people around there, so she decided to change lines of business.

With the effort that she puts into her work, she is able to cover her family’s food expenses, services, and cost of her children’s education.  Her greatest dream is to run a business out of her home.

Digna will use the money from this loan to buy merchandise.  They appreciate the support and the start of their communal bank and they promise to make their payments on the agreed upon dates.

loans.use: Inventory

loans.name: Sakina's Group

texts.en:
Sakina is a resident of Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. She owns a small, two-roomed house where she has been living with her family for over 16 years.
 
She is a 39-year-old lady who owns & operates her embroidery business from home. She started this business three years ago to supplement the family income. She gets orders from her neighbors and receives a good income after completing their orders. Her income allows her to pay for the family's utility expenses.
 
She is the mother of 3 daughters and 2 sons. All of them are getting an education, except the eldest one, who didn’t have any interest in education. That is why he helps his father in his dairy business. 

Sakina has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy another buffalo to increase the milk-productivity of his business. Currently, he has a buffalo at his home and it gives him around 8kg milk. He sells 1kg milk for 45 PKRs, which has become a standard amount in every city. He gets almost 360 PKRs every day. By adding another buffalo his income will double and he will be able to sell milk to more customers.
 
She is a regular loan user of Asasah and is in her 3rd loan cycle. In previous loan years she has maintained good credit behavior and has never missed a meeting.

Note: "In the picture, the lady who is raising her hand is Sakina".

loans.use: To buy another buffalo for the dairy business

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This borrower is 24 years old and is married, having graduated from Intermediate School. She will use this loan to purchase a sewing machine and cloth. She has a good reputation and, in addition to her good work, good quality and suitable prices, it has generated lots of clients.

She has been able to develop her job and raise her family’s income. This loan will provide lots of benefits and encourage her to develop her job further.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine and cloth

loans.name: Musharaf's Group

texts.en:
Musharaf lives with her husband and 2 sons in the second largest city in Pakistan, called Lahore. She owns a house in the area named Mughalpura where she shifted after her marriage. 

She is a very caring and supportive lady by nature. She performs her duties as a housewife and also handles her sewing business. She tries to have a balanced life by giving the required time to her family and her work. She sews clothes for her neighbors and earns a good amount from them. In this way she can share the financial burden with her husband. 

Her husband owns & operates a milk-selling business. He gets milk from his buffalo and sells to different milk shops for profit. He has been doing this for the past 5 years.
 
Both her sons also contribute financially by doing different work. Her elder son works in a private company on a monthly wage while the younger one runs a barber shop.
 
Musharaf has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy another buffalo to increase sales. She hopes that, with the additional buffalo, her husband will have a better financial outcome and that soon he will open his own shop in the market where he can sell milk to his own customers.  

Musharat is a regular loan user of Asasah and is in her 2nd loan cycle. In previous loan years she has proved herself a responsible person who has never missed a meeting and has paid her installments on time.
 
Note: “In the picture, the lady who is raising her hand is Musharaf”.

loans.use: To buy another buffalo for the dairy business

loans.name: A. Cathérine

texts.fr: A. A. Cathérine est née en 1963 à Adjohoun dans le département de l’Ouémé au Bénin. Cathérine vit depuis une trentaine d’année à Agbodjèdo, un  quartier de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Cathérine est mariée à DOSSOU Augustin et est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Cathérine vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple se partage les différentes charges de la famille. Cathérine n’a pas été à l’école. Depuis une vingtaine d’année, Cathérine mène comme activité la vente de divers produits (conserves de tomate, sardine, lait, les pâtes alimentaires, l’huile de palme, divers condiments de sauce (oignons, tomate fraîche, piments, épices), etc.) et aussi du maïs à son domicile. Cathérine s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Cathérine est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà bénéficié de cinq crédits qui ont été tous bien remboursés. Face à la demande un peu plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Cathérine désire renforcer son activité et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle. C’est la raison pour laquelle Cathérine sollicite un autre prêt.
texts.en:
Cathérine A. A. was born in 1963, in Adjohoun in the department of Ouémé, Benin. For the last thirty years or so, Cathérine has lived in Agbodjèdo, an area of Cotonou, Benin's economic capital. Cathérine is married to Augustin Dossou and is the mother of four children, all of whom have received schooling. Cathérine lives with her husband and children, and the couple share the various household responsibilities. Cathérine did not go to school. For the last twenty years or so, Cathérine has been selling various products (canned tomatoes, sardines, milk, pasta, palm oil, various condiments for sauces (onions, fresh tomatoes, peppers, spices, etc.), etc.) as well as corn, from her home. She obtains her supplies at Dantokpa, Benin's international market. Cathérine is a former ALIDé client, having already benefited from 5 loans which have all been fully repaid. To meet the demands of her growing number of customers, Cathérine wants to increase her activity and better satisfy her customers. That is why she is requesting another loan.

Translated from French by Sarah Puchner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various products (condiments for sauce, canned tomatoes, pasta, corn, etc.)

loans.name: Carmen Ines

texts.es:
Carmen de 52 años, tiene una tienda en la ventana delantera de su casa que es de caña, vive en una zona periurbana llamada “Duran” este lugar esta caracterizado por su ecología en disolución.  

Escogió tener una tienda debido a que necesitaba un ingresos para poder mantener a su familia, una de sus hijas le ayudo a comprar algunos víveres y readecuar su casa para ubicar la pequeña tienda en la parte delantera de su cada de caña. Desde ese tiempo ella ha venido trabajando desde las 06h00am.    

Para seguir con su negocio el quiere con el préstamo comprar arroz, bebidas, azúcar, golosinas. En el futuro quiere tener su casa y que su tienda este muy surtida.
texts.en:
Carmen is 52 years old and has a store in the front window of her home which is made of cane. She lives in a periurban area named Duran which is characterized by the dissolution of its ecology. She decided to open a store because she needed income to be able to support her family. One of her daughters helped her buy some groceries and adjust her home to be able to locate the small store in the front part of her home. Since that time she has been working since 6:00 a.m. To continue her business, she wants to use the loan to buy rice, drinks, sugar and candies. In the future she wants to have her home and have her store be well stocked.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Manzo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase rice, drinks, sugar and candies

loans.name: Maria Dominga

texts.es: La señora Maria Dominga C. L., tiene la edad de 46 años habita en el Barrio San Jose de los Ríos es madre soltera con 3 hijos mayores de edad ellos tienen trabajan y con sus ingresos apoyan a sus padres en los gastos en los que estos incurre mensualmente, la señora es agricultora desde hace mas de  17 años y fue gracias a su padre quien la educo en las actividades de la cosecha, durante los años ha presentado problemas de afectación de plagas, que disminuyen la producción de la siembra, es por esta razón que solicita un préstamo para la compra de materiales agrícolas que permitan un mejor mantenimiento fitosanitario para su negocio y que le permita mejores condiciones que favorezcan a su economía y a futuro poder incursionar en nuevos mercados y heredarles a sus hijos recursos económicos para s bienestar y tranquilidad maternal.
texts.en: Maria Dominga C. L. is 46 years old and lives in the San Jose de los Ríos neighborhood.  She is the single mother of three adult children.  They all work and help to support their parents with the monthly expenses.  [Maria] has been a farmer for 17 years and it was her father who taught her to harvest.  Over the years she has had to deal with crop diseases that disrupt her production, so she is asking for this loan in order to buy farming supplies that will allow her to better maintain the “health” of her business and provide her with better financial conditions.  In the future she wants to enter new markets and leave her children the financial resources for their peace and well being.

loans.use: Farming supplies

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This borrower is 27 years old. She graduated from primary school and is married with a child.

She will use this loan to develop her beauty salon and to purchase makeup, new chairs, and a hairdryer. She has been able to gain lots of customers in the market. She has a unique way of styling her clients which draws them to her salon (especially the brides).

She has a good character and a good reputation in the market and this has made her a celebrity among the women in her community.

loans.use: To purchase chairs, makeup and a hairdryer and to redecorate her salon

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This borrower is 29 years old and is single. He graduated from Intermediate school.

He will use this loan to purchase a sewing machine and cloth. He has a shop in a famous market and has been able to attract more clients to his shop due to his reasonable prices and good quality. His customers are both men and women and he has a good reputation in the market despite being young. He has a soft manner with his customers and that has gained him more clients.

He has a strong ambition to develop his shop in the future which will result in raising his income.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine and cloth

loans.name: Nadine Ayaba

texts.fr: Née le 03 Février 1977 à Ouidah, ville historique du Bénin, Q. Ayaba Nadine est mariée à GOULODE Martin, un vulcanisateur. Le couple a deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Il y a trois ans environs que la famille s’est installée  au quartier Sènadé à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Nadine vient en aide à son mari en assurant avec lui les charges de la famille, grâce au revenu issu de son activité. Nadine n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Depuis une douzaine d’année, Nadine vend des produits congelés (viande, poissons, etc.) et aussi divers produits (conserves de tomate et de sardine, lait, pâtes alimentaires, etc.) à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Nadine s’approvisionne au CDPA et à CAJAF COMMON (deux sociétés de vente de produits congelés à Cotonou). Nadine exerce cette activité depuis une douzaine d’année. C’est la première fois que Nadine sollicite auprès de ALIDé un crédit, en vue de renforcer son activité et de mieux satisfaire la demande de la clientèle.
texts.en:
Born on February 3, 1977 in Ouidah, a historic town of Benin, Nadine Ayaba Q. is married to Martin GOULODE, a tire repairman. The couple has two children who both attend school. About three years ago the family settled in the Sènadé district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Nadine helps her husband and provides with him for the family expenses thanks to the income generated by her business. Nadine did not attend school. Nadine has been selling for a dozen years frozen food products (meat, fish, etc.) and various other products (canned tomatoes and sardines, milk, pasta, etc.) at Dantokpa, Benin’s international market place. Nadine gets her supplies from CDPA and CAJAF COMMON (two companies that sell frozen food products in Cotonou). Nadine has been running this business for a dozen years. It is the first time that Nadine requests a loan from ALIDé in order to strengthen her activity and better satisfy customer demand.

Translated from French by Marie-Elodie Bazy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase frozen food products

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina is divorced and has one child. She owns a small business selling thread and other supplies for knitting and sewing. Irina started this business 4 years ago when she was left without a source of income. Today, her profit is about 6,000 Grivnas a month.

Irina would like to borrow 8,000 Grivnas to purchase more stock. She hopes that a large assortment of goods will attract even more clients and increase sales.

loans.use: to purchase stock

loans.name: Afiavi

texts.fr: R. Afiavi est née le 17 Juillet 1971 à Aného. Mariée à KAYOSSI Joseph, Afiavi   est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Afiavi vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari au quartier Sodjéatinmè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Il y a près de sept ans que Afiavi s’est installée dans ce quartier. Afiavi n’a fréquenté que l’école primaire, puis ensuite a appris la couture, une activité qu’elle exerce depuis quatorze ans et qui l’aide à subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants. De façon Afiavi vend des tissus, des rideaux, et des ustensiles de cuisine dans sa boutique. Afiavi achète ses produits à Lomé au Togo, Etat voisin du Bénin. C’est la deuxième fois que Afiavi sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un concours financier, en vue d’augmenter son fonds de roulement et d’élever le niveau de son activité.
texts.en:
Afavi R. was born on July 17, 1971 in Aného. She is married to Joseph Kayossi and is the mother of two children, both of whom go to school. Afavi lives with her husband and children in the Sodjéatinmè neighborhood of Cotonou, Benin's economic capital. Afavi has been living there for almost seven years. The only school she attended was elementary school, after that she learnt sewing, an activity that she has been carrying out for fourteen years. It helps her meet her children's needs. Afavi sells fabric, curtains and kitchen utensils in her store. She buys her products in Lomé, Togo, a country next to Benin. This is the second time that Afavi has requested a loan from ALIDé in order to increase her working capital and expand her level of activity.

Translated from French by Sarah Puchner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bowls, curtains and fabric

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This borrower is 36 years old and is married with three children. She graduated from Intermediate school.

She has a beauty salon and will use this loan to purchase makeup, a barber chair, and a hairdryer. She has a good reputation in the market and is able to bring more clients to her shop due to her modern style that suits their tastes and favorite styles.

With this loan, she will be able to raise her family income and become a good supporter of her husband.

loans.use: To purchase makeup, a barber chair, and a hairdryer

loans.name: S. Euphrasie Irma

texts.fr: A. S. Euphrasie Irma est née le 14 Mars 1965 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Irma est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Irma est une veuve, qui vit donc seule avec ses enfants au quartier Agbodjèdo à Cotonou, depuis un an. Irma n’a jamais fréquenté l’école. Pour assurer ses besoins et répondre aux différents besoins de ses enfants, Irma vend de la friperie depuis une quinzaine d’année. Irma achète ses produits à Missèbo, un marché de Cotonou, et les revend dans le même marché. C’est la deuxième fois que Irma sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un crédit, en vue de renforcer son activité et d’augmenter sa clientèle et son chiffre d’affaire. Irma a bien effectué le remboursement du premier crédit.
texts.en:
S. Euphrasie Irma A. was born on March 14, 1965 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Irma has three children, all of whom go to school. Irma is a widow; she has been living alone with her children at the Agbodjèdo district of Cotonou for about a year. Irma has never been to school. In order to support herself and provide for her children’s needs, Irma has been selling used clothing for about a dozen years. Irma stocks up in Missèbo, a market in Cotonou, and resells her wares a the same market. This is the second time that Irma is seeking a loan from ALIDé in order to bolster her business, increasing her customer base and her revenues. Irma has repaid her first loan well.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing used clothing

loans.name: Tuyana

texts.en:
Tuyana is single. She runs a small enterprise selling women’s clothing, bijouterie, scarves, socks, leggings, etc. in the central market. She has been in this trade for 16 years and has gained much experience working in this sphere of business

Tuyana is seeking a loan of 2,500 Grivnyas to increase her working capital. She is hoping to use additional funding to grow and expand her trade and, as a result, her income. Tuyana is an entrepreneur of integrity. Her professional management skills and friendly customer service have ensured her business a stable standing in this market niche.

loans.use: to increase working capital

loans.name: Sylvie Léa Laure

texts.fr: H. Sylvie Léa Laure est née le 21 Décembre 1963 et est mariée à DJIHOUAN Nestor, un peintre. Le couple a trois enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. La famille s’est installée à Adogléta, un quartier de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin.  Léa Laure a arrêté l’école au cours secondaire. Pour venir en aide à son mari dans les différentes charges du ménage, Léa Laure vend divers produits (sucre, conserves de tomate et de sardine, piles,  lait, savons, papier de toilette, etc.) à Cotonou. De façon secondaire, Léa Laure vend des fournitures scolaires. Léa Laure s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est la deuxième fois que Léa Laure sollicite l’appui financier de ALIDé, en vue d’agrandir son étalage et de mieux faire face à la demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en: Sylvie Léa Laure H. was born on December 21, 1963. She is married to Nestor Djihouan, a house painter. They have three children, all of whom attend school. The family has settled in Adogléta, a district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Léa Laure has left school at the secondary level. In order to help her husband support the family, Léa Laure sells various general goods (sugar, canned tomatoes and sardines, batteries, milk, soap, toilet paper etc) in Cotonou. In addition, she also sells school supplies. Léa Laure stocks up in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. This is the second time that Léa Laure is seeking financing from ALIDé, with the goal of enlarging her stand and better meeting customer demand.

loans.use: Purchasing miscellaneous products and school supplies

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This borrower is 43 years old and is married with five children. She graduated from primary school.

She will use this loan to improve her business by purchasing a table and chair and an embroidery machine. She has a good reputation and is a worthy and trusted borrower.

She is supporting her husband with her good business in order to raise their standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase an embroidery machine and a table and chair

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This borrower is 31 years old and is married with two children. She graduated from primary school.

She will use this loan to purchase a domestic sewing machine. She has a good reputation and has acquired a great deal of experience in her business. She is skilled lady and has the capacity to attract and gain lots of clients.

She has an ambition to raise the level of her family’s income because it will help her husband to pay the family’s expenses.

loans.use: To purchase a domestic sewing machine

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
Pamela is a thirty-two-year-old woman and single mother. She owns a semi-permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda.

Pamela is very enterprising; for six years, she has been selling new clothes and the business is very profitable. However, she has the challenge of late payment by her debtors and this is a setback to her business goal of becoming a wholesaler.

Pamela therefore needs this loan to purchase more shirts, trousers and women’s clothing to sell in her shop at a profit.

loans.use: To purchase more shirts, trousers and women's clothing for her shop

loans.name: San Miguel Arcangel Group

texts.es:
Para la formación el presente comité inicio la Señora Irma González  integrante del comité Torype Oñondivepa   domiciliada en el Barrio San Miguel de  _C.D.E. 
Ella Contactó con sus vecinas y amigas para formar el comité en la Zona.
El comité se Denomina “San Miguel Arcángel”  están  en el   Decimo Cuarto ciclo, con 4 años de antigüedad con el comité  son 16  integrantes, y es un grupo que se destaca  en el barrio por ser muy unidas, solidarias  y responsables, ellas tienen actividades diferentes.
La señora Esperanza quien también es integrante de la comité se está muy contenta con el grupo ya que trabaja en forma integrada por el bienestar de todas.
Así ella se dedica a la venta de ropas desde su casa sonde ofrece todo tipo de prendas de vestir de temporada. 
Ella pudo mejorar mucho después  integrar el comité su actividad ya constantemente hay intercambio de ideas y capacitaciones sobre cómo mejorar las actividades del grupo. 
En esta ocasión como ya entro la temporada de primavera desea contar con mercaderías nuevas y para ello solicita el préstamo para la compra de polleras, blusas, vestidos y otros.
texts.en:
Mrs. Irma González, member of the Torype Oñondivepa committee located in the San Miguel de C.D.E. neighborhood, started this committee. She contacted her neighbors and friends to form a committee in the area. The committee is called “San Miguel Arcángel” (St. Michael the Archangel) and they are in their tenth cycle and fourth year of operation. There are 16 group members. It is notable in the neighborhood for being very united, mutually supportive and responsible. Each has her own type of activity. Esperanza who is also a member of the committee is very happy with the group because it works in an integrated way for the benefit of all. She sells used clothes at home where she has all kinds of seasonal clothing items available. After joining the group she was able to improve considerably since there is a constant exchange of ideas and training over ways to improve group activities. Since the spring season has begun she wants to have new items available so she is asking for a loan to buy t-shirts, blouses, dresses and others.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothes at wholesale for subsequent resale at retail.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy another motorcycle for his transport business

loans.name: San Juan Group

texts.es:
El comité se Denomina “San Juan“están en el Séptimo Ciclo   con 15  integrantes,  es un grupo que se destaca  en el barrio por ser muy unidas solidarias  y responsable entre ellas, las mismas poseen  ahorro  y trabajan en conjunto para la recaudación de fondos para el Grupo.
La Sra. María Graciela se dedica a la venta de ropas, zapatos, zapatillas, para damas, caballeros y niños, con diferentes precios de acuerdo a la marca del producto. El negocio le resulta bastante beneficioso, teniendo en cuenta los años dedicados al mismo y a la buena clientela que posee.
Desea incrementar sus ingresos, comprando al por mayor y más variedad de ropas, teniendo en cuenta la llegada de la primavera, razón por la cual la demanda aumenta, principalmente en prendas más cómodas y frescas.
Invertirá en adquirir al por mayor las mercaderías, abaratando así los precios de costo y redundando en mayores ingresos para seguir creciendo en el ramo.
texts.en:
The committee is called “San Juan” (St. John). It is in its 7th cycle with 15 members. It is a group that is notable in the neighborhood for being very unified, mutually supportive and responsible among themselves. They have savings and work together to raise funds for the group. María Graciela sells clothes, shoes and sandals for women, men and children at different prices according to the brand of the product. The business is quite beneficial taking into account the years she has dedicated to it and the good customer base she has. She wants to increase income buying at wholesale a larger variety of clothes keeping in mind the approach of spring when demand increases especially in comfortable, cool clothing. She will invest to get items at wholesale thereby decreasing her costs that will lead to larger profits so that she can continue to grow in the field.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seasonal clothes at wholesale for later resale at retail.

loans.name: Mujeres Unidas 3 Group

texts.es:
Para la formación del Comité  inicio el Señor Biviano Cabrera ex  integrante del grupo Solidario de  Varones   de la Fundación Paraguaya  de C.D.E. El Señor  informó a sus vecinas y amigas para formar el comité en la comunidad.
El comité se Denomina  “Mujeres Unidas 3” están en el  Decimo Segundo Ciclo, es un grupo que se destaca  en el barrio por ser muy unidas solidarias  y responsable entre ellas, las mismas poseen un gran espíritu emprendedor, ya que realizan labores para la recaudación de fondos para el grupo como Polladas y Sorteos.

La Sra. Alice, una de las integrantes posee una Despensa, la misma ya cuenta con varios años en el negocio y por lo tanto posee una clientela formada, por la calidad de sus productos y accesibilidad de los precios que mantiene.
Desea ampliar el negocio y obtener mayores ingresos mediante la adquisición al por mayor de mercaderías no perecederas, así como de consumo diario, entre las cuales menciona a empaquetados como fideos, productos comestibles a granel, conservas, bebidas, artículos de limpieza, artículos de bazar y ferretería, juguetería, etc. todo al por mayor, así mantendrá los precios bajos y obtendrá mayores ingresos abaratando los precios de costo.
texts.en:
The committee was started by Mr. Bilviano Cabrera, ex-member of the Men’s Solidarity Group of Fundación Paraguaya. He notified his neighbors and friends to form a committee in the community. It is called “Mujeres Unidas 3” (United Women 3). It’s in its 12th cycle. It is a group that stands out in the neighborhood for being very united, mutually supportive and responsible. They have a great entrepreneurial spirit in that they carry out fund raising activities for the group like fried chicken sales and raffles. Alice is one of the group members. She has had a grocery store for several years so she has an established customer base thanks to the quality of her products and the accessibility of her prices. She wants to expand the business and get higher income buying non perishable as well as daily use items at wholesale. Some of the items she mentions are: packaged noodles, bulk food items, canned goods, beverages, cleaning supplies, kitchen supplies, hardware, toys, etc. She wants to buy everything at wholesale so that she can keep her prices low thus obtaining higher income by lessening her costs.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Destined for the purchase of basic need items as well as cleaning supplies, hardware, groceries, beverages and sweets at wholesale for subsequent resale.

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is a 39-year-old man who is married with six children aged 15, 12, 9, 4 and 3 years. He lives in Fort Portal, Uganda, in a rented house with his family.

Moses operates a store selling medicines for people in his community and has been in the business for two years now. He says he still needs more capital to bolster his store and dreams of seeing it grow to the level of a dispensary.

This is Moses’ second loan from HOFOKAM and he intends to use the funds to purchase drugs to sell in his store.

loans.use: To purchase drugs to sell in his drugstore

loans.name: Morelos Cristal Group

texts.en:
This picture was taken in Cecilia A’s business. She is a member of the MoreL. Cristal group that is located in the State of Veracruz in Mexico. In the photo you can see the women of the group around Mrs. Cecilia’s business of selling snacks. She has been selling snacks for the last 2 years. She is requesting the loan to buy supplies for her snack sales. Her customers consider here an honest and hard-working woman and now that identifies the business for the customers. When she requested this loan, she was very happy because she was going to use it to make her business grow. She is 23, studied through secondary school and lives in a common law marriage but she only has one daughter. She will use the loan to buy corn for the corn meal, and supplies for her snack business such as more tables and chairs. She hopes to save to put a floor on the space where she has her business so that her customers are more comfortable. Also in the near future she would like to improve the economic situation of her family and be able to buy a house for her family. Oliva B is the president of the group. She is 29, studied through high school, is married and has 2 children in total. For the last year she has been selling ceramics, and she is requesting the loan to buy ceramics to sell. The group is maD. up of 9 members and it is the first time that they are asking for a loan from CrediComún. The other members are: Oliva B, ceramic sales Reina R, taco sales Esther Francisca M, chicken sales Ana María H, food sales Cecilia G, grocery sales Alicia S, grocery sales Margarita S, tortilla sales Carmela S, silver sales

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy corn for corn meal and supplies

loans.name: Tunka Group

texts.es:
Las señoras del banco D. emprendimiento Tunka se e encuentran en la zona D. Achumani exactamente la meseta D. Achumani, entraron a su séptimo ciclo , la mesa directiva cumple sus funciones las  organizan y dirigen las recuperaciones, las reuniones se realizan en la meseta D. Achumani. Una mayoría D. las socias  son dueñas D. casa  se conocen ya hace muchos años .todas la integrantes del grupo  cuentas con buenas referencias, son  responsables  y puntuales con sus pagos.
La señora placida es la Presidenta del banco ella costura polleras y enaguas hace un trabajo muy hermoso, por tal motivo tiene muchos clientes por la zona, donD. se realizan fiestas casi cada semana, con el crédito otorgado comprara telas por mayor, para realizar varios pedidos, es trabajadora y muy responsable razón por la cual fue elegida presidenta D. este banco D. emprendimiento. 
Todas las socias del banco tienen como actividad el comercio y servicio, razón por la cual solicitan el crédito ya que invertirán en  incrementar su capital D. trabajo, están muy agradecidas con Emprender por la confianza que les brinda.En la foto aparece el esposo D. una d elas socias.
texts.en:
The women of the Tunka community bank live in the Achumani area on the Achumani plain. This is their seventh loan cycle. The board of directors organizes and oversees the loan payments. They meet on the Achumani plain. Most of the members are housewives who have known each other for many years; all of them come well-recommended and are responsible and punctual in their payments. Placida is the bank's president. She sews lovely skirts and petticoats, and she has many clients in the area, where there are festivals almost every week. With this loan, she will buy cloth to fulfill various orders. She is a hard worker, which is why she was chosen as the group's president. All members of the bank work in trading and service. They are all using the loans to increase their working capital. They are very grateful to microfinance partner Emprender for placing its trust in them. The man in the photo is the husband of one of the members.

Translated from Spanish by Ross Forman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabric

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret is a single mother with one child and takes care of three more dependents. She is 42 years old and lives in Fort Portal, Uganda.

Margret operates a computer training center and a driving school and has been in these business activities for the last three years. Having started with a lot of difficulties, she says she is now doing well with no major hardships. She says she hopes to see her business grow to greater heights.

Margret intends to use the loan to purchase computers for her computer learning center.

loans.use: To purchasing computers for her computer learning center

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is a young man aged 27 years. He is married and lives in the town of Fort Portal, Uganda. He is the father of three children aged 8, 6 and 3 years.

Stephen operates a retail shop which has been active for the last five years. He says there are no major hardships in his retail shop business since he endeavors to have it stocked most of the time. He dreams of transforming his retail shop into a wholesale shop.

Stephen says that the purpose of the loan is to enable him buy a motorcycle to cater for the transport needs of his retail shop business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for the transportation needs of his retail shop

loans.name: Maria Del Socorro

texts.es: Maria Del Socorro tiene 67 años, su actividad es la venta de mercadería en general. Hace más de 17 años que tiene este negocio por lo que ha demostrado ser una persona muy emprendedora y que disfruta de su trabajo. Este negocio inicio por que anteriormente se dedicaba a trabajar de enfermera, con el paso del tiempo es que aprendió de este oficio, pues con muy poco capital y con esfuerzos propios es que ha logrado sacar adelante su negocio. El financiamiento que solicita es para la compra de materia prima como sabanas, toallas, calzado, cosméticos y ropa en general. Ella sueña con establecer una tienda de ropa.
texts.en:
Maria Del Socorro is 67 years old, and her job is selling general merchandise. She has been doing this business for more than 17 years, and she is a very hardworking person that enjoys her work. Her business began because earlier she had worked as a nurse, but over time she learned this work. So with very little capital and from her own efforts he has been able to succeed in her business. The loan that she requests is for the purchase of materials like sheets, towels, shoes, cosmetics and clothing. She dreams of opening her own clothing store.

Translated from Spanish by Amy Schapiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Mujeres De Yguazú Group

texts.es:
El comité se denomina Mujeres de Yguazú, están en el Quinto Ciclo, cuenta con 14  integrantes. Es un grupo que se destaca  en el barrio por ser muy unido, solidario y responsable, a la vez realizan actividades varias para recaudar fondos para casos de necesidad. Las integrantes poseen un gran espíritu emprendedor, ya que están al día con las cuotas y pretenden terminar esta etapa nuevamente con muy buen cumplimiento de responsabilidad con la institución. Al adquirir el crédito se les abren muchas puertas para el progreso de sus emprendimientos ya que les facilita la realización de los emprendimientos que ellas desean hacer.
La Sra. Teresa es la delegada del grupo, posee una heladería, la cual está muy bien ubicada y posee una buena clientela, además de helados comercializa golosinas.
La señora desea incrementar sus ingresos, invirtiendo en la compra de más variedades de helados, así como golosinas, teniendo en cuenta el inicio de temporada primavera-verano, lo cual ampliará la demanda de sus productos teniendo en cuenta el clima que se mantiene en el país en esta temporada.
texts.en:
This group, which is called Mujeres de Yguazú (Women of Yguazú) consists of 14 members and is in its fifth loan cycle. It is a group that stands out in the neighborhood for being very united. mutually supportive, and responsible. At the same time, they have various business activities to obtain income  for their families needs. The members have a great entrepreneurial spirit, since they are up to date with their payments and they will try to finish this new loan cycle with complete fulfillment of responsibility to the lending institution. Acquiring the loan opened many doors for them for the progress of their businesses, since it facilitated the realization of the businesses that they wanted to have.

Sra. Teresa is the representative of the group. She has an ice cream shop that is very well located and has a good clientele. In addition to ice cream, she also sells sweets. She wants to increase her income by investing in the purchase of more varieties of ice cream as well as sweets, since it is the beginning of the spring and summer season, which will increase the demand for her products because of the climate in the country in these seasons.

loans.use: Buy ice cream in quantity for resale.

loans.name: 10 De Abril Group

texts.es:
Banco de emprendimiento integrado por  9 integrantes de los cuales 8 viven en la localidad de San José. Excepto 1 persona que vive en el km. 5 y medio entrando de la doble vía la guardia.                                                 Actividad :taxista, vena. De frutas, punto de llamadas, venta. De juguetes, venta. De ropa, venta. De comida                                               
El  presidente el Sr. Evert  taxista hace 5 años, trabaja en el centro de la ciudad de santa cruz.                                                                                                                                                                                       Estado civil : concubino con la señora Esneider y cuenta con un hijo pequeño, el dinero del crédito lo utilizara para el mantenimiento  de su vehículo ya que esta presentando muchas fallas su vehículo y no le permite realizar un buen servicio a sus clientes.                                                                                                        
La Secretaria  la Sra. Leny  vive en el barrio la  peñita de la localidad de san José  hace 19 años, y tiene el negocio de un punto de llamadas en el mismo domicilio de sus padres donde ella vive, es soltera y estudia por las tardes en la universidad, con el dinero del crédito desea comprar cabinas telefónicas.        
                                                                                                                                                                                                              La Tesorera la Sra. Betsi  se dedica a la venta de juguetes en la misma zona, concubina con el señor diego el cual es chofer y cuentan con 2 hijos que se encuentran en edad escolar, con el dinero del crédito compraran mercadería en juguetes Son personas responsables y puntuales y están agradecidos con la institución por el apoyo económico y la motivación de superación en sus negocios.
texts.en:
This entrepreneurial bank is made up of 9 members, of whom 8 live in San José. One lives at kilometer 5.5 near the turn by the police station. Their business activities include driving a taxi, sales of fruits, toys, clothing, and food, and a stand for telephone calls.

The president is Sr. Evert, who has driven a taxi for 5 years. He works in the center of the city of Santa Cruz. He and his partner, Señora Esneider, have one small son. He will use the money from the loan to maintain his vehicle, which has many problems and doesn't permit him to give good service to his customers.

The secretary is Sra. Leny. She has lived in the La Peñita neighborhood of San José for 19 years. Her business is a telephone call point in the home her her parents, where she lives. She is single and studies at the university in the afternoon. With the money from the loan, she wants to purchase telephone booths.

The treasurer is Sra. Betsi. She sells a variety of toys in the same zone. Her partner is Sr. Diego, who is a driver, and they have two children who are of school age. With the money from the loan they will buy toys to sell. 

The bank members are responsible and punctual people who are thankful to the institution for the economic support and the motivation to aim ever higher in their businesses.

loans.use: Maintain taxi.

loans.name: Eduardo Aurelio

texts.es:
Eduardo de 48 años, sale a recorrer las calles de Guayaquil para vender “pastelitos” son hecho de harina, carne y pollo. Vive en una zona periurbana llamada “Duran” este lugar esta caracterizado por su ecología en disolución.  

Empezó hacer pastelitos cuando una amiga de el le propuso trabajar junto elaborando pastelitos. Desde ese tiempo hasta ahora el recorre las calles de Guayaquil como vendedor de pasteles, mientras que el sale a recorre las calles para vender su amiga hace los pastelitos de carne y pollo. 

Para tener mas ingresos el quiere comprar con el préstamo cemento y bloques para construir mejor su casa y así tener espacio para hacer un local de pastelitos. En el futuro quiere termina de construir su casa.
texts.en:
Eduardo is 48 years old and works in the streets of Guayaquil to sell small cakes made of flour, meat, and chicken. He lives in a suburban area called Duran, which is known for its poor ecological state. He began to make small cakes when a friend of his asked him to work together making the cakes. Since that time until now he walks the streets of Guayaquil as a street vendor of small cakes, while his friend cooks the cakes of meat and chicken. To gain more income, he wants to purchase cement and bricks with the loan to better construct his house and in that way have space to establish a shop to sell cakes. In the future he wants to finish constructing his house.

Translated from Spanish by Amy Schapiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cement and bricks

loans.name: Mburucuyá Group

texts.es:
El comité se Denomina ”Mburucuyá“ están en el Octavo Ciclo con 15 integrantes, es un grupo que se destaca  en el barrio por ser muy unidas solidarias  y responsable entre ellas.
Las mismas trabajan en grupo y como tienen una responsabilidad conjunta decidieron  trabajar para contar con ahorros y de esa manera facilitar el pago de las cuotas que tienen cada una de las señoras, y actualmente cuentan con una buena cantidad de ahorro.
La Sra. Mónica quien es una de las integrantes de grupo se dedica a la venta de lencería, ropa interior femenina, así como medias, tohallas, etc.
Tiene buena clientela, la cual va en aumento, por los años que se dedica a este rubro y gracias a su gentileza y esfuerzo.
Comenta que la menera mas facil de vender a sus clientes es acercando la mercaderias hasta ello y ella recurre a esta tecnica por que muchas horas del dia a ofrecer sus prendas, y de esa forma consigue vender gran cantidad de sus mercaderias.
Ademas comenta que este ingreso le ayuda especialmente para la alimentacion de la familia.
 Ella desea ampliar el negocio mediante la adquisición de mas variadas prendas para damas, como son de marcas diferentes, colores, tamaños y teniendo en cuenta el inicio de temporada primaV.-verano, desea invertir en compras al por mayor de modo a abaratar precios de costo y así obtener más ingresos con la venta.
texts.en:
The "Mburucuya" group is in its 8th loan cycle and has 15 members. As a group, they are known in their neighborhood for being very close-knit, group-minded, and responsible. They work as a group and since they have a joint responsibility, they decided to work to have savings. In this way, they are able to facilitate each woman's repayments, and they now have a good amount of savings. Ms. Mónica, who is a member of the group, sells lingerie and women's undergarments, as well as hosiery, towels, etc. She has a good clientele, which has grown through the years she has dedicated to this business, and thanks to her effort and gentle nature. She notes that the easiest way to sell to her customers is by bringing the merchandise to them, and she employs this method for many hours each day, in order to offer her merchandise. In this way, she manages to sell a great amount of her merchandise. She also comments that this investment has been especially helpful in feeding her family. Ms. Mónica hopes to expand her business by acquiring a greater variety of garments for women, such as different brands, colors, and sizes, and by also having in mind that the spring-summer season is beginning. She would like to invest in making wholesale purchases so that her costs will go down and she can therefore obtain better profits on sales.

Translated from Spanish by Katie Kavanagh, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to acquire wholesale merchandise such as undergarments for women

loans.name: The Women's Bank Of Siquirritos Group

texts.en:
The Women’s Bank of Siquirritos is made up of ten women who live in Siquirritos, Limón, located near the Caribbean coast of Costa Rica. In general, the group members are involved in commercial activities such as the sale of catalog items (kitchen wear, cleaning products, jewelry) as well as clothing and food sales. This loan will be used, at the discretion of each individual, to make investments in their productive activities. The majority of this loan will contribute to the purchase of inventory items (mentioned above) which the group members will sell at a markup in order to earn an income.

This loan represents the first partnership between Fundación Mujer and The Women’s Bank of Siquirritos. The loan consultant that has been working with the group members describes the women as hardworking, and goal-oriented. The members have extensive experience in carrying out their individual activities. A lack of access to working capital is a commonality amongst group members and has hindered the progress of their businesses. For this reason, these women have applied for a loan with Fundación Mujer in order to expedite the success of their businesses.

Isabel M. C. is a 41-year-old mother of two who lives with her family. She plans to use this loan to invest in her sales business by purchasing inventory items such as pajamas and other catalog merchandise. Her main objective is to expand her business in an effort to improve the living conditions of her family with the added income. As mentioned, her main obstacle has been a lack of access to working capital.

Isabel wakes up early every day in order to complete domestic tasks and prepare her children for school. The rest of her day is dedicated to her business, making sales, or collecting payments from clients in her community.

With respect to the group, Isabel mentions that all the women are from the same community. She says that the group lending model is advantageous because it allows the women to act as guarantors for each other’s loans.  Additionally, Isabel is thankful for the support offered by Fundación Mujer to the group as a whole. She is aware of the potential disadvantage which may present itself if any members are unable to pay back their loans, as the whole group is responsible for all repayments.

loans.use: To purchase inventory such as pajamas and other catalog merchandise

loans.name: Lydia Junieth

texts.es: La Señora Lydia Junieth se dedica a la venta de mercadería en general, tiene 3 hijos que asisten a escuela primaria y para poder sustentar su hogar es que ella tiene este negocio.  Ella sale a vender todos los días a distribuir sus productos, ella sale muy temprano por lo que sus diferentes clientes viven en lugares muy lejanos, además de estar atendiendo su negocio en casa aprovecha para atender las necesidades de su familia. Su sueño es poder ampliar su negocio, ahora necesita el crédito para comprar zapatos, cosméticos, ropa y sabanas. Ella y su esposo son personas responsables que siempre están dispuestos a trabajar para cumplir con sus pedidos.
texts.en:
Ms. Lydia Junieth sells general merchandise. She has three children who attend primary school, and the reason she has this business is in order to support her household. She goes out selling everyday, distributing her products. She goes out very early because her different customers live far apart from one another. Besides tending to her business, at home she takes the opportunity to tend to the needs of her family. Her dream is to be able to expand her business. Right now she needs this loan in order to buy shoes, cosmetics, clothing, and sheets. She and her husband are very responsible people who are always ready to work in order to fill their orders.

Translated from Spanish by Katie Kavanagh, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy shoes, cosmetics, clothing, and sheets

loans.name: Tolcayuca In Action Group

texts.es:
Este grupo se llama “Tolcayuca en acción”, el nombre se escogió  por ser un grupo D. mujeres emprendedoras y por el lugar D. ubicación del grupo,  El municipio se caracteriza por que L. mayoría D. los establecimientos son atendidos por mujeres jóvenes con una gran capacidad D. lucha por mejorar el nivel D. vida D. sus hijos, y familiares. Con L. idea D. que las mujeres del municipio tengan que se encuentran en L. localidad tengan un trabajo seguro. Y poder aportar al desarrollo del municipio. Las integrantes que conforman este grupo pertenecen al Estado D. Hidalgo,  El grupo está conformado por 11 integrantes.

L. foto fue tomada en L. casa D. L. señora María Natividad González V. es tesorera D. este grupo.  Se observa una gran armonía y compañerismo entre ellas. L. señora Natividad tiene 40años, estudió hasta secundaria. Es casada y tiene 3 hijos, 2 mujeres y  1 varón.  ElL. se dedica a L.  venta D. calzado por catalogo  que inició hace 1 año. Solicita el préstamo para invertir en  L. compra D. calzado y nuevos catálogos. Ya que su inquietud no es solo vender zapato si no también ropa y así poder vender más en poco tiempo. Sus clientes  comentan  que L. señora  Natividad es una persona muy amable y ofrece muy buen servicio, con un precio accesible ofreciendo facilidades D. pago semanales o D. contado D. acuerdo a sus posibilidades D. sus clientas.                                                                           
 Al momento D. solicitar este préstamo se  siente contenta ya que podrá mejorar sus ventas y luchar por el sueño D. su hijo que es seguir preparándose en su deporte favorito el Béisbol, ya que actualmente el joven juega en una liga y por su empeño le han otorgado una beca para continuar sus estudios y su preparación  educativa.
texts.en:
The name of this group is "Tolcayuca in Action". The name was chosen for the enterprising women members and for the location of the group. The municipality is known for the businesses that are run mostly by young women, each with a tremendous will to improve the quality of life for their children and their family. The members' plan is to have the women on that municipality to have steady work, and to bring renewed development to the region. The members of the group all are originally from the State of Hidalgo. There are 11 members in the group. The photo was taken in the house Maria Natividad G. V.. She is the treasurer of the group. A great harmony and collegiality exists among them. Natividad is 40 years old and she graduated high school. She is married and she has 3 children, 2 boys and a girl. She sells shoes through a catalogue and she has had the business for the past year. She requests a loan to invest in the purchase of shoes and new catalogues. Her wish is to not only sell shoes but also clothing to make more sales in less time. Her clients comment that Natividad is a very kind person and she provides great customer service. She sells her products at an accessible price and offers flexibility in payment methods, in cash or in credit with weekly payments, depending on the clients' situation. When she applied for the loan she was very happy to have the opportunity to improve her sales and to strive towards her dream of supporting her son as he readies for a career in Baseball. He currently plays in a league and his hard work has granted him a scholarship. He will continue his studies and his scholastic endeavors,

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise to improve their business.

loans.name: Manuel De Jesus

texts.es:
Manuel tiene 29 años, vive con su esposa y su hijo de 7 años de edad, residen en San Rafael Oriente, Departamento de San Miguel. Él posee un taller de estructuras metálicas y lo atiende desde las siete de la mañana hasta las cinco de la tarde desde hace 6 años, este oficio él lo aprendió por unos amigos que también tienen taller y le enseñaron a realizarlo perfectamente.
Las condiciones del taller son inadecuadas por lo que Manuel quiere mejorarlo pero no cuenta con el dinero necesario para la modificación por lo que solicita un préstamo para poder realizar el trabajo, su inversión será en madera, polines, láminas y de esta forma reparar el local.
Este préstamo le será útil pues necesita reparar el local y al realizar los cambios estará mas cómodo y seguro, no le afectaran las lluvias ni la delincuencia.
Las aspiraciones de Miguel son continuar con el taller en mejores condiciones, que sus ingresos aumenten para el sostenimiento de su familia y la educación de su hijo.
texts.en:
Manuel is 29 years old and lives with his wife and seven year old son, in San Rafael Oriente, within the San Miguel department.  He has a metal shop and for the past six years he has been there from 7:00 AM to 5:00 PM.  He learned this trade from some friends who also had a shop and they taught him well.

The shop’s condition is inadequate.  Manuel wants to improve it, but he doesn’t have the money he needs, so he is requesting this loan so he can do the work.  He will use the money to buy poles and metal in order to make some repairs to the shop.

This loan will be useful because he needs to repair the shop.  He will be more comfortable and secure once the improvements are made and he will no longer be affected by the rains or by the crime.

Miguel wants to continue with his shop, under better conditions.  He wants his income to increase so that he can support his family and pay for his son's education.

loans.use: Repairs to his shop

location.town: San Rafael de Oriente, San Miguel

loans.name: Maximo

texts.es: El Señor Máximo se dedica a la venta de accesorios de  vehículos desde hace dos años, anteriormente se dedicaba a trabajar como chofer pero vio que con la venta de accesorios se gana igual y a veces mejor que trabajando de chofer, razón por la que cambio de rubro, su negocio esta ubicado al borde del rio Kora, donde los transportistas traen sus vehículos para el lavado de estos, momento que aprovecha para la venta de sus productos, vive con su hija quien es casada  y trabaja de manera independiente. El señor  esta muy agradecido con la institución por la confianza a brindada en la otorgación del  crédito.
texts.en:
Mr. Máximo has dedicated himself to the sale of car accessories since two years ago. Before that, he worked as a chauffeur but realized that he would earn the same selling car accessories, which was sometimes better than working as a chauffeur. That is why he changed careers. His business is located on the border of the Kora river, where the haulers bring their vehicles to be washed. He takes advantages of the time it takes to wash the vehicles by selling his products. He lives with his daughter who is married and works independently from him. Mr. Máximo is very thankful for the institution for the trust he is given as he is entrusted with the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Amy Schapiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital for selling car accessories

loans.name: Sandra

texts.en:
Sandra belongs to the communal bank, Renacer “Rebirth”, located in the city of Chillan. She has been selling clothing for youth and adults, stuffed animals and cosmetics for the past nine years. Sandra started her retail businesses by selling underwear and, with time, changed her merchandise. She sells her products from home and also door-to-door. She also holds a second job working at a resort, “Termas de Chillán”. Her tasks include cleaning and assisting in decoration for events. 

Sandra plans to use this loan to purchase clothing. She travels to Santiago, the capital of Chile, where she is able to find her merchandise at wholesale prices thus reducing her costs. Her goal is to have an established business, located in front of her house, where she would sell the same products but could easily add new ones.
 
Sandra received economic assistance from the Chilean Government through a family subsidy. She was also able to twice win FOSIS (Fondo de Solidaridad e Inversión Social government agency, aimed at supporting the country's poorest families). Sandra obtained these FOSIS funds for her business a while ago. She used them to purchase a car to transport her merchandise and two mirrors as customers like to view and try on the clothing.
 
Sandra´s motivation stems from taking care of her children and providing them the opportunity to pursue their studies. Three of her children, aged 12, 13 and 18, still depend on her. In total Sandra has four children. The oldest is 20 and no longer lives with her. 

Sandra enjoys working with Kiva partner, Fondo Esperanza, as they did not ask her to provide her credit history and they only charge a small interest rate. Sandra has also learnt a lot through the experiences shared by her fellow communal bank members at the weekly meetings.
 
Chillan is a village in the south-central part of Chile. The name means ¨Chair of Sun¨ in Mapudungun, the language of our indigenous Mapuche population. Chillán is known as ¨birthplace of the country¨ or ¨land of the artists¨ because, in this region, many of the great figures of Chilean history were born, like the well-known pianist Claudio Arrau.

loans.use: merchandise: clothing

loans.name: Mujeres Trabajadoras Group

texts.es:
Las mujeres del presente comité son del barrio Virgen de los Remedios  de Tobatí.
Las señoras están muy satisfechas con el apoyo económico que les está brindando la Fundación Paraguaya, con este capital las señoras están aumentando sus pequeños negocios y así también sus ingresos para una mejor calidad de vida y la de sus hijos.
Las señoras  están en el ciclo Nº  4º con sus 11 integrantes. 

Todas las integrantes del comité están muy agradecidas con la Fundación Paraguaya por el valioso apoyo que les brinda para poder mejorar sus condiciones financieras en la sociedad.
Una de las integrantes es la señora Eliodora quien se dedica a la venta de comestibles en su casa. Esta actividad la ayuda muchísimo para los gastos de sus hijos, especialmente para la educación y a también la alimentación de los mismos.
Su puesto de venta se encuentra en un lugar estratégico,  de esta manera ella vende todos los días gran cantidad de comestible, especialmente empanadas, el comestible más vendido por ella.
Solicita el préstamo para la compra de ingredientes que ella utiliza para la elaboración de sus preparados.
texts.en:
The women in this group are from the Virgen de los Remedios de Tobatí neighborhood. These women are very satisfied with the economic support that Fundación Paraguaya has offered them. Through this funding, the women have expanded their small businesses and thereby improved the quality of life they and their children have. These women are in their 4th loan cycle and there are 11 members. All of the members of this group are very grateful to Fundación Paraguaya for the valuable support it offers them, so that they may improve their financial conditions in society. One of the members is Ms. Eliodora, who sells food from her house. This business helps a great deal with her children's expenses, especially for education and nutrition. Her sales stand is in a strategic location. This is how she sells a large amount of food every day, especially empanadas, which are the food she sells the most of. She is requesting this loan to purchase ingredients she uses to make the food she prepares.

Translated from Spanish by Katie Kavanagh, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy meat, condiments, vegetables, fruits, and other ingredients

loans.name: Pablo Roberto

texts.es: El Joven Pablo Roberto tiene 35 años, tiene 6 hijos a su cargo. Su actividad es una pulpería, por lo que hace más de 8 años que se dedica a este negocio que Inicio por la necesidad de tener un empleo y proveerle a su familia un medio de ingreso que le fuera de ayuda pues inicio con pocos productos, pero eran los más necesarios y los que sus clientes solicitaban, esta no es la primera vez que realiza financiamientos, pues han sido muy necesarios para el avance de su actividad. Este crédito es para la compra de materia prima como golosinas, refrescos, pan, gaseosas, detergentes y granos básicos.
texts.en:
Pablo Roberto is 35 years old and has six children under his care. He has a general store. He has had this business for more than 8 years. He started it because he needed a job to provide income to support his family. He started with few products, only staples requested by his customers. This is not the first time he requests a loan as they are a necessary tool to advance his business. This loan will be used to purchase inventory such as snacks, juices, bread, sodas, detergent and basic grains.

Translated from Spanish by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Narciso

texts.es: El Sr. Narciso Vive en la localidad de los Limos distante a 10 km de la comunidad de Santa Rita, perteneciente al municipio de el Torno, tiene una parcela de 10 hectáreas donde se dedica a la agricultura y ganadería, su esposa con la cual tiene 5 hijos, de los cuales dos están estudiando y los demás son pequeño, ella se dedica al mantenimientos de los animales y al cuidado de sus hijos, mientras que el se dedica a la agricultura por lo que el destino del crédito es para la siembra de arroz y sorgo que es el producto que le da mayor ingresos durante el año su esposa le ayuda a comercializarlo en el mercado de el Torno, esta muy agradecido con la institución por el apoyo brindado.
texts.en:
Narciso lives in Los Limos, located 10km from the Santa Rita community in the town of Torno. He has a 10-hectare lot of land where he plants and raises cattle. He has five children with his wife. Two of them go to school and the others are still too young to go. His wife raises the animals and takes care of the children while he works in agriculture.
